review_text:
I went into this hoping for the best, in spite of how negative everything is surrounding [i]Redfall,[/i] but this really is bad. Before I get really negative, the big highlight for me was the backstory for the world. I wished the main/present narrative would have followed the tone of the "[can't remember the name right now] Echoes" and all of the notes you find around the world. If they'd gone in a more [i]Dishonored[/i] route and made this with a tone that didn't feel like a sh***y Joss Whedon script, I would have enjoyed the plot too. The antagonists have some pretty good lines and have some of the best performances in the whole game.
But that's it. Those are my only positives.

The gunplay is awful. Swapping weapons takes too long, reloading takes too long (even when you get better versions of those guns, the stats barely change except for the DPS), every shot feels like it is RNG on Damage (shotguns especially), vampires hit you even if you're 10 feet away, you get stuck on nothing or fall through the world randomly, climbing is super bipolar, upgrades are mostly useless except for the community perks, and I could go on. Everything feels stupid janky. I ended up sticking with the same 3 guns in my loadout after killing The Hollow Man. The biggest failing of this game is the absence of matchmaking, just an absolutely moronic decision. After you collect 80/100 Grave Locks, the game starts recycling the first 20 Gateway audio diaries. Why even record so much if you weren't gonna fulfil each one? Why have there be ONE-HUNDRED of these things to begin with? Just to pad out the abysmal runtime?

I hated the protagonists. The same 12 quips over and over, mixed with just terrible abilities (I can say though, I can see how each character's powers would be better in co-op, but I have no friends, so that's just a theory). I wanted to take the main cast seriously but the combination of cringe "that just happened"/"first-draft" dialogue and the mediocre performances dragged everything down. I also couldn't take anything seriously due to the crap "cutscene" animatics. They felt cheap. I wish the heroes lost.

probably not worth full price(i got it for like 10 bucks) but its honestly really fun

Like a game 70% done.  It will randomly crash. Not a polished game and lacks the storyline depth that I love from Arkane Studios. Bummer.

Yeah I recommend it, I don't care. The only things that I like about this game are the Fortnite-esque graphics which I'm partial to, and the Fall setting which I'm VERY partial to. Despite the fact this game is an abhorrent abomination, I still appreciate that they did some good here... only SOME. It's bare-bones and awful in ways, but it's got a good atmosphere and I like CHORES. It's a CHORES game. If you like CHORES then Redfall is good. I think it's good.

I bought this back when it came out and then stopped playing it before finishing it once the Development Studio got shutdown by Microsoft. 

Great idea, horrible implementation.  The game is a buggy mess and has been since Day 1, patches were released but never made it any better.  The main story is "ok", but the side missions and safe house missions are boring and repetitive. 

Such a shame, could've been a great game but once again got nerfed by Microsoft.
If you're in the mood for either a vampire game or a looter shooter that's merely "fine", pick it up on sale.  Otherwise, skip it.

The game is fine i've played worse and when i played with friends i had fun when it launched and since they added the few updates and patches to improve the game i like it even more now i would give it a 7/10 now

I've loved this game so far, had no issues at all and the game has been really fun.
It's now a completely working game and it's definitely worth playing, it's very unfortunate the terrible release has killed the game because it has so much potential to it and i'd love an expansion/sequel.

After completing the game i have to say the final boss fight was a complete let down, i was expecting more from that fight.

Still loved the game and really disappointing we'll never get a sequel as in its current state it's a really solid and fun game.

The beginning feels super hard but after you rack up the community standing it becomes super easy again, bosses are a lot tougher but still beatable as long as you have up to date weapons, last boss once again was a complete disappointment, by far easiest of them all, i disappointed myself hoping for a secret second phase on eclipse but nope. Since some achieves are coop only and i play solo i've given myself them as i complete the story with them, one day i'll come back to the game and do the others but doing 100% runs both times was enough for me for now. They had me surrounded ;)

There's simply no way to recommend this game to anyone outside of a purchase price of $5. The story is bad and told through a series of stillshots like powerpoint slides which totally remove the player from engagement. The characters are bad, not just the character designs but the fact that they have two specific powers that aren't all that fun to even use. The gameplay itself is incredibly bland, the AI being brainless kind of makes the enemy encounters feel dull almost immediately, it's yet another looter shooter leveled system, and the weapons altogether just aren't interesting. If I will give this game any praise for anything, it's that the only semi-decent thing about the game in its entirety is the world design and asset quality. It feels like the environment artists they put in charge were really good at what they do, it's just a shame that their talents were wasted on this game.

this is going to sound crazy but its not bad. i mean its not that good ether but if you get it for like 10 bucks then its A very good deal. i don't know man i had a pretty good time for the price i paid. bring a buddy and it gets a little better.just don't go into it expecting a 10/10. go into it expecting a like 6/10 then you will have a better time.

Redfall is basically Far Cry 3 but with vampires.

Recently picked it up for $20 on sale on Steam and I wouldnt recommend buying it for anything over that price. I had heard about the awful reviews and bugs and hate, but I have a bit of a love for trashy games.

So I decided to check it out and honestly, it felt like playing an xbox 360 game.

There are

    Open world map with safehouses you need to reclaim and a tonne of collectable items.
    Leveling up/perk system thats very basic
    Loot system that is just the same guns but higher damage and maybe one perk on it that makes it good
    Go to A, kill enemies, basically being the bulk of your missions
    Awkward terrain traversal/platforming

It should be noted though that the game was updated to be playable offline.

By the time I played I didnt get any noticeable bugs or glitches other than the game crashing once when I fast travelled and a collectible item (cosmetics) being stuck at 99% even though i had collected all of them (tbh this one really pissed me off despite being inconsequential, there wasnt even an achievement for 100% collection i just hated seeing it not completed).

Surprisingly decent variety of enemies too, you have your regular humans but there are different factions. Basic thugs, mercenaries and cultists, alongside vampires.

The vampires have special types like the angler that pulls you to them with a hook, or the shroud that obscures your vision by dropping a ring of smoke around you that moves with you so you have to run around until you run into the shroud so you can kill them (they throw ranged attacks at you thankfully so thats how you track them).

Least favourite vampire type was the siphon that basically tethers to you and starts draining your health and only way to break it is to either down him or break line of sight.

This one really fucks you over in open areas but luckily i picked the character that ended up being the most broken (Devinder).

The a.i isnt anything special, they shoot, they flank, they rush, they run, what youd expect from enemy ai but the challenge mostly comes from the vampires bum rushing you at melee range while the humans shoot at you from afar.

The human enemies are oddly deep for being throwaway goons, you can hear them talking to each other and theyll talk about selling out their friends and families to the vampires to survive.

Some feel guilt, others wanted power, others were just using this as a chance to off of someone they didnt like. Even weirder they'll often cry out when you kill their allies, get used to hearing "that was my friend you asshole!" when ever you kill someone.

I played on the 2nd hardest difficulty which is midnight, the hardest difficulty is locked behind eclipse which you need to beat the game once to unlock.

Overall there is enough variety of enemies for the game to feel fresh throughout your playthrough, which shouldnt be long.

I essentially 100%'ed the game collecting everything and doing every mission and sidequest and it still only took a little over 20 hours.

I managed to bang this out over a weekend and a friday.

The story is all style and no substance, cool premise but there arent even any animated cutscenes.

The cutscenes are literally just slideshows with someone narrating over them.

There is some cool lore and environmental story telling but the problem is that its all in codexs and journals lying around and i find that the laziest form of story telling.

Even more dissapointing is how dark the game actually is, but it loses its oomph when its all in written text.

For example a family lured another family member back home so they could kill her and use her blood in a ritual to become vampires.

You can even find the body in the basement, despite that because you read it the impact is lessened imo.

Another scene has a soldier torture a nurse begging for her life, where they put her in a kiddie pool and electrocute her until she dies.

But its done in this weird spirit flashback way so alot of the heaviness is lost.

Its this weird tonal whiplash that kinda shocked me at first cos you have Devinder talking about "what up youtube its ya boi again fighting eldritch horrors and shit, welcome back to innocents massacred monday" and then they hit you with the above.

Speaking of Devinder, hes basically a streamer who chases after the paranormal.

I had heard alot about the "millenial" writing in this game, about how its cringe and very "hes right behind me, isnt he?" styled.

But honestly, I didnt really see much of it, granted i only played Dev but he was actually quite morose after the initial opening of the game.

Spoiler alert but basically the vampires became vampires because a girl had special blood that gave people super powers.

The game tries to science it up but its basically magic if were being real.

Doctors come along, convince her to use her blood to help others, realise her power, and bleed her dry and use the blood to turn themselves into vampire gods.

Dev's character arc (what little there is) basically goes from guy whos giddy about discovering real vampires, to guy who wants to avenge this girl who suffered and he becomes much more serious.

Simple but effective, and the voice acting was really good. As for the other characters I dont know, maybe they suck, but Dev was cool.

The setting is real unique, and I really loved the environment, seeing these new england style houses really tickled me for some reason.

unfortunately the game has two maps. Map 1 you kill the first boss. map 2 has 3 bosses.

Why they split this up I do not know but for some reason you CANT GO BACK TO THE FIRST MAP ONCE YOU LEAVE.

It does warn you about this so i did everything before leaving but why even do this?

The loot system sucks ass im gonna be straight up. Basically the same 5 guns except yellow is the best colour and grey is the worst, ground breaking stuff.

Im not gonna lie i put drum and bass music playlist 24/7 on the background and kinda just zoned out playing this, it was kinda like i was in a trance (kinda ironic cos in this game being a vampire is called being under the blood trance).

And i enjoyed it, dont get me wrong this shit is not even close to a masterpiece, hell im even hesitant to say its good, but despite it all, i still had fun in a way.

I can genuinely say I liked playing this, (NOT AS A CO-OP HUGE BUG THE GAME CRASHES ON CO-OP ONCE YOU HIT MAP 2 AND IT NEVER GOT FIXED).

Like if this came out in the state it is now with all the bugs patched and ai fixed in 2012, i could see it being a hit.

Truth be told its just an old game, that just hasnt evolved, but i was feeling nostalgic and thats what this game did.

I wouldnt recommend this game, im not deluded into thinking people would like playing a game that was time capsuled from the early 2010's into 2023 but I think sometimes you run into a game thats emulating the right era and your mind is in the right time frame and it just clicks.

Overall I think the hate RedFall got was justified on release, but as it is now, its a fun quaint little throwback.

Fun little side notes

    . Apparently werewolves exist in this world

    . theres 100 audio file collectibles called grave locks but only 84 recordings made, so for the last 16 they just pick a random audio file youve already discovered and play that

    . the girl whos blood made the vampires spirit arrives at the end as a spirit and thanks you, but shes stuck in limbo untill all vampires die, which is kinda hell when you think about it and also sequel bait

    . the female vampires in this game are so fucking hot i swear to god

    . this would be arkane austins last game before they got shut down

Not worth the price tag but if you want something to yet again play while your brain is turned off, go for it (I guess).

For an Arkane Austin game, this one was pretty disappointing. A step down from their previous title, Deathloop, with much less love and attention. Less FPS mechanics than previous titles, stale story, and very stale gameplay. Fighting the same group of enemies around every street corner. I tried to hang in there, but it just didn't have enough to keep me playing.

 I know it's not Arkane's fault, they were rushed to wrap this up so Bethesda could get Starfield and their remasters out the door instead of letting them do what they do best and make AAA top-tier immersive sims. Oh well, congrats Bethesda. No pun intended, this really was the nail in the coffin for me.

I don't know why Redfall got so much hate.
 Granted I'm playing years after the release so a lot of stuff might have been fixed but the game is pretty fun. In my first day I put 9hrs on it and I'm playing solo. The world is pretty cool and the fights are challenging enough not to bore you, you need to watch how you're approaching them because you can die very fast.
 If you enjoyed Deathloop I suggest you give it a try.
Not good at all

The game is now mostly fixed, No need for internet connection, steady 60hz gramerate, dlss and better gameplay overall. Indeed there are still some unreal engine crashes here and there but nothing serious.
Arkane Austin certainly deserved better.

Oh boy, even at -50% it is still overpriced. You know why? The game can't be launched.
Yeah you heard me, I didnt say "doesnt launch" or "crashes at launch", no, I said "cant be launched.
Why?
Because I get stuck on a screen with "connecting to bethesda servers" (that stuff never worked in any games btw, just check Doom eternals) and to progress I have to click on the EULA agreement that is stuck BEHIND that "connecting" screen.
That I cant fucking click, because Arkane Austin produced this abomination, and after learning that their heads was about to roll, they decided to sabotage the connection to this pile of shit. Man I don't know, I don't know how to explain the dread that filled me when I saw that there was an option for infinite ammo right off the bat, in a looter shooter. And now this.
This motherfucking EULA trap screen.

I'm glad i'm getting refunded, and i'm glad i'm addind my negative review to the already long, long list of negative reviews for this abhorrent pile of dog puke.

I got the game hoping for something closer to Arkane's previous games. Yes I saw the reviews, but I held out hope that the game had since been fixed. While the game is completely playable, it didn't have any of the elements I'd hoped for. It didn't feel immersive. Stealth is hardly an option, but only if you play as Jacob and spec into the tree in a specific way. Combat is hardly better. Enemies' behavior is unintelligent, and their animations often break. Looking for a good story? Find a different game. It could have made for a very story rich game, but it seems they'd spent all their budget on the world creation. That being the only reason I'm leaving a thumbs-up. If you're the type of person who just likes to explore an interesting looking world, this one is one of the most interesting worlds I've seen in a video game. Often gorgeous. But I myself am more interested in the gameplay. Nothing special there. In fact, it often felt clunky to navigate the world due to the detail put into it. I don't know the details of why the game turned out so terribly, but it's a shame what happened anyways.

In conclusion: I recommend only getting the game if you're mostly interested in the "unique" world they'd crafted. There's apparently an easy difficulty if that's what you're looking for. The game sometimes goes on sale for 50% off, so I'd wait and get it then.

Note: In order to get through the licensing agreement when I first booted up the game, I had to do some trick I found online. I don't remember exactly what I had to do, but if you have the same issue, you can look it up.
The only positive I can find is that the game no longer launches, the spinning log in circle is vastly more entertaining than this shovelware.

I'm aware of the problems this game has, and still it's an enjoyable experience. 
You can't expect a "game of the year" but definitely a fun shooter-looter with strong world-building and at least 7-10 hours of main storyline missions. 
For a discount, definitely worth it. Even in single-player.

A lot of people shit on this game because of how Microsoft handled it, and while I will include that I see little talk about the actual game, so I want to give my opinion from the eyes of someone who's played a lot of it and knew nothing of the drama surrounding it.

Story - 
The Good:

The story in this game is fantastic. With each mission you learn about how Redfall came to be a hellhole, and who's responsible for it. A lust for power in a group of people who take advantage of a gift meant to nurture and help others, twisted into a weapon to build themselves up and disposing of anyone who tried to stop them. It's dark, and you get a real feeling of accomplishment as you take down each member of the group. 
You have a hub in both sections of the game; Redfall and Burial Point, with survivors who have their own stories and side missions you can complete. Some of them are bland, but a lot of them are fun, contain interesting story, and they feel real. It's not all sunshine and rainbows, not every mission ends well for the characters. It adds to the immersion and feels fresh compared to other games where the side missions are usually low effort fetch quests.
Now, counter point to what I just said, there are definitely missions that are just fetch quests but they are mostly few and far between.
You can see how this world can bend and even break people, and how others band together to survive. It's something that I feel like a lot of games have really forgotten, that sometimes a good story doesn't HAVE to have a completely happy ending. People break, people die, and it's not always fair.

The Bad:

You know basically nothing going into the game, and if you don't try to pay attention, you can miss a lot. My first run I basically missed the story because it's a lot of drawn out talking. There are cut-scenes in the game, but they are 3-D stills with your character just talking. The mix of slow reveal with slow exposition really drags it down. (Depending on which character you're playing you get different dialogue, that's something I don't think I've seen before and is interesting)
It does feel like the story didn't quite fit a full 15-20 hour game and got stretched out as far as it could. I 100% 'ed the game (All collectibles, all side missions, etc.) so it took longer, but if you were just wanting to play the main story, you could realistically beat this game in about 9-12 hours.

Gameplay- 

The Good:

The 4 characters you can choose from each have their own abilities and skill trees, but the main crux of the game is the guns and staking vampires. The guns feel pretty good to control, and there's plenty of variety for what kind of weapon you want to wield. You can have up to 3 weapons equipped and its completely up to you how you want to run. You want to snipe people? Sniper, Smg, and pistol. Like being up close? Smg, Shotgun, steak launcher. Big fan of explosions? Shotgun, Flaregun, Steak launcher. Etc...

Each character has 2 skills and an ultimate ability. Depending on your playstyle you'll prefer one over the other, but they boil down to:

Sniper
Psychic
Gunner
Stunner

I like the different characters, they each have their own story and reason for being in Redfall in the first place, they aren't just the guy you play, they react to what happens around you. If you play co-op with someone, there is an entire trust system between your characters who talk to each other and joke around.

The Bad: 

This game got 4 major updates before support for it ended and it is still a glitchy and broken mess at times. 
The game stutters a lot, crashes are common (especially after you reach Burial Point), but the main technical issue with this game is that it just has bugs that will now never be fixed.
My first run of this game was Co-op with my husband and it was a 50/50 chance that when I hit PLAY the lobby just wouldn't launch and say error. I was able to fix this by forcing the game to always run in Administrator mode, which also fixed a lot of the stuttering and frame issues I had, but the game should be more optimized than it is.
There doesn't seem to be any one trigger that causes the game to crash, but they happen more often than I'd like. And be careful playing co-op because it seems that bugs and crashes are more likely when playing with others. 

The skill trees feel weak, some perks are insanely great and feel like they shouldn't have been locked behind a skill, and others are completely pointless. You can respec your skill tree at any time, as long as you have 10,000 support to spend (Which you eventually will have LOTS to spend).
The Community Standing board that also unlocks perks for the entire party that feels very similar. Some are great and others are basically nothing, but it costs Support instead of skill points.

Support is this games version of currency, which you get by completing tasks, killing vampires, picking up junk items, and scrapping weapons. In the beginning you'll struggle to gather enough and have to chose between buying more ammo or picking up a new perk. But once you get about 1/4th of the way through the game, you'll just forget you needed it. When my husband and I got to Burial Point we had almost 2 million combined with every community standing perk already bought. It feels like this system is kind of just useless once you reach a certain point.

A key part of this game is the weapon quality system which is a highly debated topic but I have to be honest, it feels out of place. I think if it was just an unlocking system with perks specifically for the types of weapons you had it would be way better. (Example: You start with a pistol and find/unlock new weapons as you continue, you can choose which weapons you want to use, and each weapon has it's own skill tree)
It really does feel like corporate said: "People like Fortnite, make it like Fortnite."

Which brings me to...

The External Situation:

I can't confidently say exactly what happened, but it boils down to Microsoft trying to make a AAA MMO game out of what was supposed to be a story driven game. They jacked up the price to 70$ and made the team go in the looter-shooter direction, which is a stark contrast to the other games this team has put out before (Prey, Dishonored, Etc.)
Microsoft put money over players and it shows, but that's not even the part that makes me angry.
After the backlash of the game's release filled with bugs, broken AI, and how the game just is in general with the choices they made, Microsoft decided to just abandon the game, close the studio, fire 96 people, and write it off as a loss. Which is not only just a giant shit in the face of Arkane Austin, who tried their absolute best to bring this game to life, but also feels like a slap in the face to the players as well. 
I really like the story in this game, and I wish we could get more of it, but that will never happen because it was fumbled. And that's the main problem with gaming today, its more about money and less about making something people will enjoy.

Overall, I think this game has more hate than it should. I do think that the current price of $40 is too much, it should be a solid $20 game, especially in it's current state with no future support for it. The initial $70 price was absolutely ridiculous.

But these points should not be against the game itself, it should be against the company that ruined it. Microsoft. It's so sad to see another great IP lost because the company that owns it sucks.

If you can grab this game while it's on sale and have the patience to deal with it's faults it's honestly a great time. My husband and I have been playing it nonstop since we bought it and laughed through the bugs while enjoying the fun of it. I wouldn't recommend buying it full price (I bought a key online and it cost me $10) but I would recommend playing it before they decide to axe the servers forever.
6.5/10

Bethesda no longer supports the game. It can still be purchased (on both Steam and Bethesda's homepage) but if you cannot log in to the Bethesda servers that are required to play. You can only watch a spinning circle say "Connecting". If you have already logged in via this game, it might not required you to do so again so current players may not have this issue.

Entirely unironically, the game is fine. Yes, it released badly, the story is practically nonexistent, it's a little repetitive, and it suffers some horrendous balance issues regarding solo play and the character abilities, but the game as it is right now is genuinely fine. The aesthetic is good, guns feel basically fine, it looks alright with its stylised graphics and runs basically fine once you get around a connection bug that got left behind when the game got abandoned. Just run it in offline mode once you get past the bug (can be selected in the options menu) and it'll run just fine with very few game-breaking technical issues. 

Including the running around, grinding and doing the collectables, it took me 20-ish hours to beat, and other than the balance issues with enemies CLEARLY not designed with solo play in mind I genuinely didn't hate my time with it.

If you're curious, just don't pay full price. Like, 20 bucks on sale feels right for something this length that was abandoned. Friendly tip though, Devinder is the only character worth playing solo since all of his abilities are obscenely strong and help dealing with the balance issues with certain enemy types due to the abilities' high levels of stun, stagger and damage. He's also got the best traversal tool since it can be thrown through windows to ignore certain puzzles and platforming sequences, and his unique weapon (acquired late game) is also by a wide margin the best of the four. 

DO NOT play as Layla or you WILL have a bad time, much worse than your lowest expectations, as her abilities are largely useless.

I really don't get why everyone hates this game. Sure, its mechanics could stand to be more unique and characters could use some more customization, but I think its a solid looter-shooter with a decent storyline and well done open world/ open zone design. People say its because it doesn't stand up to Arkane's previous work, but I only played the intros to Dishonored and Prey and haven't gotten too far in either to really hold one up vs the other at this point in time. I'm sure when i've played all the dishonored games, prey, and this, I will look back and think of this as the least interesting, but as my FIRST Arkane game its not bad.

EDIT: 100% Achievement Review - The most annoying parts about getting 100% achievements in this game were a) having to get together a full 4 person party and playing the entirety of act 1 again in order to build trust levels to get the 'Friends 'Til The End' achievement. 
and b) the fact that there isn't a true 'save game' in this game, and if you mess up one of the achievements, you have to play a whole other character to get to the same spot to try again. This wasn't so bad when I was trying to get an achievement in Act 1, but for the Lost Unit quest in Act 2 I failed TWICE and had to get a THIRD CHARACTER to Act 2 in order to finish it. I was ready to give up on this game if I failed it with the stealth specialist as well...

All said and done, I did have a lot of fun with this game, even if some of the achievements were a bit frustrating at times.

[h1]PROs:[/h1]
‚úÖ Rich with lore through numerous notes and readable items.
‚úÖ Great potential for co-op shenanigans.
‚úÖ Solid variety of skills and weapons.
‚úÖ Distinctive and well-executed artistic style.
‚úÖ Good original soundtrack.

[h1]CONs:[/h1]
‚ùå Excessive junk loot with little to no purpose.
‚ùå The co-op is completely broken on the second map, making the game impossible to finish.
‚ùå The world feels empty and inconsistent in many areas.
‚ùå Characters are visually unappealing and bland, with what feels like forced diversity.
‚ùå Numerous game-breaking bugs in co-op that require restarting the session.
‚ùå The weapon affix system quickly becomes stale, removing the excitement of finding cool new items.
‚ùå Poor enemy AI.

[h1]Comments:[/h1]
Honestly, this game had some rather solid ideas and a promising combination of genres. A big kudos to the writers who fleshed out the world with plenty of lore. The game also ran smoothly, and the combat, for the most part, felt satisfying.

Unfortunately, the game is hampered by too many "unfinished" and "bare minimum" features that make the overall experience lackluster.

We were unable to finish the game because the co-op on the second map is completely broken. After a certain point, we were met with a permanent loading screen. My friend even rushed to the same point on a new save, and the issue persisted, preventing us from progressing. The only potential workaround might be to complete the entire second map in a single session, but that comes with its own risks.

The game also suffers from quite a few bugs, some of which are game-breaking and force a complete restart. So, if you do attempt a single-session run of the second map, you'll need to hope you don't encounter one of these issues.

While key areas of the world featured some nice designs, the environment suffered from inconsistencies, oddities, and bugs, such as chests spawning inside objects or assets floating and clipping through the terrain.

In conclusion, this game can offer a fun co-op experience if you're willing to overlook its massive amount of unfinished content, unpolished features, and frequent bugs. You'll have to squint even harder to ignore the inconsistent, lifeless world and bland characters.

The best parts of the game were its conceptual gunplay, loot system, and skills. It‚Äôs a real shame that the game was seemingly abandoned and the developers let go, leaving it as an unfinished, buggy mess that was rushed to release.

This game is overly-hated and very underrated its just great Vampire action. Its a shame we wont ever see from this IP again along with new content/updates. Rating: 7.5/10 (Read on for long review)
-
Ill get it out of the way first and start with the bad, the story and cinematics are trash. The dialogue has some charm, if you look at them as a cute comic lines. But you wont get anything seriously good here narratively. Character designs look so dumb, the overly cartoon character models is just giving "Fortnite" and feels off putting for a game like this. Performance isnt the best, on a RTX 4080 im still seeing mediocre Framerate on Ultra at 1080p.
-
Now as far as everything else i think the game does really well. UI design is amazing, i think to this day is still some of the best UI i've seen in a game. Its clean, nicely animated and aesthetically pleasing. Matching the Vampire tone while still looking really modern. 
-
Gun play is great. I will say at first, the gun handling felt very amateur. HOWEVER the moment i got that first blue pistol with increased accuracy and fire rate, then turned ON aim assist... yes for mouse and yes it does feel nice lol. The gun play then started feeling great. 
-
The progression from the the skill tree and community trees are awesome. It keeps me wanting to play more and makes me want to interact with side content and explore the area. This is a good loop to keep me going back to those safe houses and progressing my characters power.
-
Exploration and level design in this game are just utterly amazing i always get that feeling "Oh i wonder whats over there." that feeling is really nice in an open world game. Where in many other open world games you just tend to book it to the objective. The verticality is great too you can climb many things. Lots of side activities and interesting locations like mansions, beat up towns, out cast forests, to seaside docks. It all feels so fresh.
-
Another positive is the game will sporadically have horror moments, in caves, even in houses and random spots. Playing late at night i did get a little spooked, as the game began to build tension on me. Thats the exact feeling i want in a Vampire game. 
-
Another underrated aspect the sound and music is all really great here, building suspense or getting you pumped for fights or even re-spawning at a safe house, while the music rejuvenates you to go out just one more time it all just sounds really cool.
-
Now its not game of the year or anything, but for what it is a looter shooter in a vampire word, set in a lush foresty dark Massachusetts... Everything i personally enjoy in setting and tone. Its amazing, ill likely continue all the way to the end im curious to see where things go and the progression is doing enough to keep me invested. I certainly think this game is a must play if you can find it for under $20. With its rough release, people didn't want to give it another look after many updates but this game is great and severely underrated. Unfortunately we will never see content or another look at this IP again. But give it a go its probably the best 7.5/10 game you will ever play. Dont go in with crazy expectations and you will have fun.

It's just so bad...

I think for its current price (less than 30 bucks) and after all the updates since release, you'll get your moneys worth

 The level design is pretty great, the Locations felt well thought out and usually more than just being a set piece to kill some vampires in

There's a couple missions that show what the game could have been, but there's so many avenues the game could have gone that would have made it fundamentally more enjoyable

Any semblance of spookiness, or dare I say horror is gone when you add legit heroes to the mix, at least for me.
I enjoy the characters and their personality, but why should someone with supernatural abilities and a vampire ex-boyfriend be scared of the current setting? Or a supernatural phenomen hunter?

The levels themselves can actually build some atmosphere, and creeping around corridors with your flashlight, with some silhouettes hushing around or humanoid figures casting shadows in your field of view feels honestly great. Add in the constant droning of cult leader speeches and you can get decently immersed in the game.
I also enjoyed the constant mistery behind the vampire outbreak, every new piece of information just opened up more questions behind the key figures and their motivations.

Once the action starts though the game kinda falls apart. You use your different arrays of abilites and blast through vampires. The different "elite" vampire types are nice to have in the game, but are, at best, annoying to fight against.  The different character abilities are decent fun, but event the most fun abilities and interactions can't make unfun enemies fun to fight against.
A slower paced, more grounded approach to combat would have helped here in my opinion.

Enemy AI is pretty basic, humanoid enemies stay in cover usually, vampires just bolt straight at you.

The weapons are fun to use, and while there is some variety to them, when a massive part of your game is the potential loot grind you need wayyyy more options to choose from. The aiming with mouse also never felt quite right, and more weapon customization would have been welcome. Let me fit a suppressor on weapons and switch scopes

If you've got time to kill, enjoy arkanes worldbuilding and can get behing most loot shooters, I'd say give this game a try when its on a discount
There is some fun here, still has problems though, with the ESC button not working properly.

For $10 it was well worth it for that price for a key. Especially compared to other more recent "AAA" FPS games that are masked as AAA games and priced accordingly, but really are quite frankly just bland, boring, by-the-numbers, extremely linear snorefests, like for instance the atrociously boring Atomic Heart.

I had to do a couple things to get it running right but it didn't take long. The first thing I had to do was to try and figure out why it kept crashing, twice in 45 minutes, and luckily someone in the forums discovered that turning off upscaling fixed the crashing and so far it has worked. I had to experiment a little bit with vsync. In-game vsync sucks, so I had to disable it, set frames to unlimited, and set vsync in the nvidia control panel to 'fast'. Setting it to just 'on' gives you bad input lag in the game so I found that setting it to 'fast' fixed it. I tried nvidia reflex but it makes the game run like crap so I turned it off.

If you like FPS games, even ones that are average at best like this one, pick it up for cheap.

Is it a bad game? No.

It's an Ok game. 

Animations are a bit janky, it has some bugs with the animations, they skipped doing the cutscenes in motion and are done with 3D models standing still in poses while your character narrates something.

The graphics are ok, heavily stylized like previous Arkane titles but its a bit more demanding while not looking much better, and getting minor stuttering (nothing major like some modern games)

The loot is a bit poor, it feels like the loot pool is really small with a really small legendary variety. And the gameplay loop feels a bit repetitive by the time you are finishing, the side content from the safe houses is repeating the same 2-3 types of missions then a boss, while the secondary quests from the Hubs are more unique there are way less of them.

Overall the game feels like it was rushed out of the gate, and they suffered for it sadly, the story on itself wasn't bad, characters were ok, and the setting was interesting, but i can only recommend the game if you grab it on a sale with a steep discount if you want to play a shorter looter shooter solo or with a buddy (i played solo i can't say anything about co-op)

That said, I also must say, I actually had some fun playing earlier on and after the last big release/update, the game gave me a better experience. And I also did have fun playing this game lately to be honest. I tried out 3 characters and finished the game with 1 (solo). I see myself potentially returning to complete the game with the other characters one day, perhaps with friends in co-op. Each character has it's own gameplay to a certain level and can make your experience different, which promotes replayability.

Is the game on Triple A level? No.
Worth the full (release) price? No.
Worth buying on sale? Yes (which I did).
Is the game fun to play? Yes (solo and co-op), but don't expect a triple A level game.

My advantage was that I‚Äôve never played the game when it was released but in its final patch state and what can I say? It‚Äôs a solid game that is fun. Sure, the characters look a bit woke and the NPC (the priestess lol) is ‚Äûspecial‚Äú but meh. It‚Äôs actually a fine game. Not in my top games of course but I didn‚Äôt regret buying it on sale.

Redfall ‚Äì A Second Chance Worth Taking

I recently reinstalled Redfall after shelving it shortly after launch, and honestly? I‚Äôm impressed. This game had a rough start‚Äîno denying that. At release, it was plagued with performance issues, lackluster AI, and just felt unfinished. Like many, I dropped it with a sense of disappointment. But curiosity got the better of me, and after hearing about a string of updates, I gave it another shot.

I‚Äôm glad I did.

After diving back in, I spent around four hours exploring the vampire-infested world of Redfall, both solo and in online co-op with friends‚Äîand I can confidently say the experience is so much smoother now. The combat feels sharp and responsive, movement is fluid, and best of all, I didn‚Äôt encounter a single crash or noticeable bug. Lag? Gone. Enemies? Actually engaging. The improvements are real.

There‚Äôs a strange satisfaction in clearing out vampire nests or teaming up to take down cultist strongholds. The atmosphere is still there‚Äîcreepy yet oddly beautiful in its own way‚Äîand with the technical issues ironed out, it finally feels immersive. The servers are also still very much alive, which was a pleasant surprise, especially when jumping into co-op with minimal matchmaking issues.

Do I wish this was the version of Redfall we got at launch? Absolutely. But sometimes games need time to become what they were meant to be. It‚Äôs clear the dev team has been working hard behind the scenes to get this title into fighting shape.

If you were burned at launch, I get it‚Äîbut if you still have it in your library or you‚Äôre on the fence about trying it, now might be the time to give it a second look. It‚Äôs not perfect, but it‚Äôs definitely playable‚Äîand more importantly, fun.

Played solo as Jacob ‚Äì after the final patch.

Far from the most terrible game ever made, Redfall is a bog-standard, by-the-numbers looter-shooter. Too easy and not scary. PC performance is fixed though. 
5/10
Total size on my ssd: 71.8 GB

+ Performance is fixed. Redfall ran smooth and stutter-free for me (5950X +4070 Ti Super)
+ Sandbox design is great.
+ The stylized graphics are generally good. Can be degraded by excessive default brightness levels, so check that out when starting. There is a flashlight tool available throughout the game, so don‚Äôt hesitate to make things dark and use the flashlight! When you do‚Ä¶
+ ...The atmosphere starts to click. Darkness everywhere at night, random streetlights casting pools of light in the darkness. Even during the daytime, exploring a shed or basement will need the flashlight.

+/- enemy design is decent, but there isn‚Äôt enough variety. Barely half a dozen different vampires. The rest are human cultists or hostile mercenaries.
+/- Have seen freeze-frame cutscenes before in DLC (Just Cause 3), but they‚Äôre odd in a full game. Definitely feels like a cost-cutting measure.
+/- Story is actually decent, but feels rushed and patchy, being told through freeze-frame cutscenes w/ voiceover, collectibles, and impersonal holographs. 
+/- gameplay tries to emulate DOOM. It feels quick and slick, but movement feels a like you‚Äôre on ice-skates. Mantling / climbing works fine, but feels cumbersome in the middle of a firefight.
+/- ambient music is generally good, though there are a few odd mood choices

- First area, Redfall Commons, has a single major boss, while the second area, Burial Point, has three. Like there were plans for a larger game, but the vision for the game had to be scaled down so they jammed everything into Burial Point.
- character back-story is never explained. Jacob, for instance, has some history with one of the villains, but it‚Äôs only referenced in passing. There aren‚Äôt any collectibles which expand on it, either.
- can‚Äôt return to the first area, Redfall Commons, after leaving it
- level design is still too linear. Those times where Redfall took me out of the sandbox and into a dedicated level, the level is still a very direct path from beginning to end. 
- Too easy. You take a lot of damage, so face-tanking is out, but you also deal tons of damage. If you keep your weapons on-level and are smart with the use of cover, combat will never make you sweat.
- Not scary. Redfall‚Äôs biggest mis-step. Vampires scream, swagger and laugh, but I never felt in danger.
- Not Gothic enough. There‚Äôs a presumption that vampires = swirling cloaks, evil laughter and imposing castles with intricate spires / gargoyles and (inside) luxurious red velvet everywhere. The swirling cloaks and evil laughter are in Redfall aplenty, but the modern-day setting just didn‚Äôt work for me.
- Vram-hungry. Played at 3440x1440, max settings, and vram usage was regularly over 12GB (dedicated; allocated was even higher). I suspect some of the people complaining about stutter simply didn‚Äôt have enough vram.


Redfall is worth picking up if you can get it cheap. I had some fun clearing the map of collectibles, I didn‚Äôt hate the gameplay and it has some decent atmosphere. 100%-ing the game will require co-op; good luck finding people to play with, as the online is deserted.

I was wary of this game due to the negative reviews, but it came at a good price at Fanatical and I tend to like these open world FPS games, so I thought I'd give it a shot. I honestly think your view of this game will depend on how much you paid and what you're expecting. If you paid full price and expected a AAA game, as most folks did at launch, you will definitely be disappointed. It does not feel like something on the level of a Bethesda or other AAA game. That said, I paid about $7, so my expectations were much lower Now, there's still TONS of stuff wrong with the game. It crashed a number of times during my playthrough. I also hit a glitch with a boss where I couldn't deliver the killing blow (which other people have had too) and had to completely redo the boss fight. There's in-game glitches and just lazy game development stuff too, like that you still hear the random lines from bosses *after* you've killed them, instructional prompts at nests come up *every single time*, and instructions don't actually pause the game and involve a long button press to get to go away (which resulted in me dying more than once). The "cut scenes" were often pretty lame, as well. In addition, the difficultly leveling can be WAY too. As in, I had more trouble with the first boss than I did with the final boss of the game, who I managed to kill first try without even getting close to dying. All of that said, if you are fan of games like Far Cry and willing to be lenient with its faults, I personally enjoyed it. Now, I would NOT pay $40 for it. But if you can find it for $10 or so, I think it is worth that.

To be honest, I got this game at a steep discount and I honestly think it's worth about $10 - $15. Is it game of the year? No. But is it the terrible game people make it out to be? Also no. It's really good for quick bursts of looter-shooter fun. The story is pretty okay but the game is definitely a more casual experience in a similar vein to some games in the Borderlands series. There was definitely potential in this game and setting if Arkane had been given the chance to bring this back. As it is, it's a pretty decent game while on sale.

Despite all the hate I think this game kicks ass, and people should give this game a comeback. Ok, so I have a lot of hours into this game, says steam.   Surprisingly, almost as many as I have into Vampire Survivors when I include time spent playing that on my Xbox and Switch and PS5 and PC.... :)   

Was initially excited when Redfall launched on XBox Game Pass in 2023 just because the title seemed different and I enjoy survival horror games, but quickly lost interest given how buggy it was.  2 years later I got a cheap game license for PC from one of those internet game license sites and figured, I'd try it again.  

I've played on all the difficulty levels from easiest to hardest.  However, I've only ever played as Jacob because, well, sniping.  So can't comment on any of the other characters.

The game is fun, at least I think so or I'd not have logged a zillion hours into it.  I enjoy the creepy horror aspect, which was certainly very excited on the first run-through when you don't really know what's coming next.  The story isn't bad.  It's a novel take on material that's presented countless (hah?) times in the past, but Arkane has a good backstory that isn't just the same 'ol.   So playing through the single player story line the first time was fun.

The game is not particularly hard, even on the hardest difficulty.  When you start out and you have no skills and no decent weapons, you need to proceed more carefully and slowly.  But once you have some abilities and better weapons, thing start to roll along.   I actually wish the hardest mode were harder to present more of a challenge.   

Unreal 5 engine looks great.  Town is rendered nicely.  Many of the buildings have doors or windows you can use to enter said buildings and look for lot or plot items. 

There are still some bugs.  For instance, it's possible to get stuck while crouched/creeping around.  It happens occasionally in Redfall Commons and a LOT in Burial Point, which leads me to believe the dev team spent more time polishing RC and was rushed to make their release date before BP had been as thoroughly debugged.  Normally, if you get stuck and you're not in combat you can use the map to fast travel someplace else and then go back to the area where you were stuck.   The only time I got stuck where this presented a problem was when it happened inside one of the vampire nests after I'd cleaned it out and was destroying the tethered heart connections.  In that case I had to do the nest over again.

Other stupid glitchy stuff is Jacob saying dumb things like, "Got the last one" when there are more monsters/NPCs heading your way to attack you.  Happens all the time.   That and saying, "There's a nest nearby" EVERY TIME you enter the area that a nest influences, as if you wouldn't already know this on account of the nest barrier and visual effects within.

At this point I've played through at least 5 times and probably explored 90% of the buildings and map area, though I would guess there may still be some buildings that can be entered that I haven't noticed yet.   It's disappointing that the Arkane Studio team was disbanded because it seems clear they were planning some DLC for this with at least a final vampire boss based on a missing NPC and some implied comments by other NPCs.   Besides introducing a final, harder boss, I would have liked to see more variety in the regular and special vampires including different looks/models, more abilities, different combinations of abilities, and possibly even more unique abilities for named vampires.   Once you figure out what various vampires are capable of, they're a lot easier to fight and kill, so adding some variation and surprises would add some scare factor back.

On my last two run-throughs I decided to use the flare gun exclusively.   It may not be immediately apparent, but based on how the devs created this weapon it is arguably the most versatile in the game.  The only downside is that there really isn't enough flare gun ammo around, so I cheated and enabled unlimited ammo.   Ok, and when the Rook appears I did use two other weapons that are better suited to dispatching him.  And the vampire bosses.  Yes, I suppose I could kill the Rook and the bosses with the flare gun if I had to, but it would take a long time and frankly it's not fun and not worth it)  But killing everything with the flare gun?  That's actually a hell of a lot of fun once you get the hang of it.

This game on release was a clusterfuck, now Redfall is slightly better but still ultimately a clusterfuck.
It's a shame that due to Arkane Austin closing down, we'll never see what the "real vision behind Redfall" was,
if there was one.

[h1][b]A Vampire Game That Sucks‚Ä¶ But Not in a Good Way[/b][/h1]

I went into Redfall hoping for at least a decent co-op shooter, but what I got instead was one of the most shockingly bad AAA releases in recent years. This game is an absolute disaster on almost every level, and the negative reviews are 100% deserved.

The control doesn't feel great a t all, the movement feels stiff and floaty. It just neve feels satisfying to play. 

The plot had potential, but it was executed terribly. Vampires taking over a town sounds pretty cool imo! But the way we were presented with the story is laughably bad. The story is completely forgettable, and by the time you get through the missions, you won‚Äôt care about anything that‚Äôs happening.

Another thing is, there are no proper cutscenes! Instead all we get are [b]PowerPoint slides[/b]. Seriously a really baffling choice. Instead of actual cutscenes, Redfall presents its major story moments through still images with no animation whatsoever. Imagine paying full price for a game these days, only to get something that looks like a slideshow instead of a cinematic experience. It feels lazy and completely kills any sense of immersion.

For a game released at AAA pricing, Redfall gives you the bare minimum of effort. This game simply not worth your time or money.

It's actually not that bad, however you have to be prepared to play through it on the hardest difficulty in order to experience any sort of challenge. Redfall was made during the pandemic which is really evident in the final product (You can literally pick up and sell toilet paper). The story is ok and the guns all feel nice to shoot, the open world is filled with people to rescue (which earns you points to level up a totally different skill tree) and unique weapons which I enjoyed hunting! Overall, I'd give it a 7/10

The story and characters are so ugh i literally skipped all the cutscenes. The games art style directly impedes its attempt at a serious tone. The Main character's boil down to an Indian who thinks hes funny and quirky but just annoying, the tech girl whos forgettable as she is generic, the shoehorned black woman and a guy whos already like half vampire. the weapons are basic af and nothing about it stands out its just a game that again if you like farcry can get into this. I played this to punish myself for having pre-ordered like a total dumbass. I wasn't able to refund it, so I 100%'d it to make up for my brainlessness.

Key takeaways: in some ways it reminds me of Cyberpunk at launch. You can tell that there's a good (potentially great) game hidden in there somewhere, but the game never truly realizes its potential.

Where CDPR recovered fully, Bethesda/Arcane really shit the bed. This needed *at least* 6-12 more months in the oven. Had it been given that, I really do think it could have been a solid 7-8. Even after about a year's worth of updates, I'd say Redfall hit somewhere between a 5-6 for me.

The atmosphere is pretty cool, and I can appreciate the general aesthetic, but the world still feels very empty and "same-y". There are points of interest scattered throughout the world, but none that made be think "wow, that's cool!". There are scraps of story bits strewn in, but it's mostly just weapon finds.

If that's your thing, you can find yourself in a mindless flow state fairly easily, and it could be worth a purchase (in the $20 range at least). There is a lot to explore, but ultimately nothing super rewarding for doing so. On that note, I was surprised at the amount of subquests, but they were all fairly rinse & repeat for each zone / neighborhood. I almost feel like they should have made this more like a L4D clone with fairly linear level design. There's no real purpose to having an open world for anything you do.

The story really fell flat -- at no point did it ever have its hooks in me. The AI isn't the worst, but it's a far cry from being good. Combat can feel pretty good though, and at least as Remi, I enjoyed my kit quite a bit. All of that said, you can still catch whiffs of what could have been... This could have been a very good game.

Regardless of whatever happened to cause Redfall to end up the way it did, let's just look at the end product. It's badly written, lacks a lot of the "stylistic" art/visual pedigree of Prey/Dishonored, the loot system isn't very good, the enemies are bland, the allies are bland, and the game just generally sucks. If you want a looter-shooter, there are better options. If you want a good plot, there are FAR better options. If you want a generally fun game, there are piles of options. I love vampires and I love character progression (level-ups, abilities, new weapons, etc.), so I really, truly gave this game a chance, pumping over 64 hours into it, but I couldn't even bother to finish the game, despite 100%-ing the collectibles and exploring almost every area in the game. Everything in this game is either bland or bad, and there are too many better games out there to play. Avoid this game like the plague if you want something "good." This ain't it, chief. Read the other reviews to help you make up your mind, but I assure you the game really and truly is lacking in literally every category. There is nothing this game does well. Nothing (unless you present joke answers like "It is really great at being crappy").
If you care about story or presentation at all, don't bother. The cutscenes that advance the plot barely even qualify as storytelling. It was an insulting way to cut corners

Single player as JB with power-ups, Redfall will please fans of Dishonoured/stealth gaming with its equally immersive, finely crafted world. A lean-around corners function (not provided) and double-jump (also not provided) would have added to the immersion/playability.

I avoided buying and playing this for a while because of all the terrible reviews, but I just love Arkane so much that when it was on sale I had to go for it, and I was pleasantly surprised. 

Now, up front: the game is, generously, unpolished. Some of the visuals are genuinely bad, and many other parts seem unfinished. 

That said, I enjoyed it quite a bit. The gameplay is fun (though it gets stale toward the end, especially if you do all the optional content). The characters and environmental storytelling are very charming and I enjoyed them a lot. Finished a solo playthrough as Jacob, and I loved all of his characterization. The voice acting is also top-notch.
 
Most of my complaints can be chalked up to the game feeling unfinished. There aren't a lot of NPC character models, for enemies or civilians. It feels like there should be more different types of enemies, weapons, and safehouse missions. And as I mentioned, some of the visuals (not all!) are kind of embarrassing for a released game. But none of that stopped me from enjoying the game, and I'd like to play it again to try a different character. 

Basically: buy it on sale, on heavy sale if you can, but if you can get past the visual clumsiness in places I think you'll have a fine time.

I'll be reviewing the game as a 7$ game instead of a 70$ dollar one because you can find Redfall in a bundle on Fanatical for around that price.

The technical state:
After the patches the game is in what I call a good enough state where you can have fun and are able to ignore all the glaring issues.
The game plays really well, though disable Framegen if you are experiencing issues, not only will fix this the horrible input latency but it will also fix the crashes (at least for me).
It runs smooth without frame generation though keep in mind I got a 5700X3D and a 4080 Super.

The positives:
+ Gameplay wise Redfall is a ton of fun, it looked fun back when it got released though the all the issues it had for 70$ is daylight robbery so I gave it a hard pass like everyone else.
+ The game has a meme status for the crap AI, the hilariously easy difficulty and bugs galore. This has now been largely addressed to the point where it can actually be quite challenging on the highest available difficulty, especially at the start. The vampires are quick, unpredictable and have AI similar now to that of Bethesda games, so not great but not bad either.
+ The gunplay is a ton of fun and pretty smooth! The movement is a little bit jank and could've used some more dev time. Still I prefer the gameplay of Redfall over something like Borderlands 3 or Dying Light 2, it's a perfect game to mess around in and have fun.
+ The world of Redfall (the first map) is really quite nice to explore, lots of unique looking places to look through and it can seriously look pretty dang good at times.
+ The loot is a little like that of Borderlands 1, simple, little variation between guns but still fun to loot.

The big negatives:
- The second map sucks, boring generic looking environments, few unique looking locations and just not as fun to explore. This was clearly developed to extend the playtime of the game because it feels so half-assed.
- Sometimes the AI still craps out, especially if you run around cover they can easily be cheesed.
- The story, dialogue sequences and characters are terrible. No depth, simple as can be and all consist of fetch-type quests. Even the main quests offer the same amount of depth, if you're after a story to care about look elsewhere.
- Short playtime considering the price on release.
- Simple and unoriginal mechanics, everything Redfall does has been done before.
- You can still tell that the game has been slapped together to be in a state that it can be sold in, the studio clearly had no idea even near the end what the game was going to be.

Look, the game is enjoyable but not worth more than 10$, I'm someone that can enjoy games that could be considered as a guilty pleasure like We Happy Few and Fable 3, if you're like me and the gameplay looks fun you'll have a good time.
For 70$ hell no, for 7$? Sure why not.

Playing on steam deck in offline mode. Seems like a great mobile game, runs at 60 fps with some tweaking and still looks really nice. I'm a big fan of Arkane Austin so I love the setting and premise. The story is meh, but great for playing on the train or while listening to a podcast.
A year and a half after its release it's patched and it's worth it.

The environments were nice, you get two maps and an interlude in between, I just wish the props were destructible.

For combat, the vampires can get in your face, but the human ai is dumb as nails. They'll run backwards and spend more time staring at your feet than pumping lead into your chest. Also included are explosive cars and electrical boxes, great for collateral damage. Maybe it was just the difficulty but I really didn't feel any danger. I don't think I got any cool loot either, just the occasional upgrade that carried me to the end.

It's made for co-op but idk why they'd lock achievements to just the host. I got to about the halfway point with a friend when we realized this and had to restart solo. Accessibility settings include infinite ammo and I really didn't feel bad putting that on. Also, there's no in-game save system and there are branching decisions. Feel free to manually scum your documents folder. You'll need to max trust all 4 characters, which takes about 4 hours total, just sprinting through main missions with 3 and then another go with 1 more. 

I didn't have any technical issues playing solo on high, but when I played with others my frames would drop to single digits, especially in combat, then return to normal.  

The story was ok? The cutscenes were just slowly moving stills with your character narrating. Pretty underwhelming. 

You shouldn't feel bad avoiding this, though there's something about dumpster diving and playing things other people avoid. Meeting all the challenge conditions was pretty fun to be fair. Maybe it's meeting friends that also play your games that makes it worth it.

I enjoyed this game but I did find the gameplay overall to be too easy.  If Deathloop was way too hard, they over adjusted on this one.  I played the entire solo campaign.  The final boss was a joke, more of a puzzle really.   The cultist AI was pretty bad and you could snipe 3 or 4 of them and clean up the ones that rushed you with a shotgun.  

Anyway, this games problem is that it's mostly mediocre.  I got it as part of the Humble Choice so I didn't feel ripped off at all for what I paid.  Had I paid $70 for it I'd be angry.

I had it crash twice on the steam deck I think and ran into one glitch where I got stuck in a bridge.  A lot more stable than others would suggest.

The game is far too repetitive. I don't like the weapon system. It doesn't make sense that the same gun can out perform another because of its level. I don't think I got far enough in the story to examine the writing, but so far I am unimpressed.

Honestly? While the game has its problems and is certainly lackluster in a few regards, it nonetheless is a good time. Very detailed and intricate map like you'd expect from an Arkane game, satisfying movement and shootin, and a few nice surprises throughout the campaign. Not a must-play (like everything else Arkane has put out), but if you can get it on sale and also like vampires, you could do a lot worse!

How have you not implemented an ADS sensitivity option yet? I also can't connect online so can only play offline solo, although I haven't bothered to try anything with that the ADS thing is just too frustrating to deal with.

Really, really enjoying this.
A shooter that have dying light influences without its sense of oppression.

I got this game back when it was bundled with the 40 series RTX cards and wanted to wait to play this game after some updates since I saw loads of bad reviews. It seems those updates did not help with game stability too much since this game has crashed for me 4 times with the 2.6 hours that I have played.

From here on, this will just be a review of what I have been able to play (only through the first main mission). If the game doesn't crash for you at all, or as often, the game itself is fun to play. There are skill trees for each of the four playable characters that seem like skill trees; you level up to get upgrades for your abilities. The combat is smooth as well, the only downside being the enemies tend to give up really quickly when they loose sight of you. I haven't played nearly enough of the main campaign to give an opinion on the plot or dialogue, but from what I was able play through, it was okay.
Having now beat the game I can say it definitely has its faults but for me as someone whole was looking for something Far Cryish with vampires it fit that hole. Worth $20 on sale but not full price.

As we have just binary thumbs up/down on Steam for reviews, my decision is based upon whether if I was given a time machine to go back to before I played the game, knowing what I know about it, would I bother to play it again?

Redfall: NO.

It starts off quite fun, vampires are pretty tough (on hardest difficulty, solo) and exploration seems interesting. You establish a base with other survivors who setup shops and have side missions for you. Quickly though you realise the thin-ness of everything. The other survivors talk rubbish, they barely acknowledge you (even though you're saving the world while they sit on their butts), the shops sell junk, the doctor only sells medkits (there's only 1 kind too) and there's only a handful of missions. The survivors missions (I recall like 3?) were just fetch quests. You'll find very little in the world except pointless notes and some items that boost your ultimate meter base level.

Soon you get overwhelmed with the amount of loot, too. So, much, loot. Levelling up feels pretty linear so even in late game you level up quite a lot and those legendary guns you got soon get overpowered by rare or lower quality guns of higher levels. I maxed out both skill trees around the same time I got to the end of the game... or what I thought was the end. But no, another whole new map opened up, this time with 2 "bosses" in but otherwise you're doing EXACTLY the same stuff. There's literally no new gameplay elements, no new progression, just more of the same. If they cut the game in half it would've been better for it.

Dumb stuff the game does:

- Puts batteries everywhere. *Everywhere*. Even on top of cars, which seems redundant. When shot they shoot out electricity that does massive damage to everything
- Puts petrol under every car, which does massive damage to everything
- Pointlessly spawns a "boss" in when you kill too many vamps which shoots lightning from the sky (Did I mention all the batteries and petrol everywhere that do massive damage?)
- Lets some enemy attacks interrupt you when you're in the canned animation for your special "ultimate" attack
- Gives enemies massively annoying abilities like siphoning off your health from a huge distance or dragging you towards them
- Makes you HOLD DOWN the key to use a medkit (which takes ages to apply and does very little)
- Lets vamps immediately spawn behind you 1 second after they see you or you attack them from a mile away
- Moves you to the 2nd map and doesn't let you go back to the first (Stops you getting all the collectibles and you probably won't feel like spending hours getting them all in the "middle" of the game)
- Doesn't give you a "dodge" button which is one of my pet peeves in an fps, especially when most enemies just run at you and melee

My favourite "FU" moment? Spawning out of a safehouse, one of the defensive turrets tried to shoot an enemy and instead shot a car that was parked right in front of it. Did I mention the petrol? Instadeath for me before I could blink. "Yay".

Other technical stuff:

- Games runs at high fps but still has lots of traversal stutter (Unreal Engine)
- Cartoony Fortnite style graphics don't match the dark tone
- Forgets your gfx settings so you need to re-apply them every single time you load the game (How is that still an issue after all this time?)
- Crashes quite a lot

Wrap it up:

Game looked like it was on a good trajectory at one point but then they either ran out of time, ideas or money. What's left is "ok" but it cost me about a tenner - I wouldn't pay much more for it. Play it while you watch TV or something if you're desperate for some open-world vamp killing action.

Buffy the Vampire slayer RPG meets Destiny meets Far Cry Dungeon Crawler action first person shooter. What's not to love? The fact it's nearly complete due to Microsoft putting profits before art and especially fucking over studios akin to EA aquiring and eating studios alive. RIP Visceral Studios and Dead Space 1-2. How much more Anti-consumer can you get? 

Fuck Microsoft for shutting down a great game studio in Austin. This game IS fun in offline singleplayer mode and if you can manage to get it to work the online mode is still functioning and is crossplay. It's made for single player solo campagin offline mode AND coop.
It's just plain fun, and not a steep learning curve like many games.

This was a rough one.. I had such high expectations after playing Prey/Mooncrash. Unfortunately, the magic ain't here. Still fantastic art and world design, but buggy environment (getting stuck in trees and tree roots). Had couple crashes - not too bad.

Finally played the game after purchasing at a discount.  I read all of the reviews and agree with many.  The AI needs some serious improvement along with other facets of the game.  

I found the game to have decent story but lacking in a lot of other areas.  Good map and typical characters for Arcane games.  However, it becomes tiresome to battle the same characters over and over.  No real development in the progression of the game.  You would think that when you move to another map you would also uncover another level of play and characters.....nope.  In the end, not worth a premium price tag...more so a mid-level gaming experience.  Just my take!

Its certainly not as bad as the reviews would tell you. its got some issues but overall a interesting story, fun exploration, and decent gunplay.  There is also a Coop bug about halfway through the game that will never be fixed.  Single player has run fine. One crash in 35ish hours.  6/10

I bought this on sale for 20 bucks, and honestly, I absolutely love it. I don't know what it was like before the updates, but I genuinely don't understand the hatred over this. I went into this expecting it to be awful based on reviews and youtubers saying this was genuinely purely bad, and I just don't see it based on experience. 

I've only been focusing on the solo campaign. I'm playing on the highest difficulty, and I gotta say it's challenging. The gun play mechanics are super fun and great to play around with. The map is gorgeous, as someone who once lived in Massachusetts they captured the spirit and aesthetic of it perfectly. I enjoy how you can only focus on one mission at a time versus having endless missions you have to keep jumping back and forth with. 

The writing is quirky, not the best, but enjoyable. I really like the quiche of having a vampire ex-boyfriend you can summon occasionally to fight your battles. Very reminiscent of Lollipop Chainsaw Massacre. Art style is beautiful. 

I have zero complaints, and I've been playing a great deal.

Let me be clear, I only don't recommend this game for groups.
As far as I can tell Solo play works well enough. But late game saves tend to break and stop groups from even loading it. And since progress is based on the host, you either have to start at someone elses save or start over entirely.

The game is actually decent.  I've only played a little bit though.  Plan on playing more.

Its Bethesda's version of Far Cry and Generation Zero with Dishonored artwork.  Has generic FPS looter/shooter formula, but it works.  I have gotten a couple crashes, but nothing gamebreaking.  Combat is somewhat fluid, story is generic.

I do wish we still got the DLC's :(

EDIT:
I'm a big S.T.A.L.K.E.R. fan and love Ghost Recon Wildlands above most games, but this one can be played solo exactely how you want it; stealth, gunner, both. I really had some insane situations happening to me, from stupid death after having barely survived and close to my goal, having to run for my life after a situation escalated with some vampires in an abandoned railroad track surrounded by kinda cliffs, so no way around but trapped on a straight line, finally escaping this too much closed area, fleeing through the bushes to cross a main road, attracting various factions to the dance, and survived with a lot of sweat.

In higher difficulties, enemies track you way way longer, that's really a manhunt sometimes; I've just (10 mins ago) been followed from a main road to a dried sea zone pretty far away, and as I felt safe down there by the rocks but decided to lounge them, and I did well because a lot of guys did follow me to the edge of the rocks, but didn't penetrate the dried sea, as 3 vampires were already killing some cultist there.

The thing also is that night is way more dangerous than "day" because vampires activity is way higher, almost no sleeping ones or hiding by the environment shadows, they can roam more freely, and altogether with packs of allies (cultists).
So moving at night feels a lot different than by daylight, also a really interesting contrast and change in gameplay. There's actually a lot of subtilities to discover, things have been thought pretty deeply.

What is cool is that there are some interactions within the world between vampires, cultits and another corporation, so when you move forward in the game, the world actually feels more alive as they fight each others, lots of random events...

I started on Dawn difficulty and moved to nightmare just to get feelings back from the very beginning, when you're poorly armed and every single threat is dangerous, and believe me, a lot can happen and it can turn surprising pretty quick.

There's also a lot of verticality, you can access almost all rooftops, there's pretty much always a way to climb up to take advantage of being above things, even if you play Jacob, who can't "teleport" himself or throw himself in the air like Devinder .

Not as bad as everyone makes it. The art and the environment is super good, if you ever wanted to visit a small town with vampires, it's a great place to see. Sure the game is half-baked, but for me personally it's 7/10

This game didn't get a fair shake. Yes buy it on sale. The AI can be a little stupid, the stealth a little janky and the hit boxes still need work. It wasn't terrible.
