Waiting for a bite back patch

Update after finishing Game :

Please consider that after starting the 4th Journey on Elden Ring with the Shadow of the Erdtree DLC with 1133 hours later , plus another 73 hours on Steel Rising on Epic Games , this is my first Non Souls type / and normal game ( to say the truth it is also refreshing ) so my Review can be biased on how difficult the game is ......

Story/Narrative is Awesome , and voice casting is very good 

Main story Narrative progression is sequential.. By the way on story progression there is no animation , its a 3D comic/anime book style visuals ,with voice acting 
 
If you are going to ask why vampires still appear during daylight etc , don't do it , the important thing is that the game is entertaining

Bosses are NOT that hard - BUT I did NOT try the Eclipse Game Play mode - which is the Hardest ..( there are 4 Main Story Bosses ) , then the Elder Nests Bosses , and some special vampires roaming in particular areas.

To be Honest I played it with unlimited store of ammo ( option when you start game ) , but in reality there was no need as there are a good amount of pick up points in game and even when killing cultists/operators  they drop.

This Game has a lot of looting but no crafting , character upgrades like Vampire God Remnant are earned during story progression and Blood Remnant upgrades are earned with killing particular vampires or by completing  vampires Nests and the Elder Nests in time after destroying main nest hearth,later in game these  can be found also by looting letter boxes ( after buying option in safe house upgrades )  , weapons are found during looting and can even buy these

There is also character progression with usual XP points on killing foes and even from safe houses a different type of upgrade for various items from better looting , reducing damage from 'Rook' lightning by 50% etc etc etc, helping residents and doing safe houses 'side quests' will unlock these , there are an amount of these upgrades to keep you busy

Game is basically a shoot'em'up , it's not so challenging but at the end it is a stress free entertainment , its ideal to cool down after a day at school / work

I'll start by saying that I liked this game. The few updates made it better than what it was when it came out. Is it as good as previous Arkane studio's Games? No. Is it still fun to play? Yes.

You can still feel Arkane's soul in it, the graphics, abilities, weapon. I'd say it matches more Deathloop than Dishonored or Prey.

I played using Devinder as teh Translocate ability felt a bit like the Blink ability is Dishonored.
I really liked the story, it start slow with just a city overrun by vampires, but as you complete the missions and advance through the story you get more infos about what the doctors did and how it came to being vampires.

The difficulty scale is weird, at the easiest setting pretty nothing can touch you, move up 1 notch and the vampires can 1-3 shot you already.

Looking at weapons, you had a wide variety of them, you can't modify the unrivaled tier weapon with the stakes you find which is a bummer. You can't upgrade your weapon, you just have to hope you'll find another one when a few level higher. I played with pretty much just the Painkiller, Basilisk, Cass Special and the Perfectly Normal.

I experience some low 1% FPS a few times but nothing serious. The game crashed about 5 times. The first 4 times was because of the frame generation so I deactivated it and was fine after that.At the beginning I had trouble getting into the game as the server loading screen appeared at the same time as the terms and condition screen, just had to smash the space bar to bypass it.

It pains me to see this as the end of Arkane Studio. They made some of my favorite games and it's a shame we won't get another Dishonored/Prey/Deathloop kinda game.

Would still recommend Redfall but not at full price, this feels like it should be a 15-20$ game

i don't know if everyone is a bitch or uif the game changed that much with the updates but this is exactly the type of vampire game i always wanted. reminds me of militarized buffy the vampire slayer and that makes me extremely happy.

I bought this game together with Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League and I played this game first with the pre-conception that this game was going to be terrible. Not just terrible, but terribad. I loaded into the game with two other friends and after the tutorial, we were plopped into the open world and started to immediately have fun in the game. There was laughing, cry-laughing, gasps of astonishment, excitement over friendly fire (literally) and 15 hours later, we are still having fun just exploring, shooting, cleansing and traversing.

Then I played Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League for two hours, and refunded that game.

TL;DR: Redfall is better than Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League.

Having read on Twixxer that Harvey Smith considered patch 4 the finished version of the game and he was pleased that people were now enjoying it, I thiought I'd give Redfall a try. I love Dishonored with a passion, though I wish I liked the sequels; enjoy Deathloop; am more impressed by Prey than enjoying of it; and still have great fondness for Arx Fatalis and Dark Messiah Of Might And Magic. So I'm generally skewed toward favourable approaches to Arkane games.

Redfall got a legendary beating at release, and I can only imagine what it must have been like. At present after patch 4, it feels like a compromise of a game: solo play is cluttered with the kind of HUD icon spew that contaminates quite a few co-op games.

Enemy AI is really very poor - I generally play stealth but it's barely a viable option here as the NPC enemies spot you easily and their detection progress from 'huh?' to dogpiling you is *fast*. Mostly it's human enemies, being either vampire cultists or mercenaries, so you're going to get shot at most of the time. Vampires zip around and slash at you with their claws, and there's a fun twist on the old narrative where after wearing them down with bullets they can be seen off using a thrust from a shotgun or assault rifle with a wooden stake mounted in place of a bayonet.

The premise of the game is great - small town cut off from the world and being taken over by vampires, so far so 30 Days Of Night -  but there's no tension or horror here of the kind that make Dying Light so unnerving: if you're expecting a late-stage Salem's Lot/ I Am Legend (book not cr*ppy Will Smith movie) experience, you're going to be disappointed. The map itself has so much potential for that kind of slow-burning exploration, tense race against sundown gameplay: but it's basically Far Cry Vampires Edition,  just a lot of run-and-gun, health regen spamming, but with looter-shooter weapon drops (be ready to compare stats! Blue gun better than green gun! ugh). 

Absurdly for a vampire story, the day/night cycle seems to make no difference at all - vampires are out during the day (there is a black cast over the sun which one assumes is protecting them but the game doesn't tell you this) so the prospect of nightfall has no menace beyond worse visibility, and your flashlight is extremely powerful so that's hardly an issue.

I'll play to finish the game now it's in my library, but it's really not a good epitaph for Arkane Austin. It reeks of publisher interference, forced design decisions to try to chase trends which had already moved on, and a schizoid tone which fails to be either endearing or horrifying. Probably a good thing that my expectations were already low.

EDIT AFTER CAMPAIGN COMPLETION: Oh dear. Oh *dear*. Ending on a cliffhanger for DLC/sequel that are never going to be made was a bit of a boo-boo now wasn't it? Also my character's references to having encountered one of the vampire bosses and gaining his vampire eye (which grants exactly no powers) were never explained during my playthrough (though they are in a trailer, whut?) and I dread to think how incoherently the other characters backstories will be presented. Oh and several times I came across textures that looked like they'd been made with an AI art generator - gibberish glyph text on a poster, generic memorial plaque in a museum to name two - which contributes to the impression that this was a project doomed by pushy publishers demanding a team create a project of the kind they're not best at to meet a demand nobody in the gaming space made. Also why are characters' hands so damn enormous?? There's stylised art design and then there's the inverse-Rob Liefeld NPC models of Redfall. Wasted potential is probably the greatest artistic crime, and Redfall's maps (minus the clutter) could have been the setting for something atmospheric and memorable. Instead we got this unlovable turkey which frankly I can't recommend to anyone, and we haven't even got to some of the Joss Whedon-esque 'quips' that keep getting dropped. You know what? I'm going to reinstall Dying Light and scrub the stillborn Redfall from my memory. Verdict: avoid.

I like Arkane games and I actually enjoyed the game...until it started non-stop crashing. After about 8hrs of no problems in two days, it started crashing with UE4 errors and within an hour I lost count of times it crashed.

I tried disabling steam overlay, and every third-party tool in system tray, verified game files, I know I have the latest nVidia 4090 drivers, 24GB VRAM etc. Basically no apparent reason for it to crash but it kept going and took the joy out of the game.
 
When the game crashes, you lose not only time, but also progress and loot. For example, I cleared a vampire nest, got out and got the rewards a min later game crashed and all were lost. Nest did not show up in the map either.

Update: I really wanted to finish the game but it is still crashing. I considered uninstall / reinstall, which had helped a bit with recent Star Wars. 
I reset all settings in case I may have changed something that was causing this (for example, I had increased FoV a bit). I actually thought it got better, but was probably placebo, it still crashes randomly, sometimes fine for 2-3hrs, other times crashes 5mins apart. Still no clue what the UE4 error is about, nothing on google. 

OK, will stop talking about crashes, although it is hard to ignore it. 

Gunplay .. OK, though I don't like the choices much.  Aim down-side is not great, view blocked most of the time, especially with pistols (yet how I loved healing from "Painkiller"). Each level almost obsoletes the previous lvl guns, so constantly trying to get back favs. A few combos are  sometimes OP (UV + saw).

Loot ... kinda annoying that in the second half I got greens and blues from most, rook was the only guaranteed way to get legendary.

Story / Quests .. OK

Gameplay in general ... Fine, I would rate this 3.5/5 if it was not crashing.

Fun game.

I can sum up this review in two words - wasted potential. If you can, snipe this game for cheap. $20 at the most. Grab a friend too.

Game has its moments and its appeal. I really wish they had more time to cook but unfortunately, the game was bogged down with a poor launch that kept folks away. They tried to address the issues in a timely manner but bug fixes and upgrades were not coming fast enough.

Gunplay feels arcade-y but not goofy. It doesn't come off like Call of Duty or Battlefield either. With only three weapon slots means you are forced to go into your inventory a lot and swap out weapons. I found myself keeping the UV weapon in slot three equipped at all times because it was just too valuable to unequip, meaning I was constantly swapping out the first two weapon slots to whatever was needed for the situation. My one gripe early on was you hold so little ammunition and feel forced to invest in the ammo perks early on if you don't want to swap guns all the time.

Movement is basic, not including abilities or perks. With more perks and abilities, movement allows you to get into some interesting places rather quickly, bypassing (sometimes locked) doors or repositioning yourself into a higher area for an advantage.

Voices are good but your character just WILL NOT SHUT UP. After every fight they comment and it will most likely force people to disable voices. I found myself forced to disable voices to continue playing and retaining my sanity.

Exploring and scavenging felt natural and not forced. I did not feel compelled to go out of my way to farm or focus on something in particular, outside of collectibles.  My one gripe is lockpicks and hacking tools were limited you being able to carry three at a time. There are certain perks that reduce the chance to use one but still, only three being the cap? Jacob has a perk that increases his lockpick count to 8 and there are, usually, ways around locked doors such as windows in certain places, etc. Lockpicks only work on doors, safes and certain chests. If you're a loot goblin like me, you are compelled to open all the things.

Menus were straight to the point. The information you need is categorized in a way that's easy to find and navigate with minimal fluff, with text that's easy to read. You will also be spending a lot of time in the inventory screen swapping out weapons so get comfortable with that. I also enjoyed the red text format. 

Quests are pretty standard but a few twists here and there kept me wary of approaching certain quests the way you normally would. "Go here, find X" but X turns out to be a trap. Don't trust things you hear over the radio or TVs.

Characters have their own identity and skillset, meaning playing with friends as different characters comes off as necessary, sorta. Each compliment one another but you can still solo without anyone. Skill trees are expanded through skill points, acquired from leveling up, killing mini-bosses, doing certain quests, etc. My first several bunch of points went straight into increasing my ammo count because I was tired of having to swap weapons so often.

Enemies ranging from standard melee vampires to humans with guns. The AI for the standard vampire comes off as jank because they seem to have no real sense of self-preservation while saying they'll eviscerate you. They also run at you in some strange angles and weird ways that the animation looks goofy while looking at you with a >:( face. There's a few other types of special vampires as well as unique variants of humans such as humans that summon help or build turrets to attack you. I won't spoil the vampire variants but I do recommend you aim for the head. 

Also as a side note - If you are using an RTX card, do not enable DLSS. Your game will crash a lot. A shame the game will most likely never get patched to improve it.

Overall, the game is just okay. It's very unfortunate the game will not receive anymore updates. If this game had more time to cook and had a better launch, I daresay this game could've been pretty damn good. Maybe not GOTY material, but still enjoyable all the same.

My review of [i]Redfall[/i] is in response to the latest and final update the game received (May 2024), as someone who has played it on launch. 

I will say upfront at launch it was a mess. I thankfully played it on Gamepass and finished it through till its end. Glitches, bugs, dumb AI and all. I liked the premise of the game and the world building despite its problems. I can certainly understand the backlash, especially from those who paid full price for this game or beyond the standard base game. 

[i]I do recommend this game in its state now but at a heavily reduced price.[/i] I paid $20 for this game and deem it worth that much for the hours I got out of it. Also I have not experienced co-op mode, my review is from playing single player only. 

[h3]The Story[/h3]

The town of Redfall has been besieged by darkness and vampires. You explore the origins of the vampire threat as one of four main characters, all with unique traits and abilities. The story itself is a strength in this game, sadly hindered by the short-comings of the game mechanics. 

[h3]Gameplay & Features[/h3]

I am writing this review from the standpoint that you know what an open world fps game is and hopefully this is not your first experience with one‚Ä¶that would [i]bite[/i].

The different characters with their own abilities are fun. The first time I played through with Devinder and this run I played as Layla. I like her ability of the lift. It gets you up to hard to reach high places fast. The weapons themselves feel okay. I like the addition of staking the vampires after weakening them. But overall the game still has a lot of dumb AI. The enemies are more responsive than before but not enough. I found I enjoyed more of my time looking for collectables and focusing on the story. 

I really like the addition of the Community Standing chart where you can spend points after opening up the safehouses by completing safehouse quests and  freeing captives. They added a lot of great stuff that can be eventually unlocked through this system. Being able to find the Grave Locks and cosmetics revealed on the map was a huge time saver in my second run. 

Also I never experienced any crashes or stutters in my full play time with the game on Steam so despite in-game issues with some dumb AI or pop-ins from time to time the game overall ran pretty smoothly. Also you can remap keys (I recommend a programmable mouse if you have one). 

[h3]Two points in the game to beware of‚Ä¶[/h3]

Once you leave the first map (Redfall Commons) to travel to map 2 (Burial Point) you cannot go back to the first map so finish all objectives on the first map before heading into the second one! 

Once you finish off the main boss (the Black Sun) the game will restart you in Redfall Commons in a new game+. You keep your character progression but all collectables respawn and once again you're locked within only Redfall Commons. 

[i]I can understand not being able to continue on after the final boss but I do wish that in the final update they could have allowed us to travel back and forth between maps to finish achievements.[/i] 

[h3]The Visuals[/h3]

The greatest strength this game has is world building. The game world is incredibly detailed. I enjoy looking in the houses and buildings, jumping around the rooftops and finding secret rooms and easter eggs. I love games where a lot of the time you can actually go into the buildings and explore. 

For starters I love the game's concept and key art you can find online. In game I am not a fan. The characters look lifeless and ridgid. A lot of the time just repeating the same actions or sayings over and over. The cut-scenes were well done and reflect what your character is wearing in game at the time. More scene captures as opposed to animated cutscenes. 

[h3]Overall Experience[/h3]

I love Arkane games with Dishonored being one of my all time favorites and really enjoying my time with Prey. This will never be the game it could have been but I am happy to see offline support make its way to the game before the servers are gone.

I really enjoyed the narrative of this game and the world itself. The story of Redfall is complete for the most part at the end of the game with some parts of the story left open ended. Sadly anything going forward is pretty much limited to our imaginations.  ‚ö∞Ô∏è

Overall Summary:
Redfall has received overwhelmingly negative feedback due to its high price tag, poor performance, lackluster gameplay, and numerous bugs. Many users feel the game is unfinished and not worth its $70 price, comparing it unfavorably to other AAA titles.

Key Issues Highlighted:
Price: Many reviewers are outraged by the $70 price, feeling it‚Äôs too high for an indie-quality game in early access.
Performance: The game suffers from severe performance issues, including low frame rates and poor optimization even on high-end hardware.
Gameplay: The AI is considered weak, controls are clunky, and the open world is described as empty and boring.
Graphics: Described as average and not meeting the expectations for a AAA title.
Story: The narrative is shallow, and the world lacks meaningful interaction or environmental storytelling.
Refunds: Many users have refunded the game, and even those who received it for free feel it wasn‚Äôt worth the cost.

Game should have been 40$ from the start, I feel like it would have had more success. After the last couple patches the game was pretty fun.

This game is no longer receiving updates.

This game was 12 years too late...and I'm here for it. The gameplay reminds me of older shooters like the original RAGE, Aliens: CM, Borderlands 2, etc. Let me be clear; this game is an AA title, and shame on Xbox for marketing it otherwise. 

Overall, I enjoy the atmosphere and the way combat feels. The moment to moment gameplay is simple and entertaining. Redfall's gunplay feels just like Deathloop and can get intense. Also, the sound design is decent, the weapons sound nice, and the music is very unique. 

I've played this on the Steam Deck (which is why my hours are so low) as well as the Legion Go (the Xbox PC version where I have 20+ hours clocked) and I have to say that the game performs very well. It's probably one of the best performing games in my library (both on the Steam Deck and Xbox PC).

If you're into older FPS titles from the PS3/Xbox 360 era, then chances are you'll probably enjoy Redfall. The story is intriguing enough to pay attention to and the ""cutscenes"" are literal slideshows, but what really makes Redfall enjoyable for me is the actual gameplay (as simple as it is) and the feel of combat. Swapping weapons depending on the enemy type and dwindling a vampire's health to eventually stake them in the heart never gets old.

I was a day 1 player of this game because I got it for free with a graphics card. I'm a huge Arkane fan so I was actually really excited for it. It has its issues, and it's far from being Arkane at their best, but it has a great atmosphere and had a ton of potential. The vampire hunter aspect is pretty cool too, with UV lights and wooden stakes as weapons.

Obviously there's a decent amount of issues. The game is buggy, lacks variety in a lot of ways, doesn't have the same tier of level design as other Arkane games, has a pretty annoying loot system, and the emergent gameplay is pretty bland. It kind of ends up being a pretty straightforward open zone shooter with some sandbox elements. I was excited for the new heroes and updates, and was holding off until some content before giving the game another shot, but lo and behold the news of Austin being shut down came out and crushed any hope of that.

I never felt to burned by the game because I did get it for free, and on one of it's $17 sales it is really a lot of fun for a bit. There's a final offline update coming out with a bit more content, and I hope they open it up to modding after that so the community can attempt to continue the game. This game has one of my favorite original worlds that Arkane has come up with, and I'm pretty sad they never got the chance to really allow that to happen.

So I pretty much am giving this game a good review because I think it gets a bad rep, and to let Arkane know that this game DID have its fans and those of us who wanted the game to improve. I enjoyed my time in the spooky town of Redfall.

Thank you Arkane for doing your best with Zenimax's tonedef demand for a live service game. Redfall has a really unique world, and I hope some game in the future takes notes and tries to do a vampire/paranormal hunter immersive sim again someday.

Game with huge potential, and it's kinda scary to see how its unique gameplay remains unseen and unexplored. Despite glitches, the world feels like an Arkane game, and the visuals are amazing. It has its issues, clearly attributable to rushed development and publishers pushing the game out before key parts were finished, but that doesnt diminish the game enough to make me hate it. As always, playing with a friend helps!

I'll straight up say pass on this one. Gameplay is admittedly decent, a looter shooter the likes of Borderlands with a Vampire coat of paint. Gun play feels solid, and the idea of open world vampire hunting and shooting up cultists is fine enough, but thats mostly where any positives stop. Enemies even on their harder difficulties are laughable. Sure, it was even easier back when it first came out, but even post patch its a breeze. Enemy path finding makes me feel like this was pure after thought, with even now certain enemies just unable to figure out player position and elevation correctly. Dispatching vampires can be awkward, as you need a stake to finish the job or UV light (barring specific hero abilities or some super unique weapon). This alone shouldn't be an issue except for the fact that only certain types of weapons have a stake attachment and specific tech weapons using UV light. Without any hand held stake to melee finish a vampire, you're rather limited or forced to use certain classes of weapons for vampire killing (once again, barring certain hero abilities that can bypass that which will vary from person to person). Story was... mostly forgettable. Very few points while playing did the game have my attention in terms of dialogue, and the cut scenes are just freeze frames of 3d models despite the game itself having animation during game play. Its such a bizarre choice that only further paints this game as a half baked product. For online Co-op, the game balance gets even more thrown out the window as if enemies just weren't properly scaled to take on 2 or more players. When the party is intentionally trying to draw the attention of The Rook (an allegedly punishing opponent for drawing too much attention from the head vampire) to just trash him like hes a side quest boss, something is really off. This game isn't even an indie game, this is suppose to be a AAA experience. This came out the door with a 70 fucking dollar price tag; and that's the "basic" version not including season pass crap that would demand you a total of about 100 dollars for the full experience. Its beyond shameful, because the ones who pushed this out the door clearly had no shame to hold them back. Now with the developer team effectively terminated, don't expect much more fixing beyond this point. Is it worth playing? At a discount at best, fun was had by myself because I wasn't soloing and got this game on a significant discount. With no further updates in the works, and season pass content cancelled, I don't expect a very active player base to remain playing this if there even is anyone still online. This game is by no means worth the full price.

[h1][i]Bordlerlands[/i] with vampires[/h1]

TLDR, this is basically [i]Borderlands[/i] but with vampires rather than sci fi. I play with not-Gaige who summons a friendly vampire rather than a robot like OG Gaige. 

[h1]If it were sold for $20, it would be a decent buy.[/h1]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3252498949

[b]UPDATE:[/b] Microsoft is apparently planning to release the final patch after all. 

https://x.com/playRedfall/status/1791491460858020040

If this were a $20 indie game, it would be considered a decent AA game with an interesting premise. However, rather than sell it for what it was worth, Microsoft decided to push it out before it was ready (Bethesda style) and then sell it for $70 + Season Pass.

Right now it's in a bundle on Fanatical which means you can get it and another game for $25 which is worth it in my opinion

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

It's an FPS with stealth and way too many guns. If you can imagine Borderlands with more stealth and tougher enemies (the Vampires at least are tougher than the enemies in Borderlands) it's basically that.

One significant minus is that the ammo is expensive and seems hard to find. More ammo, cheaper ammo, or simply ammo that automatically refills between missions would have made this game better. 

[h1]Setting[/h1]

If you liked [i]Evil West[/i] you will probably like the setting of this game. 

This has a gothic, vampire themed setting which I quite like. In particular, I like that you are fighting the vampires rather than being one. It's enjoyably cheesy in a way which more or less matches the tone of [i]The Secret World[/i] but with an emphasis on vampires rather than conspiracy theories. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3246518759

If you are fan of [i]Welcome to Nightvale[/i] or Neil Gaiman books like [i]Coraline,[/i] you will probably like it OK. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S6kPXH9HJvE

One thing I disliked is that the setting goes too far in my opinion insofar as things have gotten so out of hand that everyone you meet besides your crew is either a Vampire, a cultist working for the vampires, or a literal prisoner waiting to be rescued. It would have been better to use the enemies more sparingly in my opinion to have an atmosphere that would be more mysterious and unsettling as opposed to post-apocalyptic.

[h1]Story[/h1]

Very basic and told via voice-overs, lore items and images rather like the extended cut of the [i]Mass Effect 3[/i] ending. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

I really hope that they follow through with their recent announcement to make this playable offline. It's nice to have a gothic, vampire-infested town to sneak around in.

[h1] Those darn vampires and their darned climate change! [/h1]

[b] Redfall [/b] is a game developed by Arkane Austin, developers of Prey, but you would absolutely not be able to tell without the splash screen on boot up. Ignoring how this game is a massive downgrade from Prey, it is fundamentally different. However, the game itself admittedly isn't what drove me to write this review, hell if things went differently I might have been willing to give it a POSITIVE one. It's more so...recent events surrounding the developer and the games future.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]
[b] Redfall [/b] is a looter-hero-shooter, I'll say it right fucking here, this game plays nothing like an Arkane game. Through the open world of Redfall (which is split into two maps depending on story progression), you kill vampires and their cultists, get weapons of varying rarity and stats, level up and use skills....yeah there's no magic in the traditional Arkane sense; there are four characters (would have been six but MORE ON THAT LATER), known as Heroes, and each of them have their own skills, with two cooldowns and one ultimate that needs a recharge. Only two characters have skills that could fall under magic, and I didn't pick either of them. I need me my on-demand flashbang dammit. 

In terms of mission structure, at multiple points you can select one of multiple missions(though it's more of a "which one do you do first" rather than a proper choice), and at certain points you need to acquire skulls to progress, done by completing Safehouse Missions. This is like the most obvious padding in the history of video games, but at least you can get them done with early. Contrary to what people say, this game is NOT like Left 4 Dead; it's simply NOT a horde shooter. It's more like Dying Light in mission structure (as well as in enemy variants).

Stealth is possible but is very bare bones (if it wasn't obvious for the fact an update had to add cultist stealth takedowns), so loud is very much the preferred approach. Then again, not like I played Prey stealthily either.

The gameplay in general is a massive stepdown from Prey, but honestly I kinda liked it, I definitely had some fun with the game. Not one of the greatest games ever made, but I think you could find worse. I mean, for a studio which never did co-op, open world or live-service before and were forced to (including the inclusion of vampires, that was forced too), it's not exactly good but honestly it's not the worst.

[h2] Story [/h2]
Scientists make vampires real, blocking off the titular island town of Redfall via sea tides and a permanent eclipse. We have the technology. We can science magic into reality.

Meanwhile, [strike] six with DLC [/strike] four shitheads end up getting plot armoured and being the ones to kill the vampires; totally not Insomniac Spider-Man ex-military Jacob, magic wielding uni student in crippling debt Layla, idk Remi and her robot Bribon, and self proclaimed "cryptid hunter" Devinder. 

Redfall's story won't set the world on fire. It absolutely did not. But honestly I didn't hate it. There are some exposition missions but aside from that it's relatively well paced.

[h2] Graphics [/h2]
I played on low, which resulted in ABSURD pop-in (especially with the shadows), and I had FSR on which resulted in less than stellar image quality. The UI itself has issues, with copious amounts of default Unreal Engine 4 UI font. Artisically, it's not really unique but it looks pretty nice.

[h2]Beyond Opinion [/h2]
[i] Note: As of today's (May 30th 2024) update a lot of this rant is void, but I'm still keeping it for posterity. [/i]

Warning: the following text is going to be dramatic as an edgy 2010's emo fanfic. You have been warned.

Now what I said is very much my opinion. The following is also admittedly my opinion despite the subheading. But there's a difference between an opinion about a game's various components and what I'm about to write.

You will walk through rocks. You will get semi-stuck between rocks(you can get out easily bur your viewmodel will spaz out). Your Heroes hands will get freaky when using a skill. Your character will t-pose in menus. You will ocassionally be told you can't connect to the Arknet despite being fine, and you will need to brute force your way into the game. The HUD will cut off at lower resolutions. You will fall through the ground(though that might be a HDD issue). Performance probably still isn't fully fixed. These are just some of the issues I experienced. Not saying it's launch-state Cyberpunk 2077, but compared to other games it is terifically below par.

Redfall in it's current state is broken as shit.

And it will remain broken as shit.

Today as of writing this review, Arkane Austin is announcing to be shutting down. Of course this means no Prey 2, but this also cause a more pressing matter at hand; the future of Redfall. With their shutdown, they have announced the cessation of further development. Now this would be fine if it was basic updates right? But no.

As part of the [i] Bite Back [/i] edition, you would have been able to get access to two new Heroes. This will now not occur and you can get a refund for the value of the BB upgrade's price.I didn't buy the Bite Back edition (no way I would pay 85 quid for this game), but still.

But what I'd say more importantly, is the lack of further patches, and the fact that offline mode is no longer coming.

Admittedly this review has gotten a bit dramatic, but you have NEVER heard a game studio announce "we'll add offline mode" and then go "umm actually you're not getting offline mode". Even though this happening to Redfall isn't the biggest deal in the world, it surely doesn't set a good precedent. What if this happened to Sea of Thieves? Halo Infinite? People would be absolutely losing their bloody minds. 

And on top of that, they will keep the game as broken as it is. If they were also pulling the game from sale or something, sure that'd probably mean they'd shut it down but it's not that big of a deal. Redfall would just be a drop in video game history. A stain in the long road.

But as of writing, Redfall is currently still for purchase; the Bite Back edition isn't anymore, no, but the game itself is, and it is very apparent to me this will be like this for the long run. Bethesda likely has the money to keep the game going for stupid long periods of time.

In my personal opinion, the continued sale of Redfall in its current state amounts to a scam. You may argue it was always a scam sure, but this has made it definite. There is NO way in hell Microsoft does not know how fucking scuffed this game is on a technical level. To bail out on it and STILL take money for it is, to me, absurd.

And as of writing, they were working on the DLC eight hours ago actually. They were working on the DLC and then they get shut down.

Arkane Austin was really forced to make a game they were not prepared for, and then proceeded to get killed when the end result doesn't end up being peak, ESPECIALLY while they are actively working to improve said game post-launch.

Fucking hell Microsoft.

And not to mention they also shut down other studios, including Tango Gameworks. What the fuck did THEY do? They did nothing wrong. Certified bruh moment


UPDATE 17/05/2024: So the tweets all said there will be no more updates but Hi-Fi Rush got one final update like a couple days ago so uhh hopium sesh time????????

UPDATE 26/05/2024: Apparently a final update with offline mode is confirmed, video game preservation w??????

[h2] Verdict [/h2]
I hereby declare [b] Redfall [/b] as
[h3] A "FUCKING HELL, MICROSOFT" MOMENT. [/h3]

If you [i] really [/i] must play this game, it goes on sale for 75% off pretty much every major sale. I mean, my expectations were very high since this is the studio that made Dishonored series (although, it was Arkane Lyon that made the series but still they are the same company) and Dishonored is one of my favorite games and for me, that series is a masterpiece. So, with those expectations, Redfall fails to live up to them. But, for the price of 7.5 (there was a 75% sale when I purchased it), it's an okay game. The graphics are very good and fun. But the characters have little to no depth, cutscenes and story are bland, the gameplay and quests are little bit boring and gets repetitive very quickly. I mean for me, this game is like combining Borderlands, Far Cry, Dying Light and then taking the 25% of the combination. The guns get very weak with every level we get, just like in Borderlands. This made me use a lot of different weapons so I guess that was nice. But the safehouses, (or antennas in Far Cry and Dying Light) have the same 3 quests and then killing a boss. Gets very repetitive very quick. Sometimes, you don't know you're dying because there is not much of a clear indication of noises that alert you enough. Had little to no crashes or bugs until the last boss where the game crashed three times. Overall, it felt like a longer headhunter dlc of borderlands, so it is buyable on a sale but comparing this game to Deathloop or Dishonored, this game has literally too little to offer

Redfall never deserved most bad reviews it has been given. The game was being review-bombed before it even released on multiple sites because fans of other IPs created by Arkane Studios were upset Arkane hadn't made a new version of one of their favorite games instead of this one--that's on those fans, not the game or studio.

Were there issues with Redfall's release? Absolutely. What new release doesn't have bugs? No game in the history of video gaming ever. Are there legitimate gripes to be made? Sure, but most poor reviews consist of complaints made by people with very little play time about issues other games have largely been given a pass on--games with remarkable review histories with the exact same issues.

So, one year after release, what big negatives remain: 1) online only, even for solo play; and 2) the price tag. The first is the kind of crap I have come to expect from Bethesda and certainly not Arkane's fault; and, importantly, it doesn't reflect on the game, itself (but may influence a purchase). The second can be resolved with buying it on sale (which I completely recommend), because however good the game may be, it's not worth $70 a pop. I have bought this twice--once as a full price gift prior to release, and once for myself on sale. With a good sale, at nearly sixty hours of play time, I've gotten far more value out of my dollar than my Netflix subscription.

Personal negatives? Outside of the two big ones, above: 1) not being able to make a manual save is a bit frustrating, especially since a few bugs remain that could pop up and prevent you from acquiring a 'one chance per playthrough' achievement. That can be rough if you're an achievement hunter; 2) I'd like to see whatever is causing occasional issues with movement in the game resolved. Whether it is enemies or heroes getting caught on invisible architecture, or heroes not being able to simply climb into the back of a van without vaulting over it; 3) someone please redo the voice lines for the Raven, preferably with an actual corvid -- the voice, now, is just bad (but thankfully, not heard often).

The positives? The atmosphere is great. I absolutely loved the depiction of a Northeastern US island town. The way the story unfolds like a mystery instead of being handed to you on the silver platter. The characters and voice acting are both very well done (with the glaring exception of the Raven). And the playable heroes are interesting, with intriguing power sets that can have impactful play styles.

I had a lot of fun, and expect to have more in the future. So, if you're on the fence, but online-only isn't a deal breaker AND Redfall is on sale? Try it. Hopefully, you'll like it as much or more than I have.

Entering a game knowing it's bad is a different affair. I am more relaxed without any fear of missing out anything which might be vital to the plot. I don't have any expectation so I am not nitpicking as much as I would've in a 96 metascore game. 
Now, the game is not good, make no mistake, but it's not 4/10 bad. I am playing it 1 year after launch and most of the technical problems seem to be fixed bar 2 crashes early on.

That being said, let's talk about the game part of the game. I can't tell you how bad the story is because it's so poorly told that it lost me 1 hour in. The gameplay is pretty fun and involving but it encourages you to stealth with a hand by making most enemies really strong later on, while simultaneously not giving you any means of stealth with the other. So 90% i just killed everyone and it was functional.
The worst thing is the dialogue, and in particular, the protagonist. If it was ever a time when I missed the silent protagonist was now. This guy will just not shut up and everytime he talks I want to strangle him. Don't get me wrong, all of the characters are like this but they are very few with really limited interactions so if that were all it would have been tolerable. No! My guy just needs to comment on everything and over-explain any plot developments in a "comedic" fashion until any subtlety flies out the window. 
This, in turn, lead to an unbelievable clashing of tones, because, against all odds, the game is pretty atmospheric in missions. Really need to stay on my toes, gameplay-wise, and story-wise, the situation is quite horrific. If only they kept the dialogue method of dishonored, short, serious, and to the point, the game would have only been pretty bad instead of aggressively bad to the point that I feel personally assaulted. 

Probably the guys who made dishonored and prey don't even work at Arkane, so I won't hold my breath for their next title, Blade, especially because, being a superhero, they will inevitable give it a go with that "wacky marvel dialogue"      .

Update after 55+ hours. So have got to the end and completed the game once over in 'Dusk' difficulty level and all the side missions + neighbourhoods. I'll admit to not reading all the little notes and I found about 60 of the 100 grave notes. 

I'll admit to really loving the game in the end and got addicted eventually, but only after the first 5 or 6 hours of play. I don't know what it is about the early experience of it that put me off, but once I was in control, I started to settle in and couldn't put it down.

I loved the game mechanics, despite a handful of minor bugs here and there (I did pick the game up for the first time 12 months post release, so I guess most things people complained about were fixed).

It's pretty immersive, the art direction is pretty incredible, loved the music - Story could have been a little better, but you do get into it more by "Burial Point" (which is the 2nd area map / set of neighbourhoods).

Looking at my game achievement scores, I can see that only 12% of people who buy this game complete it and a lot of the achievements have very low player percentage of achievement, which is a shame really. Think more people should have given the game a chance and I'm pretty surprised by the 'mostly negative' reviews.

If you're sitting on the fence about it, I would say the game doesn't disappoint. It's entertaining to play, especially with a friend and we both loved it. Most of the negativity is related to the first 12 months where the game was released at full price as a 'finished' game, but was largely buggy and incomplete. Those issues have since been resolved for the most part (although some minor bugs still remain end of May 2024).

Update after 18 hours:  So, I have to say, I am enjoying this game. The negative rep this game has attracted is not the sum of its parts in my opinion. I'm playing along with a friend and neither of us can understand why people find it awful. It's a fun shooter. 

I suppose they could have gone full horror with it, but to be honest I quite like the cheeky lightheartedness of it. That's just a matter of personal styling, I think it would work either way. There's plenty of variety to keep you immersed in the game. The loot you're picking up to gain cash which you can use to buy better weapons if available at the safe houses, restock on ammo, etc.

I like the different missions, the music design is well thought out and I personally like the graphics.

There are a few glitches here and there, opening some of the locked cases, the sliding instead of walking of team mates sometimes... But to be honest they are very small, not really noticeable and don't ruin the overall enjoyment of the game.

If this is still available at a low price, I would say the game is a steal and definitely worth the money.

So I've played around three hours or so and I don't consider this game to be as bad as a lot are still saying. It seems people are hating on it just because the pitchforks are out, or maybe it got off to a bad start almost a year ago now. I know I'm late to the party, but I'm enjoying this version as it stands so far. I wouldn't say it's the best game I've ever played, but I certainly don't dislike it by any stretch. So what do I like and dislike?

Well I got it on offer for ¬£14.99 and in my opinion, it's definitely worth that. I like the story, I like the artwork and scenery. The missions are interesting and I'm enjoying the exchange of fire with vamps and hollowmen! So in terms of beauty and entertainment, I'd say it gets high marks.

So where is it failing? I'm playing solo game coop with a friend and we're having a lot of fun... But, the reward/loot factor is too high - We're always fully stocked up and so the challenge diminishes. This game has a balance problem and I think they could do with addressing that. I've only played a few hours, so I'm early into third or fourth mission, so the challenge could get harder...(?)

The music and sound design is excellent, love that. But the sound direction feels off. It's a bit disorientating hearing an enemy behind, but it's not there at all. Maybe that's just me, not sure.

I'll be sure to come back and add to my review after a few more hours and missions in. But so far, if you're sitting on the fence, I'd say go for it. There's a lot worse games out there at higher prices. Redfall deserves another chance!

OLDER GAMER HERE, I started gaming on a Sinclair ZX-81 back in the early 1980s.

I found this to be a masterpiece of a game, STRONGLY RECOMMENDED. 10 out of 10 ‚Äî one of the most enjoyable games I have EVER played.

It was wise of me to disregard the negative reviews. 

I bought a Steam code for ‚Ç¨15.74 from Fanatical (March 2024), and I have to say that I am loving every minute I have played so far. Here is what I enjoy:

(1) The game code is very well optimized. My nVidia RTX 3060 12 Gb fan barely makes any noise while playing the game, with most settings maxed. The game never crashed on me even ALT-TABing out of it, e.g. in order to check something on the Internet, and ALT-TABing back into the game.

(2) The game is first-person view only, and open world, of medium size. The in-game map is clear and easy to read. Lots of houses and locations to investigate. You can fast travel between safe houses and monuments or walk ‚Äî no cars or other vehicles (not that they are needed, the world is not that big).

(3) The graphics are very well done and very atmospheric. They remind me of Fallout 4 and The Sinking City. The attention to detail is amazing and so is the movement of the character. You step over every little object ‚Äî and I never got stuck even moving into tight corners.

(4) The story is absolutely gripping. You have to deal with cultists and vampires. The game scratches my zombie itch in that respect.

(5) The interface is simple and elegantly done. Not super confusing as in other games I love, e.g. The Division.

(6) There are skills to unlock that are organized on a skill tree that does not feel overly complicated.

(7) There are safe houses to unlock, usually after turning their power on and occasionally after beating the cultists that defend them. The game reminded me of Far Cry and Dying Light in this respect.

(8) You can parkour! In addition to jumping, when you press the SPACE BAR, your hands reach up and you climb to whatever you are looking at. Moving from one roof to another in the city at night is just amazing.

(9) Destroying a vampire lair is a lot of fun. You enter the lair through a door, and the lair feels like an alternate reality, sort of like a neighborhood that looks wrong, in which you have to find and destroy the heart, and after that make it out of the lair in less than a minute.

(10) If you enjoy searching houses, yards, and other locations for items, you are going to love this game. And whatever you collect, get converted to currency immediately ‚Äî you don't have to sell it anywhere.

(11) Finally, daylight, the easiest difficulty, is doable for kludges like me, although it can get challenging when more than one Vampires are attacking you. The boss fights don't seem unfair.

TIP: When you first start the game, you may have to disable any external displays (that are in a different resolution than your main one) in order to get all resolutions to show up in the Settings.

A Promising Concept hindered by Short Length and Development Bugs

One of the most glaring issues with Redfall is its brevity. Despite boasting a captivating world filled with rich lore and interesting characters, the main campaign feels disappointingly short-lived. Players may find themselves completing the primary storyline in a matter of hours, leaving them craving more depth and substance. This lack of content ultimately detracts from the game's potential longevity and replay value.
Furthermore, Redfall is marred by several development bugs that hinder the gameplay experience. From occasional framerate drops to AI pathfinding issues, players may encounter a variety of technical glitches that detract from immersion and disrupt the flow of gameplay. These bugs can range from minor annoyances to game-breaking issues, leading to frustration and disappointment.

The game is okay. Campy as hell, which I actually kind of liked. Campy makes me laugh. The world is really empty though. It feels a little like Dishonored with some Fallout loot tossed in. The loot is sold immediately upon pickup, which took me way too long to figure out. "Where is all that loot that I just picked up???" Durr, it sells instantly and grants you health. It would be nice if this was explained in one of the absurdly long tutorial screens that pop up at the most inconvenient moments, but hey, who am I to tell a well-established game publisher how to make engaging games.... 

Anyway. I wanted to like it.

I really did. But alas, it just... pushes you away every chance it gets. The world is a bit empty, the NPCs that do exist have zero depth. When I go to slide, my character will slide like 100000 feet before finally stopping and its impossible to aim and shoot while that happens. Its impossible to know just how many vampires are going to be in an area. If you see only 2, assume there are 10. The radar is laughable. Questionable? Exclamatory. 

I only paid ~$17 for it, and I still feel kind of ripped off. It has an unfinished quality to it. Like they had a great idea, and just couldn't be bothered to follow all the way through. A young teenager may enjoy it. Otherwise, I just can't recommend this one.

So I have played Redfall.  Beaten it once with one character, began with another character and stopped.

The world has a very Arkane feel to it, which if you've played any of their games, you'll appreciate. There is a ton of really cool worldbuilding elements and small stories in little places that showcase an event happened here and that's really dope. 
For all intents and purposes Redfall feels like a real place which is very cool. Kinda washed out like a contemporary Dunwall. There are things like birds circling houses which is cool and the storm before a Rook arrives is very cool. Additionally, the set pieces surrounding the bosses are cool but the bosses themselves are very been there done that.

The characters are fine. I played as the coast guard character and found it fine, playing as the psychic character I found the internal monologue eye-rolling. 
The gunplay is balls, characters become bulletsponges instead of becoming smarter or more elusive, some builds are just useless, you'll never need the sniper person like ever because most skirmishes don't merit actual prep planning when you can just cheese everything. 
The story is very hit and miss, there are some beats that are really cool, but the throughline is garbage. 
Finally, and it might seem nitpicky. Put some fucking cinematics in the game. It's just jarring to do to the comicbook thing because it's basically a sign to tune out and go grab a drink.

On a sub-twenty discount with a friend, it's worth going through for sure. The bite back edition is definitely not fucking worth it. 
But the real issue is that, fucking play L4D or Borderlands instead. They still hold up fabulously and also hit these notes better.
This game on the real is a $19.99 game at best. Not sure why it is 70 gig to install. Yes 70 gig .. the trailers look nice and I guess it just gets better. All good. I like it.

Redfall launched to a LOT of issues. Had it been delayed six to eight months, it might have been received better. Another reviewer summed up the game best when they called it "Far Cry, but with vampires". In Redfall, you're going to assault locations full of bad guys, hunt sub-bosses, and then square off against proper bosses. Every time you do, you'll unlock loot and gain experience points to unlock new abilities. Rinse and repeat. If that's all you want out of the game, you'll have a good time. The gun play is good, the abilities are fun, and since Redfall is a "looter shooter" you'll get that dopamine drip of new goodies constantly. I bought the game for about $15 on sale through a 3rd party site and I can honestly say I've gotten my money's worth out of it. Will that change as new DLC and whatnot drops down the road? I'll have to wait and see.

Great fun. I'm glad I waited to play this one, after all the static and heat calmed down. It's a fun, dark, action-packed shooter that has a lot going for it. It also takes up a unique space in the genre. Not many horror shooters that are built like this out there.

Got it on sale cause I thought "nah, it can't be that bad". 
It can.

It's an OK game at its core and I had a pretty good time completing its campaign. In fact, the most egregious problem here is the price point. For that kind of money, you'd expect the highest level of quality and not an aggressively mediocre shell of a game, only good to be muted so that you could play it while catching up on podcasts.

In a lot of ways, this reminds me of Anthem because it's yet another example of a developer whose strengths lie in crafting sophisticated single player experiences but somehow they got involved in producing a co-op looter shooter. Every now and then while playing you will notice glimpses of that studio's signature style of gameplay, but most of the time your brain will barely process it as a background task while you're in deep thought about what's for dinner.

In short, it's passable if you paid 20 buckaroos for it like I did. But, had I paid full price upon release, I'd be steaming out of my ears.

Like it - 7/10

Don't roll your eyes at me... I had fun, it's a solid 7 in my book.

Update: I have now played the game again after its last patch. This is what it should have been at launch, it runs smooth, plays well and now there's a pause button. The game has great atmosphere and game-play. Its such a shame this is not what we got, and it ruined the devs. 

This game and Arkane deserved better. Besides the crazy amount of miss-able achievements this game is pretty good and worth getting.  Its fun solo and I would love to play coop, but sadly those days have passed. 


Original review: I have tried to get into it a few times. I actually enjoy the gameplay and the setting. I like the designs and ascetics. But this game plays very poorly, also some of the gameplay choices, such as non replayable missions and a huge amount of missable achievements, suck.

While this game definitely shouldn't have launched in the state it was in, it has gotten a lot better as time has passed.  Is it at all a perfect game?  No, it still has issues but it is a decent bit of fun and I still find myself having a challenge on nightmare, still have yet to beat the game and play on the hardest difficulty and will update this once I do.

Redfall at its core has potential to be a great game but it fell short and now has a horrible reputation.  Having to start up an entirely new run for just wanting to switch characters is annoying, along with story progression not carrying over from co-op play.  The updates and patches for this game are slow but each one is adding much needed QOL changes and improvements.  The characters are quite fun to play and their kits do have good synergy and are strong by themselves.  The dialogue is still very much Arkane but in a more comedic way while still keeping the dark tones of the game.  The characters and gameplay loop is fun but the AI still has its faults.

The AI is still decently dumb but not as buggy and or as stupid as they were at launch.  They aren't anything incredible but they do their job of being cannon fodder while the vampires are the main threat.  The vampires have decent AI and can prove to be a challenge to take down in groups, especially with the different variants that are in the game.  I will say the Rook needs more work as in my opinion they are the easiest to take down despite them supposed to be a major mini-boss of sorts.  Attack patterns are simple and easy to avoid.

A small note to add is the fact this game is still online only, hopefully it follows most games that realized this error like Payday 3 and Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League and adds one.

I do believe this game can recover and be something good and not be a lasting blow on Arkane Austin.  It definitely needs more time and fixes to be in that state.  Solo or tagging a friend along, its a fun time but its still not worth the $70.  $30 is more what this game is worth to me at least in the state that it is in right now.  It is a fun time regardless though from my experience.

It's a shame to see this last part of my review can't and wont be true to do the shutdown of Arkane Austin and many other studios. My statement still stands with it being bought on a discount with the last update the devs pushed out, really is a shame to see that this update was fixing parts of the game and fleshing it out more, wish I could see what else they had planned before the door was shut on them.

TL;DR I would say this game is worth at least maybe $30 in its current state and is a decent time solo or co-op, though would definitely say get a friend in if possible.  These games are much more fun with friends.
omfg

Forgot to leave a review back when I bought it.

It was both boring and bad.
love the game play

I know this game had a rough launch release, but I am really enjoying it and I think they cleaned it up nicely. It was a challenge but not to hard that I wanted to quit instead of trying again. The story was good, I think it had good depth and character development, the game looked good, every once in a while I would get a little bit of massive lag, but that might have been my PC more then the game. I think I ran into maybe 1 or 2 bugs, that were easy to fix with a game reset. I really enjoyed playing this game.

Sometimes it feels as if this game doesn't know what it wants to be, but if you just wanna blaze through it, blindly following quest markers without putting much or any thought into it, then this game might be for you.
You can't get disappointed anymore when your expectations are already low from all the bad press the game got

Gonna give it a yes, but it's definitely almost a no.  If I hadn't picked this up for $18 I wouldn't be super happy about it. 

The gun play feels really bad to me at least compared to shooters like call of duty or destiny.  Looting is fairly boring.  Vampires are not fun to fight at all.  They just get in your face via teleporting making it hard to aim because they are so close on the camera.  Just makes me feel constantly crowded/claustrophobic.  

The guns don't handle well at all.  Reload speeds are just awfully slow like there's a vampire chewing on you, maybe put a tiny bit of effort into speeding up that reload. Skip the tactical reload, dump that mag on the ground and get the next one in like maybe your life depends on it, lol.  I realize I'm playing a young college girl who probably never touched a gun in her life but damn it just feels awful to play.

Finally, dodging.. I spend most of my play time in a sprint away from the fight while I reload, trying to guess the exact moment I should slide to avoid the claws.  All this without being able to see, so it's pretty much a guess.  When in close quarters there is no way to mitigate or avoid vampire damage.  No dodge mechanic, no block, it's face tank and shoot or do the run and slide thing. 

Thumbs up because I got 11 hours of entertainment about it even if I finally realized it's just not fun for me running away, sliding, spinning around shooting, running away, sliding ... you get the point.  Maybe "end game" or later in the game guns actually start hurting the vampires fast enough that you don't need to do the run and slide stuff, but as I aged I stopped playing games that weren't fun while "leveling" because what's the point really.

I haven't tried the co-op because none of my friends own the game and nobody is playing online, but I think I could kill some more hours with a buddy at some point and not totally hate it.

I love this game, from the story to the game-play. I had been looking forward to it's release for a long time and sure the release was rough but it's turned into a game that I recommend to others and enjoy spending hours playing. I'm looking forward to more updates big and small, along with the new characters whenever those drop. Thank you Arkane Austin & Bethesda Studios!!!

Janky in many ways and definitely very buggy, especially in Co-op. However, there is a fun Arkane skeleton underneath the jank. The world is easily the best part with lots of attention to detail in hidden areas and environmental storytelling everywhere. That being said, the gameplay loop doesn't do much to reward exploration of that world in the way previous Arkane games have which is a shame. There is plenty of lore if you're interested in that type of thing and the main characters have fun personalities, even if they are a bit cliche.
 The game definitely suffers from being a looter shooter and even a co-op game in a few ways. There was the potential for a really cool, tense, vampire killing, stealthy game here but it definitely fell short of the fantastic bar Arkane have set for themselves.
Overall I did have fun with the game and I do recommend it if you like vampires, open worlds and cool visuals. 
Not for full price though! PICK IT UP ON A DEEP SALE!!
Trying to slide a $70 charge for this broken and poorly developed game should be a crime.
its fine

it's not a bad game, sure it lacks in graphics and the storyline is not that innovative, but it's fun and in coop with friend it's even more fun.
if you can get it on discount, it's good.
it's really good
You can't break my heart like this.
REALLY fun!
Enjoyed the open world very much

For 15 EUR probably worth it as an FPS timewaster.
But all in all it is mostly a lot of wasted potential.

Pro's:

- Interesting aesthetic & atmosphere
- Setting/world & theme are interesting albeit underdevelopped.
- FPS system is 'okay'. There are some interesting ideas like the UV & Stakes. But all in all very basic.
- Overall the mechanism and rpg system is functional.
- There is a bit of creepyness here and there especially early on but it only goes so far. The chosen aesthetic probably diminishes the horror/suspense.

Contra's:

- The main plot is pretty boring.
- Engagement is limited. It feels very cookie cutter.
- Political correctness and 'Hello Fellow Kids' vibe all over the place.
- The combat does nothing special and there is little depth.


Conclusion:
Worth it on the cheap to waste time with. But in the current state anything over 20 EUR is wasted money.
Might improve with some more updates. I may revisit it eventually.
fun game, very good idea , need some fixes but still enjoyed this game

I don't normally bother with bad reviews; check out my other game reviews, and you will see this for yourself. This game feels like a blatant cash grab. This is what I would expect to get if I were to put a penny into a candy machine at a grocery store and a game redemption code came out. The graphics are generations outdated, the art & design are horrible, the animations are terrible, the gameplay feels like a cheap, A.I.-generated, algorithmic reproduction of the weakest examples from the past. I bought this on sale thinking, "How bad could it be? I like vampires." I'm here to tell you that I feel ripped off. Even at a discounted price, I feel taken advantage of. Redfall really is THAT bad. Everyone who worked on this and who was involved in okaying its release should be fired and banned from ever working on PC games again for their entire lives.

It's been a while since I've played a game as frustrating as this one, one of the ads or intro vids I saw presented it as "play coop or by yourself" (paraphrasing). no, it's not meant as a SP game, it's tacked on as an afterthought. First play through I selected tutorials but they're very limited, so I didn't know that vampires may leave a collectable residue when killed and since the residue glows weakly, especially during the day it's virtually unnoticeable. yes you might see the ashes but not realise that they're collectable.  I killed several dozens before noticing a weak glow during a sundown. also not explained by the tutorials: the meaning of the chomping jaws that occasionally appear in a corner (red teeth) or on storage box contents (white on black), or the fact that the ultra-vast majority of objects you can pick up are not stored but instantly converted to cash. the backpack has 40 slots and I could never fill it, well it turns out that this is shown in text that can't be made larger and I am vision impaired. I needed someone to tell me what was happening. There's no pause function, understandable for online/coop play but not offline. I was killed very literally hundreds of times while tweaking the settings or answering a call and of course it's one of those games where you get charged for dying... all that cash collected, gone tweaking settings. Ah, the settings, the settings... I have a 1080p monitor, but the game has no FHD option; maxres is 1366x768. WHY? because I have an RTX capable card? no idea, what if I do and I don't want to upscale? enemies spawn within seconds of you clearing an area, and if you approach a group of enemies by stealth - and therefore slower, I've lost count of how many dozens of times I was killed by enemies that spawned in an area I just cleared. You go back to your last death locations where you have collectables from dead enemies, and in the 3 minutes you were gone the area has changed drastically. going back to a T  intersection where there were drops from 6-7 enemies, the drops were gone but there was a road block, a van, a UV trap with a stone vampire. and the two biggest mind-fuzz ever since X-Com, which also was guilty of this: Once enemies lock onto you, they will hit you even from behind cover. So far I've been killed: behind a tree, crouching on a path running at the edge of an (empty) river with rocks, soil and cement between us, and by an enemy who was obviously below ground. as far as I was able to determine, if you can see their !!! or ???, they WILL hit you. and the greatest perverse peeve: use a pistol, the vast majority of drops will be shotgun shells or combat rifle. switch to combat rifle/shotgun and the drops will switch to pistol and sniper rifle. i suspect it will only provide you with a little of your most used ammo to force you to switch. once again as with the resolution, what if I always want to use the same weapon, what's it to the devs? reason to rage quit: the game is online only, even in SP. if your network connection drops, you get booted out to the main menu. My internet connection has always been sketchy, so between all of the above and the disconnections, you go ahead, guess how much fun i'm having in this game?

i went in without too high expecations and found a fun atmospheric open world shooter/looter. the atmosphere and exploring the town is the highlight here. would recommend on sale.
still for an arkane game, who used to be a great immersive sim dev studio (arx fatalis, dishonored, prey) this is very lackluster. but as i understand this wasnt made by the same team
super fun and challenging. IDK why the hate, plus they are still adding things to the game. I really hope more people give this a try its worth it as there is nothing close to it

It's fine now, had lots of stability updates, just don't try to use higher settings than your system can do. If you don't have an ultra machine, you can't run ultra. I have an Nvidia RTX 1060 11gb and it's fine on high. Cool guns, creepy atmosphere, sneaking up on vampires and stabbing them with wooden stakes doesn't really get old for me. not a $60 game though unless I am missing some sort of additional repeatability. I think it would be better with friends on the hardest settings. And go Vampire hunting at night. Way more enemies and way harder to kill. I'm planning on doing this with friends soon. I'm getting jump scared while I'm also sneaking around. It's kind great if you like sneaking around and picking off enemies. Running straight in is usually bad. You can get ganged up on quick at night. It's not an overly complicated game. Which I enjoy. Sneak, snipe, stab, loot, repeat.

DO NOT PAY FULL PRICE FOR THIS GAME! Now that we've gotten that out of the way, if you see this game for $40 or less, YOU GRAB THIS GAME! Once you get to $40 this game is every bit worth that price. You are in a town that's been overrun with vampires and the cultists that support them. Your job is to SMITE them with extreme prejudice. You can go in with a team of your friends and charge in and defeat them all or you can take a rouge approach and solo stealth through the town taking them all down on the sly. There are lots of little adventures that honestly made me giggle and super strong vampires that will challenge your abilities. This game is absolutely fantastic from the combat to the environment, it's just not anywhere near $70 fantastic.

At least we got the offline patch...

I tested it myself, you don't even need to create a new character it just downloads your online save file. At the very least now the game won't die with Arkane and they finally followed through with the promise of releasing a single player mode, even from beyond the grave.

RIP Arkane Austin.

At full price this is a hard NO or make sure you're watching game time so you can refund.

At $15 or less, you may get some mild amusement from it and not feel like you got ripped off. But you will be stuck thinking from Prey to this...?  Sad.

This is a great game. It had some launch issues, but they seem to be committed to fixing all of that and improving it. I love the atmosphere and all the story built in to the world. I would recommend this to anyone that loves shooters and story games.

It's a solid vampire shooter.  I did experience some crashes that probably should be patched by now, but otherwise a well done shooter with some cool if not unique mechanics.

I felt like I need to write a review since this game has been less then positive with other players. Now, I did not play this game when it was first released so take this positive review with that in mind. I picked this game up for sale when it was $20. I like that is game. I feel like this has a satisfying quirk to it all. The  gun play is average but it ticks it up a notch when you include the different type of vampire mechanics. Your skills come into play when you are forced to handle the vampires. At first just one vampire can be a pain, but soon with better skills and better guns, one vampire becomes a lot easier to deal with. Now, just when you get the hang of one of just one vampire, you start having to handle more and more at one time, or handle different vampire types. Then you again repeat the process of becoming more powerful through better skills and guns and this will allow you to handle vampires better. I think that this is where the game shines. I am having fun running around killing vampires and collecting loot. There are dungeons, a mechanic where the more vampires you kill a gauge will fill up that allows you to take on a powerful vampire that drops better than average loot. I feel this game is like a Dead Island like game in that the game is played better if you treat it for what it is and not what you want it to be.

definitely DO NOT BUY the "dlc" which is a couple of cosmetic skins and two new characters. 4 to choose from is already enough. if you do buy this game buy it on sale 50% or more. gameplay and graphics are alright. The obligated internet connection is a deal breaker for me. I have lost important progress so many times because my wifi cuts out for a millisecond. I then get booted out of the game and have to re-enter I only play single player so this is frustrating. The dlc is extremely offensive that they would charge the price of a whole new game just for some cheap cosmetics.  @Redfall make an offline mode now.

Bad start, I can't recommend this... Just running the game for the first time, the general loading screens stuttered! We're not even talking gameplay here!! Got into the game, it's okay... then crashes within a few minutes of being online! Mind you I'm playing single player... Why does it have to be online? When I need to go to the bathroom, I press ESC thinking it'll pause the game, but nope... 

I went a little further and killed some enemies, but I'm already not digging the way this game is playing. Steam only gives you 2 hours to refund, so I can't invest too much time. I bought this at 75% off and don't even feel it's worth that. I don't like throwing money away. I bought this during the last sale which is more than 14 days ago, and Steam may not refund... I'm keeping my fingers crossed. I don't understand why this has to be online all the time when you play single player. That's not the biggest deal-breaker to be, but I've heard so much bad and playing for the first time already see it's not running great (and this is HOW LONG after launch??), I don't want to keep playing to lose what I paid. If I don't get the refund and am stuck with it, I'll update this. But to quote Han Solo "I have a bad feeling about this". 

I love Arkane games, the Dishonored series is one of my favorites, really enjoyed Deathloop. Deathloop took a little time to grow on me, but it really was a great game. I hoped to say the same here, but I feel they dropped the ball big time. I'll keep my eyes open on updates and a sale larger than 75% off and maybe try again if things change...

This game company was recently shut down and it will no longer receive the promised updates or any support whatsoever. It was already a short game that had hope of getting better.

It no longer has that hope.

Redfall is far from a perfect game. But it has vampires, a decent loot system, and a game that shines beneath its tarnished exterior.

Pros:
+ the art style of Redfall is a MASSIVE relief from "every game must now be as realistic as possible" motif many modern games have. If you look at a screenshot of Redfall, you'll know what game it was just from the picture
+ decent loot! The loot is plentiful but never too overwhelming. It's a healthy dose of Borderlands 1-style loot and gun design but never disrespectful of your time a la Destiny 2
+ the atmosphere! The atmosphere is creepy, lonely, and full of Autumn vibes. The world seems empty save for vampires, cultists, and a PMC group in town. It vaguely reminds me of S.T.A.L.K.E.R Anomaly's world map
+ you're never taken out of the story during cutscenes. You're directly involved with the course of the narrative and never treated like an outsider like in BL3
+ killing vampires is always highly satisfying

So-So:
+/- the gunplay isn't as tight as other FPS games but it's certainly come far from where it was before
+/- the empty world can feel too empty with few things to explore but that can be forgiven with deeper exploration and collectables
+/- the side quests are meh, mainly "fetch this, look for that" but lore can be found in notes scattered around the world to fill it in
+/- some buildings can feel samey, but can be forgiven if you think about how neighborhoods are constructed with largely similar housing plans
+/- sometimes the AI will stand around, and other times they'll actually try to scout you out. It's a mixed bag

Cons:
- few named locations make looking for things to explore a little boring
- playing solo can be a bit of a rut due to poor balancing
- the balancing is AWFUL. At some points you're 1:1 with your enemies and other times you're 2+:1 in terms of pure damage
- vampires huddling in groups of 3+ will outnumber and kill you extremely quickly
- clunky healing makes healing during combat meh
- "skill trees" are boring, uninspired, and not in any way intuitive
- the dialogue could be better but not horrible
- No offline mode

For 75% off, I'm enjoying the game. Think of the game as a lighter helping of Borderlands. There may be way less gun variety, but it's because it's not flooded with useless combinations. Example is the flare gun. You got your 1 shot single heavy damage or your 2 shot lighter damage. Kinda hard to squeeze out more flare gun drops that wouldn't annoy players
