Maybe I'm too easy, but I'm really enjoying this game. It's pretty much your basic open world map with tasks and battles, but looks fantastic; very reminiscent of the Arkane games (Dishonoreds, Prey, et al.) I have enjoyed so much in the past. No, it's NOT those games, depth-wise, but if you find it on sale ($15), grab it. You won't regret it!  ;)
I am enjoying this game and the graphics are stunning. I think $90 may be a little high but I would recommend this game to anyone.

I bought this because it was cheap and I had some high hopes for it since it's Arkane/Bethesda. This is fun to run around and shoot things with a friend/friends. There are weird power spikes in enemies, I haven't quite figured out if it's my level/time/quest line or something else. I'll shoot something in the leg and it basically dies then awhile later I will shoot a human in the head 5x before it dies. The solo gameplay is very dependent on your choices for talents and how you utilize these in combat to succeed or leave. Learning the specific character's strong points and focusing on them makes for better gameplay for myself. Hope this helps.

I love Arkane games.
I absolutely hate this one, and cannot believe that it was made by the same people that made my favourite Prey.
My disappointment is immeasurable.

After reading so many bad reviews I expected something really horrible, I got it on sale and was pleasantly surprised.   The game is not as bad as it seems from the comments. You just need to take it for what it is - a very casual shooter, not an immersive sim or in any way similar to other Arcane games. it should not be compared.
The world and locations are well designed and they are quite interesting to explore. There are many classic Arcane signatures you can find here even in the gameplay as well. Locations are designed in such a way to encourage you to use various tactics depending on your abilities or arsenal. 
if you are an Arcane fan, then definitely expect a much simpler and more basic shooter game than what they previously made. I believe Redfall should not've been more than $40 - $50 at the start, and the price was probably one of the factors driving people to expect more and get disappointed eventually. If you like Arcane and Redfall is on sale, then I do recommend it.

So, in all fairness, I do really like this game. But I still have to give it a thumbs down because of the massive amount of things they just refuse to fix. The game has so many problems I can't even list them all. The major problems being: After you complete the story, they wipe your save and start you at the beginning (that alone warrants a thumbs down), game runs on a scaling system with no way to keep your gear relevant other than farming new, which brings up the next problem... Farming for gear is non existent, you do not get drops from vamps except for special vamps, which are very few, hard to find, hard to kill, randomly generated, and drop blue gear at best (usually white or green) in my 45 hours I never once seen a single purple drop from a special vamp. So quite pointless. The game gives you an option that is suppose to be a farming method but this also fails horribly. Unless your playing as the character that has the lightning abilities, running vampire nests is extremely difficult due to the massive amount of vamps and no way to NOT get swarmed (if you could take them out one by one, it would be better), but the real problem with running nests is that you only have 1 minute to try and run around looting as much as you can (which you can't loot much in 1 minute, like 4-6 items). And unless your running the lightning character, it will take you some 20 minutes for a single run. Oh and the rarity of the items is pretty crap in nests too. Making this option completely pointless as well. The only way to get new gear is to check all the supply vendors at safe houses, reload and repeat, which is so very boring. It would be much much more fun to run nests, but you would need to get much better gear and either not have a timer, or increase the timer to 2 minutes. And there are so many other bugs and problems with the game, its not even funny. And considering its been out for over 3 months now, and its in this bad a shape after 3 updates...that is sad and pathetic. Thus the reason for a thumbs down despite the fact that I did like the game. Could have been so much better if not for poor dev
Las graficas se ven medias infantiles y tampoco son las mejores, tampoco se siente como un juego premium pues los controles son un poco vagos. No recomiendo el juego.

This game is really a "mixed" bag of stuff.

Arkane Studios that developed games like Prey, Deathloop and the Dishonored series, it creates a high expectations and standards which Redfall sadly does not meet based on those games.
Having said that, I don't feel that Redfall deserves the hate it's given, but at the same time sadly it's understandable.
There is no denying that Redfall has it's bugs, from player characters gliding along/through the floor, player characters that look like they want a hug once loaded into the main base/safe house (I really find that funny), to a random Vampire that's stuck in place and enemies that spawn inside the floor or walls.

The difficulty seems to behave oddly. As 4-players we started on Daylight to find our footing and then changed it to Dusk because Daylight had very little encounters. After the difficulty change the first 2 nights of playing was interesting and felt balanced with the weapon drops and the enemy difficulty, but after that it's been one shot-one kill, even with a pistol. However loading into a single player game with the same difficulty and character used in multiplayer, one is killed by the first vampire encountered outside the safe house.

It is essentially in the same style as games like Left 4 Dead, Back 4 Blood, Earthfall, Vermintide, Zombie Army and World War Z (minus the 3rd person) but not as chaotic as these.
If you enjoy those type of games it might be worth a try, but get it on sale, I would suggest around 75% off or more, which is when we bought it.

There's a decent amount to explore in Redfall and missions to complete along with side missions and each character has different abilities.
We're enjoying it a lot, bugs and all.
I'm recommending it because I'm enjoying it and hopefully there will be more patches out sometime this year that will fix the bugs.
fun game. people who are still giving this game a terrible review probably never got past the 1st boss.
What the fuck?
Very fun!! A few small glitches here and there but funny ones imo

Look it's not as bad as the reviews say... but it's still pretty bad. If it wasn't free with my GPU I would have refunded the purchase.

It's just that the difficulty of the game doesn't match the cartoony aesthetic. It looks and feels like Apex Legends meets Vampires.... but it plays like Apex Legends meets Elden Ring with Vampires. I mean ok -- but not really what I was looking for with a dumb braindead vampire cartoon game. 

The combat is boring and repetitive, difficulty only comes from Vampires being stupid hard to defeat with extremely low ammunition. I never played this game on launch, only picked it up in Jan/2024 so it's had several large patches. 
The AI is janky at best. They run around and take cover, then attack and then go back to cover in spurts and fits. 
It feels like they had all the proper behaviors programmed into them, just no logic on when to do them.  So instead of procedurally knowing when to take cover, or when to attack... they just kind of randomly pick a behavior or action, and then randomly choose another. 

The graphics are good, they have a nice cartoon style to them. It runs very well. Parts of the game feel like State of Decay. Rescuing civilians, gathering supplies and clearing out the vampire infestation. It's just not as fleshed out as State of Decay by any means... But you get that vibe.  Granted I have only done 2 quests so far. 

Co-op play is fun for the bit of it I have played. Difficulty is not very hard for being set on the hardest difficulty allowed without unlocking "Eclipse" mode.  And I should mention I was only playing with one other player. (2 of us in total)  The enemy don't feel too spongy, they just kind of overwhelm you because the Vampires can teleport to you instantly, so you have no way to run away or take cover. 

If they do add more patches and improve the AI, and beef up the difficulty options I think this game could recover some of it's bad reviews.

A cautionary tale of what happens when you force a studio to pivot to live service games. Redfall is Far Cry 5 meets Borderlands 2, except just a little bit worse and with a vampire-hunting coat of paint. Gone are the immersive sim elements that Arkane is known for; it's a generic looter shooter with a modest open world and slightly above average gunplay. 

The game itself is passable, hardly the disaster that it has a reputation for being, but if you're paying more than $20 for this game then you shouldn't be. Go buy Prey or Deathloop instead.

A couple of months ago I got a wild hair and decided to play both Redfall and Gotham Knights to see if both titles were as bad as people said they were. I played Redfall specifically on Game Pass (so as to not lose any money if it turned out to be horrible) and ended up beating the game within 40-hours. When I played the game Arkane had already done two big updates but had not done their most recent one. Almost immediately I could tell there was a pretty decent concept that was Redfall buried underneath a broken (at times) and bland (at times) game. The town of Redfall itself is a lovely setting, lending itself a charming vampire-ridden equivalent to so many New England coastal communities. As a community it can oftentimes feel rather empty and boring but it still nonetheless captured my attention, with all of its beautiful Fall foliage; intriguing locales (like the old whaling museum); and quaint neighborhoods. In terms of gameplay I thought character movement and gunplay felt a bit clunky at times (especially the latter) but still did not quite detract from my enjoyment of the game. Of course the elephant in the room, in my opinion, is the game's stability (or lack thereof in some cases). While it's no doubt gotten better since launch I would say it still runs rather poorly at times. There is still quite a bit of pop-in and if you stand still and watch a particular scene for a few seconds you'll see the on-screen assets struggling to properly render, one moment being in hi-res and the next going to low-res, then back to hi-res (I've played the game on both a 3060 and 4060 on Medium/High/Ultra settings and it always did this. Despite all of this though I still found a fun, somewhat interesting game that managed to keep my attention long enough for me to finish it. I didn't feel the need to find every collectible or clear every single vampire nest, but I still found myself wanting to play the game again just to try new aspects out (like different characters). All-in-all it's a decent game with its own set of problems. What matters then is if you are interested enough in the game to develop a tolerance for its shortcomings.

Redfall had a horrible launch yes, but the game is far from that "hurried" crap shoot the developers were forced to put out before it was finished. All these negative reviews stem from the launch, and do NOT reflect the current state of the game. I purchased Redfall on sale for $17.00 and my intentions were to youtube the sh*tstorm for entertainment, but there was no sh*tstorm. The game has come quite a ways and just may be another "No Mans Sky" comeback story. It has given me hours of content and enjoyment, and is more than worth the current sale price.

Positive:

+ World design and the eerie atmosphere in it. Well crafted world in my opinion.
+ Guns and the gunplay was smooth and hitting headshots was satisfying.

Negative:

Update: My opinion of this game hasn't changed. It's disgusting that a [b]trillion[/b] dollar company decided to close this studio over a bad game they didn't even want to make. These major companies worth ridiculous amounts of money are awful for closing studios on a whim. 

Instead of judging this game based on what it should have or should have been, I'm going to review it based on what is actually in the game. I bought this game on sale for about $17. I played the entire game solo. I would absolutely not recommend getting the bite back edition at this point. The new characters haven't been released and all you get are cosmetics. For the price it simply isn't worth it. Also, for just characters I still don't think it's worth it considering how shallow the characters feel that are already in the game. 

For about the first ten hours or so, I actually had a ton of fun with this game. The first area is pretty fun to run around and explore. The gun play is very satisfying. The slide you can do after a big sprint is also a lot of fun because you will slide an obscene distance. The events, missions and encounters are decent enough to be engaging and push the game forward. You can approach some of the missions in different ways such as distant and stealthy, tactical, or guns a blazing. I had a good time experimenting with different approaches to groups of enemies. 

The second area of the game is where things started to run thin. You'll realize at this point that there is very little variety in enemies. In this second area, the enemies are significantly spongier without offering anything significant to reward you for the effort in taking out a challenging enemy. Almost my entire time in the second area was spent avoiding combat as much as possible and when I was detected just running away. Bosses in this part of the game are equally as frustrating and not fun in the slightest to have to deal with. Regular enemies could take me out in a few hits, and to add insult to injury, the AOE of the regular vampire is so huge it is almost impossible to avoid. I can be so far back from a vampire that I could see their entire model and they'd swipe and I'd take 1/3 to 1/2 damage. Not to mention that at this point in the game my guns seemingly barely damaged the vampires unless I could land headshots. 

There's a money system in the game that makes little sense to me. Throughout the world you can find items to pick up that are worth an arbitrary value and you can accrue money. I primarily spent money on reviving after ridiculous deaths, buying ammo, and occasionally lockpicks. There are shops for guns and other things but they never offered anything actually valuable compared to what I would find out while exploring. I never found any significant use for money despite the game giving you tens of thousands of dollars easily. 

I only played as one character. Character's have special abilities that frankly I almost never used because I never saw much of a need for it. The skill tree isn't great. I maxed out the ammo and healing options right away. In my one playthrough I got to level 23 and there were still a lot of skills I had never accessed. There is a NG+ but frankly it would be hard to recommend one playthrough let alone a second. I nearly maxed out one of the skills and when I would remember to use it I never even noticed a difference between the beginning and upgraded versions of the skill. 

I'm not one to jump on a bandwagon and hate on something because it's the thing to do. I gave this game a fair shake. I do think it has some decently fun elements. The gun play is pretty fun. Exploring the environments was interesting because there is some decent environmental story telling. Some of the missions could also be pretty fun as well. What significantly brings this game down, though, is the lack of variety. There are only six weapon types and you're really only going to be using one or two of those once you find the ones you like. The difficulty spike feels unfair or poorly implemented. This is a very under baked product. The ingredients are certainly there for something that could have been quite good. Maybe they can patch this game up and make it a more enjoyable experience in the future? It's hard to say. We'll see. As it is this is technically a functional video game (even with some glitches here or there) but not one that's really worth the time or money.

This game launched a mess. Like a dummy, I bought it day one. Won‚Äôt make that mistake again. Well, I set it aside and waited until they did some fixing. Now, after update 3, I‚Äôve restarted the game and I‚Äôm loving it. Is it perfect? Absolutely not. Some times (not often) an enemy will sit while you shoot them. I‚Äôve seen some funky glitches like people sliding rather than walking, but it‚Äôs not often enough to bother me in the least. I‚Äôve got 22 hours in the game since revisiting it and only one crash. I‚Äôll take that any day.

I think some games just are fun to hate, and once they get on the hate list, it‚Äôs really hard to get off. Call of Duty and Madden Football come to mind.  Check out the reviews on MW3, mostly negative. But guess what, it sells like hot cakes and there are a ton of people out there (including myself) that buy it every year and get more than their moneys worth.  But, since it has become cool to hate COD, the reviews are always negative. I think that is what happened to this game. I‚Äôd say that it has come far enough that it is worth looking at again. 

Positives: 
Good (not great) graphics.  
Good story. I‚Äôve seen hate on the style of cut scenes (they are voiced stills) but I don‚Äôt mind as I‚Äôm the type that skips cut scenes anyway.
Nice open world with great atmosphere. 
I‚Äôve yet to see the 2nd map, but I like the first. 
Great audio. 
Neat idea. I‚Äôm tired of zombies and Nazis. Vampires is a nice change of pace.
Lots of variety in enemies. There are quite a few different types of vampires.
Nice skill tree.
Co-op. From what I hear it works, but my friends won‚Äôt get the game because of all the bad reviews, maybe if it goes on a big sale one day..

Cons:
Game does not tell you how ammo works in the beginning. The ammo in your main base (the firehouse) still does not work for me. I almost quit the game because of this. But my work around now is to just buy the ammo from a safe house and it works.

Ok now for some fun. I often see reviews on Steam that are obviously designed more to get likes and awards than actually provide a useful review. I‚Äôm going to toss in my favorites; maybe I‚Äôll get some awards as well!

1. Nobody reads reviews, so I‚Äôll just say I‚Äôm gay.
2. I‚Äôm paralyzed from the waist down (no disrespect to those who really are). This game allowed me to finally get to know my son. We play it together and have grown closer than we ever were before, because, you know, I‚Äôm not very good at outdoor sports.

Originally, I gave this game a negative review. After four major updates with countless additions and fixes to the game, I decided to come back to try again, albeit, with lower standards than the first round.

When the game first came out, the general opinion on the game was that it was simply underbaked, felt empty, ran poorly, lacked enough substance to the gameplay to keep you engaged for a full 12 hours (as my playthrough took).
So with the updates that have come out since launch, is the game now worth a playthrough?

YES, and here are my reasons;
-Added new community standing system, rewarding you for both collecting massive amounts of loot and complete side objectives as you come across them. Among the upgrades is one that shows grave locks on the map when your close enough to them, making the arduous process of collecting them so much easier and less taxing.
-Optimized the game, making it so that it actually runs smoothly, even on the highest graphic settings possible.
-Fixed numerous bugs, making it easier for you to stay engaged to the game.

I hated this game when I first got it, and it had been sitting in my library unfinished for over a year before I decided I should try again, and I am glad that I did, this game has faced major improvements that make it genuinely playable and enjoyable.

In the end, I would have to give this game about a 7.5/10, when originally I would have said 4.5/10.

Red Fall is an excellent game that I highly recommend to anyone looking for an immersive and engaging gaming experience. The graphics are outstanding, and I love the style of the art. The game runs seamlessly on my PC, with no hiccups of any kind, and the FPS is excellent on my 1440p monitor. 

The combat system in Red Fall is top-notch, and the weapons feel fantastic. The game does an excellent job of making you feel like a badass, whether you're taking out enemies with an assault rifle or a shotgun. 

One thing I appreciate about Red Fall is that the ammo situation isn't as bad as some people claim it to be. You can buy ammo and get money pretty quickly, and you can find ammo in the world as well. This makes for a more balanced gameplay experience, where you're not constantly worrying about running out of ammunition.

However, I do feel that the game is too easy, even when playing on the Midnight difficulty level. While the combat is incredibly satisfying, I would have liked to see a bit more challenge in the game. Perhaps adding more difficult enemies or increasing the number of enemies in each encounter could help to amp up the difficulty and make the game more engaging.

Overall, Red Fall is a fantastic game that I highly recommend to anyone looking for a fun and engaging shooter experience. The graphics are stunning, the combat is satisfying, and the gameplay is well-balanced. While the game may be a bit too easy for some players, it's still a joy to play and provides hours of entertainment.

First of all, I did NOT expect this game to be Dishonored, but I WILL hold it up to the standard that Dishonored set.

This is the first Arkane game I won't bother to 100%. I am probably one of the biggest Arkane fans; I adore that studio, but the last games released were underwhelming.

Deathloop had a sloppy story. Your character had no weight; you constantly felt like you were floating. Your weapons had no weight; you had nothing going for you. Even systems that they created and mastered for Dishonored fell flat in Deathloop.

Redfall is the culmination of the failures of Deathloop and Arkane. That's making me extraordinarily sad. Like in Deathloop, you have no weight. You feel very floaty. My first playthrough was on Hard. I chose to play as Remi. While Remi is a support character, she felt like the best option to play as, offering staggers and movement options on top of sustain. This brings me to the next point that combat is incredibly boring and stagnant. You get your human enemies who usually die in one or two shots; the vampires are bullet sponges. The special vampires aren't really stronger than the regular ones, just more annoying. And the weapons felt kinda... eh.

The story, once again, fell completely flat.

All in all, I can imagine this game being more fun with a duo, not because the combat becomes more fun or anything, but simply because you have something to actually do while you get your 15th "go here, kill bad guy, come back" quest.

To recommend, or not to recommend?
I think two things killed the goodwill this game may have otherwise received:

1 - The price. At $70, it's a hard no. At $20 - $30, it's fine.

2 - It was basically marketed as "Dead Island with Vampires instead of zombies." I.e. a co-op shooter for up to 4 players, with quests and different characters with individual skill trees.
Had they marketed it as "a single-player experience with some broken co-op elements" (i.e. "Far Cry"), people would have known what to expect.

As Vampire Far Cry, I enjoyed it immensely -- the core loop is spot on. The guns feel good, and each type feels necessary. This isn't a "one gun fits all" game where you find your favourite gun and then never shoot anything else; it's a game where all types (sniper rifle, AR, shotgun, and yes, stake launcher and UV gun) feel like useful arrows to come out of the quiver depending on the situation -- and not begrudgingly, either. Almost all buildings can be scaled, at least by the two characters with powerjump / teleport skills, enabling dynamic escapes and a lot of sniping from the rooftops, and both stealthy methodical and "guns blazing" approaches.

Redfall suffers from many odd decisions -- the characters look ugly, the cut scenes are slide shows, and friendly NPCs receive very little writing or flavour lines. There are two very unnecessary points of no return -- once in the second map, you cannot return to the starter area, and after completing the main quest, you are evicted from the open world altogether (perchance to return in New Game+). Like the writing of the allies, the story is somewhat basic (and the latter may also have worked better had they picked one of "sciencey vampires" and "fantasy vampires", rather than mixing the two). Perhaps this is intentional, to keep you in the fight rather than in the hub, and as such, it works.
On the plus side, this also means we're not bothered with yet another crafting system, and there never is any real inventory pressure. Additionally, once you know what you like, there is no lengthy deliberation which guns to sell and which to keep. For once, we spend our time playing, rather than running chores!

I can't speak to the co-op experience; there is no match-making, and the reddit groups and discord servers I found seem inactive by now (Dec 2023). The whole "progress only registers for the session host" thing sounds incredibly broken regardless.

Addendum: Played on Linux, zero issues.

Verdict

If you're looking for a co-op experience, skip.
If single-player "Vampire Far Cry" sounds good and you can pick it up for about $25, give it a go.

I resisted the urge to buy it on day one, later purchased it at a discount, and played it after update 3. 
The story is like Deadloop: fringe scientists become godlike beings that dispose of hordes of cultists. 
The main loop is straightforward: kill countless enemies, loot everything not anchored to the floor, gain experience, level up, repeat.

The game isn't terrible at this point (I wouldn't recommend buying it at full price), but it lacks content and gameplay variety. 
I really liked the aesthetics and enjoyed the story. It's not the most original story out there, but it's still good enough to keep you playing.

Redfall is, for all intents and purposes, a game without a purpose designed by committee. It is hard to believe anyone had any creative vision that was poured into this playable nothingness.

Its threadbare story serves only to connect playable point A to point B. It has little dramatic arc, as its main characters are not personally invested in what's happening, even though voice acting might melodramatically try to convince one otherwise, as a character's voice cracks while describing events that could pretend to rattle a bleeding heart teenager. The truth is that playable characters have only the barest of connections to the game's plot: they stand to gain nothing, are there out of literal obligation, and do not change or explore any aspects of their personality through the course of the game. Secondary characters, though more involved in the town's tribulations, are too absent to develop anything but suggestions of a personality, and, compelling as some of these might be, they are given so little breathing room that they, more often than not, amount to nothing.

When one is out in the world, they might run into enemy humans or vampires: humans pose little to no challenge, as most die with one or two shots to the head, and do not move around enough to make this task difficult. Vampires have more resilience, and have to be finished off either with a stake, fire, lightning, or UV lights. Most will try to rush the player, and can deal decent damage up-close, making encounters with them a little more engaging once they come in larger numbers. There are a few special types of vampires, but these rarely force the player to change their tactics around, safe for one who creates an area of limited visibility around the player, and tries to flee while throwing projectiles, forcing the player to switch roles and give chase, and one who has rotating shields, forcing the player to be more precise in aiming, lest they waste their (frankly abundant) resources.

These encounters run out of steam rather fast, as the game fails to throw any further curveballs down the line, and encounters increasingly become annoyances that serve only to interrupt the pace. The other side of the game is exploration, but the game very much discourages it. The only thing of value to find in its world are safehouses and historical markers, both of which are already marked on the player's map, so they might make a  beeline for them immediately. Once a mission is started, it, too, is marked on your map and one is given very little reason to take any detours. 

The only thing one might find in active exploration is ammunition and healthpacks, both of which can be replenished at one of the safehouses that dot the map anyway for very little in exchange, dry notes left behind by the unseen inhabitants of Redfall that fail to either add texture or suggest a sense of loss, or guns than more often than not are worse than anything you might be carrying. Should one try to ignore markers and objectives, they will find themselves at a loss, since there is very little visually distinct about Redfall that might orient the player to anything interesting, and objectives sometimes give so little direction, that one is forced to rely on markers anyway.

I can think of very few reasons to play Redfall. It adds nothing to anything, everything it does, others do better. It serves only to spend (or more accurately, waste) time, it has nothing to say for itself, nothing distinct about its story, gameplay, or visuals. One would be correct in thinking fixing the bugs or developing content for this playable bread sandwitch to be a waste of effort, money, and time.

Cant be that bad comming from Bethesda RIGHT.  Anyway ill find out one way.

Even after the much belated 1.03 update Redfall is still utterly pointless.  The AI is braindead, the missions are uninspired and boring, the open world is virtually empty of anything actually happening, the player characters are dull, the "cutscenes" are laughable and ultimately the game is plain bad.  This is a title where every single narrative point is delivered either by still images using the in the game render or artwork.  Echoes of the past are narrative dumps that are also barely animated with the characters being made of glowing circulatory systems awkwardly moving.  The problem during these scenes is that you don't know who is who and worse some of them have to play to completion before allowing progress to the next area, and these can last a few minutes at times so strap in folks.

The world I found was quite good from a visual design perspective, I knew what area I was in from the look of the surroundings easy enough and each area had its own unique style.  The massive downside is the near complete lack of any kind of life in the map.  It has no dynamic events or wandering enemy parties to encounter for instance or special events.  Most if not all of the games enemies are locked to their spawns and will only react when engaged meaning you can easily pick them off one by one from a distance and sometimes not even receive return fire.

Opening up safe houses is supposed to be a way to represent your push back against the vamps but it doesn't really visually do much.  Outside of adding some homeless people to the safe house it is hard to see that you have secured the territory.  Safe house gameplay works in exactly the same way each time.  Go to location and shoot cultists.  Congrats you now have access to a shop that sells lock picks and hacking devices.  Next step, defeat the vampire underboss.  Sounds cool but what does that entail?  Go to location and shoot cultists with a vampire at the end bish bash bosh you have secured the territory.  Not that you will notice since cultists and vampires will still roam the area regardless and the good people of Redfall will still hide in the safe house.

Enemy variety is pish poor as well.  Human cultist enemies come in the single variety of gun toting lobotomy patient who have zero awareness of their environment.  They worship different vampire gods but they have no variation between them.  So the bloody tom cultists and miss whisper cultists just have slightly different masks and no other distinguishing element to them.  Bellweather mercenaries are much the same outside of one deploying a turret.  Human foes are just terrible and have no challenge to them at all.  Vampires are pretty bad as well since your normal vamps just run at you and slash forwards.  Sidestepping can easily defeat a creature of the night and they do little else of note before being staked.  The three other vampires in the form of the shroud, siphon and angler all at least do something different during combat.  Shrouds produce darkness that forces you into a haze that obscures them until you get closer allowing her and her minions to hit you more.  Siphons steal health during combat and anglers can grab you and bite you for big damage.

The big downside of these three is that they are all pretty formulaic despite the different abilities they use and hilariously all of them can be killed instantly with a stake launcher to any part of their body.  They are supposed to drop loot upon defeat but nearly always drop wedding rings which are just currency items and when they do drop guns they tend to be of the low quality type so fighting them just becomes as perfunctory as the regular vampires sadly.  It is a shame here because these three show Arkane Austin had some good ideas for these enemies but they just become another regular enemy to thrash your way through.


Technically it works in as much as it won't crash to desktop or have severe performance issues but so does desert bus and you don't see droves of people running off to play that.  I know Redfall had little support during development and I feel for the team who knew they were making a digital stinker of a product but it doesn't excuse the end product.  The bugs are funny to witness like Vampires getting stuck on the environment and still yacking at you about how superior they are.  Human enemies will pop into existence ahead of you and then begin to patrol a five foot square before you kill them.  I stumbled across numerous captives who were being held by literally no one but they kept spouting lines about rescuing them from their captors and look out for the cultists.  Freeing them does nothing by the way, they just run off and you get very little if any reward.  Animations even get the stinkier end of the stick with some weapons like sniper rifles that have hovering magazines that float into the gun while you use the force to load them.  

Enemies in buildings will be completely oblivious to your run and gunning if they are on the second floor while you stake and gun down their buddies downstairs.  It completely undermines the atmosphere because the enemies are so dense.  The bosses are crap to fight.  They are built up with names like "Miss Whisper" and "Bloody Tom" but the fights just end up being a bullet sponge boss with extremely basic attack patterns in arena's that have abundant resources to keep you armed and healthy so there is zero threat or chance of failure.

This is meant to be a looter shooter in the same vein as games like Borderlands but enemies drop very rarely and when they do the weapons are always low tier trash you won't keep and just end up buying better quality stuff from the base vendor.  You only get the really good stuff from the supposedly dreaded Rook enemy.  After you kill enough vampires the Rook will eventually appear and then rush you like any other random vamp.  He has zero unique abilities or skills outside of being able to teleport away briefly which always has him just popping back in to run at you more.  Killing him will nearly always reward you with a gold quality unique weapon and these are the best guns in the game.  

Nests are supposed to be where you go for the real challenge and potential loot bonanza but they are just tepid rehashed areas of the map stitched together to form basic procedural levels.  Vampires can be completely ignored in these as you speedrun to the finish, break out the trapped souls who maintain the nest and then gobble up loot before it collapses.  After clearing about ten of these nests not a single gold dropped.  It doesn't help that when you do get the chance to loot hoover the nest has roughly sixty seconds before it closes giving you barely anytime to find all the loot drops.

Oh the guns also suck in visual variety as well.  You will see the same rifle, shotgun, pistol and SMG just with slightly different names as you play but honestly the number of "Grackle" pistols you discover will fast become old.  At least other looter games will have a lot of loot to collect and it be distinct enough to be interesting to look at, this game cycles at a guess from my time playing from start to finish around a dozen common models for the weapons.  Special weapons like flare guns, UV beam emitters and stake launchers are all the same model and have either limited ammo or feck all damage that you will ignore most of them to carry an extra shotgun or rifle to have quick access to a bayonet for quicker stabbage of vampires.

Overall Redfall is not worth buying, not even on a massive discount.  Cooperative doesn't help alleviate the issues at all other than to share the pain with someone.  The best thing I can say about the game is that it has a nice shade of red for the title and you could maybe gift it to someone you really dislike.

Good and fun game to play and chill after work day (in Solo and Multi). If devs will add multiplayer matchmaking lobby option and fix some small bugs like unsaving progress multiplayer bugged lobby(rare), add more enemies spawn in second map then the game will be great.

Ignore the recent reviews, this game is definitely still very, very terrible. I beat it after 11 hours, and see from the achievement I got that only 9% of people did as well. Only 25% of people even beat the first boss! And these are the people that were interested enough to actually *pay money* for this thing, not the people that just gave it a go on the subscription service!

It is definitely up there with like, "The Quiet Man" as one of the worst games I've ever played. Though like that game it's SO bad that it does kind of loop back around to being sort of fascinating - how is it even possible that a game that had half a decade to cook, from a studio that was so good, end up like this?

This is a $20.00 game originally sold in broken condition for $70.00. 

If it had been sold at $20.00 on release, and had not been full of goofy bugs and graphics glitches and all the features had worked, it would have been a solid but forgettable open world action game you could waste time on with your friends. Sadly, none of that happened. Instead it gets judged as an AAA game because that is how they chose to price it, and if you pay full price for an AAA title you expect a level of polish that Redfall in NO WAY delivered on release, and doesn't really deliver even now. Releasing it when they did, and how they did, at the price they did, was a massive mistake on somebody's part somewhere up the corporate ladder, and I hope they at least realize how dumb they were.

If you can get the game for less than 20 bucks, and you like open world looter shooters with mostly boring loot and average shooting (and a pretty small open world, considering) than sure, pick it up I guess. If it's more than $20.00, that's a hard pass. Even being largely bug free at this point (half a year later) it's STILL not worth more than that.

I've had a great time with this game so far, now >20 hours of playtime.  In retrospect and despite the significant number of negative reviews, the purchase was a no-brainer at the sales price. I'd argue it would also be worth it at the full price, budget permitting.

Lots of jump scares, a diversity of weapons and enemies, a pretty cool skill set and progression, a robust city to explore (and I've not yet opened the larger map), and so on.

On normal difficulty at least, you thankfully don't lose everything on your multitude of deaths and some degree of your mission progress is preserved (although human NPCs repopulate the area of operation once you respawn and return). It's no "Jogging Simulator 2.0" (see e.g., un-modded Arma 2 and 3)  thanks to a number of fast travel locations you can open up as you progress.  Lots of looting, killing and achieving opportunities.

Again, well worth the money in my view and based on my gaming preferences and budget . . . even if not on sale.
they have fixed almost everything that was wrong with the game at launch. i would highly recommend this game, but sometimes the enemy damage can be whack.

I'm about a third or so way through the game (from what I gathered). Redfall isn't by any means a great game, but I have still been enjoying it. The concept and story is interesting. The gunplay is fun, although not too in-depth. I think exploring is better than some open world games. Not that there are a ton of sidequests or ambient things going on in the world, but the world at least isn't so huge that you feel like you're wasting time just getting from point A to B, something that seems to be a problem with some recent open world games. So I appreciate the developers keeping the open world more concise and to scale with the amount of content.

Performance-wise I haven't had any issues. It's been running pretty smoothly on both my 3080 and 3060-Mobile. Which is welcome considering how poorly optimized many new releases have been.

I didn't play the game when it came out, the third major patch was released when I did. It sounds like it was a lot more buggy and less optimized when it released, so I never had to deal with that. I bought it on heavy discount at 75% off. I didn't have high expectations going in due to all the negative press and reviews. All of those which I am sure influenced my expectations going in verses someone who paid 70 or 100 USD on launch.

While I enjoy the game in general for what it is, there are still some areas that could be improved or added to greatly improve the game in my opinion with potential future patches or content updates.

 - Improve the enemy AI. It's... serviceable, but  feels pretty basic and unintelligent for a modern game. Sometimes the AI is alright, but it feels like most of the human enemies mostly will just move and shoot in one place at you. Enemies sometimes get stuck behind walls or act reckless to the point where it seems like they are just suicidal. The vampire enemies are a bit more engaging, but still seem like they need some work. I think the game tries to offset some of the shortcoming of the AI with having them do more damage to you, so you can easily die if you are reckless or aren't paying attention, but the AI is still often questionable enough that it's noticeable.

- Better develop solo play: 

This game should be able to played offline if you are playing solo. Being able to play offline would make this game a lot more attractive to Steam Deck owners and people interested in Modding. 

Also, allow manual saves, pausing, more tweaks to the difficulty. Make the game more open and easy to mod. I think these may give the game a bit more replayability and more of a better experience if you play the game solo. If the game was as flexible and open as a Bethesda-developed game I can see potential there. (Bethesda was the publisher of this game, not the developer)

- Make more ambient quests and activities, and more side quests and lore. I think the game has an interesting setting and more stories and things happening in the world could help show that.

- It'd be nice if there were ways to manually upgrade or mod your weapons, instead of having to just scrap them after leveling up a bit. Adding modification may be a bit much at this point, but maybe add a way to upgrade a weapon's level, even if it is expensive.

- [spoiler] Ability to go back to the first map after the point of no return shortly after defeating the Hollow Man [/spoiler]

- Add melee weapons

- Allow the player to assign more than one keyboard or mouse button to an action. Such as the bash key - It'd be nice if I can have it assigned as a keyboard key and a mouse key. Currently it's just one or the other.

Overall Redfall seems like it has the beginnings of a good and interesting game, but was released too early. Another year of polish and rounding out of content and gameplay features and AI would have helped a lot and probably would have delivered a good game. At this point Redfall I think is playable and enjoyable enough (to me), but it does feel pretty mid and like a lot of wasted potential. It would be cool to see some content releases that improve the game, but I find it hard to see Akane/Bethesda committing more  than they already promised considering the game doesn't appear to be selling well or have a lot of people playing it.

Overall: I wouldn't pick up the game for full price right now, but for a very good discount I think it's worth a try. I think it's much better than its reputation has been portrayed online at least, so I wouldn't judge the game just off that. I've played games that I've paid for that I feel were genuinely much worse; but that's me. It should have retailed for probably half the price. 

I'll see how the future Bite Back content and updates pan out before deciding if I want to get that.

I got this on a strong discount Nov 2023 - whatever issues this game might have had on launch day, what I played was very stable, smooth, performant and bug-free (game version was update 3).
I'd be satisfied with my purchase even if the discount was lower.

Pros (SOLO playthrough):
- Runs VERY well on my old 6-th gen Intel together with Nvidia 3080
- excellent, satisfying sound effects
- Good visual design and graphics
- Excelent, satisfying gunplay
- Many different playstyles available

Cons (SOLO playthrough):
- Forgetable plot and story
- Average music
- Mid-part of game is somewhat boring (some grinding)
- Didn't engage me sufficiently to consider additional play-throughs, for now.
- Unavoidable mechanisms of "Vampire Nests" as well as "Rook Storm" can become tedious
- Some balancing issues

Noteworthy if you are an Arkane fan - be aware that:
- Arkane games normally have excellent music - Redfall does not
- Arkane games do not excel at elaborate story-telling, but they normally have an excellent plot at their core - Redfall does not
- Some side missions appear quite lack-lustre - again, not something one is used to from other Arkane games.

I recommend Redfall if you can get it for 50 Euros or less.

I am so glad I didn't listen to anyone on the reviews for this game. I am absolutely loving it. The game is somewhat of a doom/borderlands/far cry mix for me. It's really what I kind of want in a game, it just needs to be a bit deeper.

+ Gunplay is fantastic
+ Leveling up and getting new loot is enjoyable.

+ Performance has been great. 120FPS, 4k Ultra with DLSS3 with a 4070ti.

Mid:
- Lack of crafting would make this game better.

- Wish there were bases you could setup better with users.

Cons:

Overall I am enjoying the hell out of this game and incredibly happy that I played it. I am going to complete it within the next few days. Really glad I got it. Shame that there likely won't be a sequel as it could really build on some misses from this.

I got this game on a 75% off sale, so I'm going to rate this positive with a big caveat: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FULL PRICE.

This is not a AAA game, it's a rough jankfest from an inexperienced team. It has all the hallmarks of a budget title, slideshows instead of cinematics, dated graphics, bad NPC models, etc. 

However -- if you buy this game for what it's worth, which is about $30aud, it's somewhat decent. $30 means you can kind of forgive the irritating wokeness, the bugs, and the nonexistent AI. The cartoony style can be charming, the environments are often very interesting, and the badly written characters can be ignored. Surprisingly, it's not soulless trash. 

If you didn't hate games like Back 4 Blood or Generation Zero, you probably won't hate this. It's worth playing with a friend or two if you can get it for the price they should have been charging for it, instead of the insane $120aud non-sale price they're asking.

The story is what you would expect from a boring co-op game. There is one, low effort and bare minimum. 
The character models all have stunted growth and acromegaly.
The guns feel alright and are pretty accurate, the scaling is way off though. Too often you go from one-shotting everything to not dealing any damage. The sniper constantly sways for some reason. Instead of recoil guns (apart from the sniper rifle) don`t deal any damage at longer ranges.
The AI is fucking retarded.
The human enemies run up to you in a straight line and die way too easily. The vampire enemies just rush you relentlessly until their pathfinding breaks.
If you want to buy/unlock/hack/salvage anything or save survivors you have to hold "E" for an abhorrent amount of time.
If you are playing with a mate, get ready for them to constantly be T-posing and bobbing in the ground. For some reason your mate has a shadow, but you don`t. The connection was stable at least in my experience.
The missions can be completed super quickly and the game often feels like a walking simulator. There are barely any enemies for one person, so sometimes you don`t even get to shoot anything.
The graphic settings are useless. The game looks and runs like shit regardless of what you pick. I had screen tearing issues and my mate had FPS drops, even though we have the same beefy setup. Textures looked mushy and washed out, especially at a distance. The low draw distance meant enemies sometimes just disappeared out of view. 

Even after half a year this game is still an unfunny joke.
The heads of Arkane Austin should be ashamed. I would rather be known as the village idiot than be associated with such a dogshit travesty.

After giving Redfall another chance with recent patch. I can confirm this game still has major game breaking bug issues.

I was playing with a friend as host for a substantial amount of hours. Next day we both logged in to resume game and found out none of our progress in levels and equipment had saved for him. Meaning he was 7 levels below me. Making continuation in co op impossible.

This is a well documented bug after searching google. And yet Arkane still has not addressed this major game breaking bug and instead focuses on basic game play improvements.

After this we have completely abandoned giving Arkane a second chance to redeem themselves. Game is uninstalled and abandoned.

Do Not Buy This Game!

I approached Redfall with high hopes, fueled by my love for vampires, open-world games, and looter shooters. Unfortunately, this game turned out to be a crushing disappointment, and no amount of patches can salvage its core issues.

Redfall is plagued by a lack of basic features that are essential for any video game. The narrative is virtually non-existent. It fails to deliver on the promise of an immersive experience in every way possible.

While the gunplay manages to be enjoyable and responsive, the overall gaming experience is marred by poorly executed combat encounters. The AI, in particular, is the worst AI I have ever experienced in my life, in a video game. Constant glitches, awkward t-poses, erratic behavior and other bugs are not even the main issue. The main issue is core programming of the AI. The coding is uninspired and lazy, showcasing a lack of imagination and a fundamental misunderstanding of what makes games truly enjoyable.

Even if the developers miraculously fix the AI issues, fill the game with content, and make it feature-complete, Redfall would still a below average gaming experience. It falls short of the entertainment value expected from games, turning each session into a laborious task that made me feel bored, frustrated, and ultimately disappointed.

Even at a discounted price, Redfall makes me feel like I got ripped-off. The game fails to fulfill its primary purpose ‚Äì providing entertainment. The initial excitement fades quickly, transforming every gaming session into a disheartening experience.

Save yourselves the money, there are plenty of good games out there. Unfortunately, Redfall will never be one of them.

I think Redfall is bloody good (for $15)! Get it now while its on sale!

Just to be clear, its not great, its not nearly as good as Prey, Wolfenstein etc, but its the most fun "post apocalyptic survival fps" Ive played, and at ~$15 its great value.

Basically its an open world vampire/military first person action RPG. Guns feel pretty good to shoot, enemy AI is a bit dumb but its OK enough to have fun, you can scavenge a bunch of stuff - what more do people want?! (Oh wait, after playing a bit more, I have more on this later).

Music is fine, as is the voice acting, character models, animation, etc - it would obviously be better if this was all outstanding, but oh well.

It very much has an Arkane game feel (think Dishonoured2) - but not as good as their normal stuff.

3 weapons to hotkey between isnt enough - 5 would be good, and 10 even better. Im using a keyboard Arkane!

You cant return to areas after moving onto the next area? And There are gravelocks (secret-ish collectibles) to collect? Wow, that design decision sucks.

PS - Im playing solo, but playing with some friends would be even more fun.

I might be a complete dummy, but I dont know how to host a game with random people dropping in... this is a thing right? OMG, no its not. OK, so this is why Redfall flopped! Its a perfectly fine single player FPS action RPG (at a $15 price point), not as good as Arkanes previous games, but its OK. It requires an always online connection, and you cant pause the game which is obviously complete faeces. But thats because its not really supposed to be a single player game right, its supposed to be an open world action RPG version of left for dead. But There isnt the ability to team up with random ppl, you need to host a game, invite friends (friends only?!) then and there as there is no drop-in drop-out functionality - so as a multiplayer coop game its completely nerfed and has zero chance of being successful.  Arkane should work to add in 1/ the ability to team up with random people, and 2/ drop in, drop out, this is the critical functionality they need to have so this stands a chance of success (see Generation Zero for a comparison).

Edit: I think Ive figured out what may make people think this game is jank, and thats the music in the fire station/hideouts - it is *complete* jank, this carefree piano and hip hop tune that says "you dont have a care in the world and everything is even kinda cool". It completely sets the wrong mood, and subconsciously contaminates the rest of the game. I dont recall hearing any good music yet either (and never ever discount how important music is for setting the feel of a game), so I will shortly turn off the music entirely, and listen to something which I think would suit better.

Edit2: Im got to area 2, and ennui set in. Im bored. I dont think I'll continue this unless it becomes more fun to play. Could be more fun if they make it into a decent SP game. Could be more fun if it gets drop in MP. As it is, Ive had enough.

Got this in the sale and at a price tag of about 15 bucks this is a fairly enjoyable experience. The gameplay loop is fun and it is sort of a blend between your typical Ubisoft sandbox and Borderlands. Which means for my own personal taste it tends to lean on the whacky / non-sensical parts a little bit too much but it's not overt enough to drive one away. 

That aside, I would be probably a lot more unhappy with the game if I had paid full box price for it. At its best moments its heated, adrenaline pumping combat, at it's worst it hits you with samey levels, samey enemies and a poorly delivered punchline that you've heard three combats prior before. 

Redfall is a fun experience to play in coop across a day or two but its not much more than that. So my overall score leans towards a recommendation but only just barely and given you get it at a steep discount.

Even at $20 AUD, which I paid, it's just not a good game. The AI is braindead, but to make up for it can kill you in only a few hits. ADS forces a 50% reduction, with no setting to change it. The world is lifeless, which even Back 4 Blood didn't have the same issue. The main reason I bought the game was because I like vampires, and the enemies don't even feel like vampires.

Do not waste your time and money on this game like I have.

It's all right - although on a 2060 I had to drop those graphics settings to lose the frame rate freeze. On a 4060 with 32GB of RAM it's as smooth as butter. Offing a vampire with a shotgun to the face followed up by  a stake to the heart can make you feel like a regular little Buffy. Poking around the town of Redfall is good fun although despite it being populated by the undead it can feel a little lifeless (!). 

The tone is mixed, and this can break the immersion. Your out of place character quips grate - and the AI for the cultist/soldier enemies is so shaky its like shooting fish in a barrel. If the devs had sharpened up the ai more and leaned into the horror this could have been something special.

It's ok solo, probably more fun with others - assuming of course you can convince anyone else to play it.

This is not Arkanes' best work (actually it's at the bottom of pile). Get it on sale, ignore the 'bite back' upgrade, and pretend Arkane didn't make it - then it doesn't feel quite as bad. Personally I like the scenario of wandering through an open world reclaiming it from an army of bloodthirsty vampires. And I have a fondness for below average games. This is definitely that - and I still find it a lot of fun.

In a nutshell: as a game this game really sucks.

A short distance from the firehouse I ended up fighting about 5 vampires as a level 2 character with appropriate weapons for my level. I only lasted a short time. A group probably could have handled them but a low-level solo player it was impossible. 

You must complete a quest or you have to redo it. I really hate games which do not allow me to save on the fly but this is the worst. It is basically complete or redo no in-between.

I cannot recommend this game to anyone.

Redfall is a pretty good Vampire game.

+Graphics(it looks good but in some places you say it is more old gen than next gen)
+Gameplay(easy to learn, the mechanics are the same as all the FPS that appeared on the market recently)
+Story(the story is quite interesting for a game of this kind, it is not AAA but it does its job to be told)
+Atmosphere(it gives you the feeling that you are in a movie with Vampires)
+Open World(you have quite a big map to explore and enough activities to do)
+Vampires
+CO-OP(if you have friends, if not, you can play quietly and SOLO without problems)

Redfall is an interesting game with Vampires that suddenly becomes a Looter shooter but in a good way if you have played Borderlands then you know what to expect overall Redfall also offers a good experience.

9/10 Must Play! I recommend at a discount.
Crapfall

Before we begin, know that updates have been coming infrequently, but they have been coming, and they do add a lot to improve the experience.
Though, I don't think this game is worth 70 bucks. Wait for a sale. Sometimes it's on sale for more than half off.

So let's get the cons out of the way first:
- Visual story telling isn't that interesting so far. Arkane is fantastic at story-telling in their environments and notes. And this game does have moments of decent visual story telling. But most of it so far is a mostly un-touched looking town with notes where most of them don't say much interesting.
- Not a lot of creativity in gameplay. Arkane has always encouraged different approaches in their levels, combat, and stealth, for maximum creativity and experimentation/discovery. But due to the multiple characters and open world, your abilities aren't that wide in variety, and the levels aren't that tight in design compared to their other titles.
- Vampires are a mixed bag when fighting. On one hand, they're dangerous and cool looking. On the other, they have lunges I can't seem to dodge, and they swarm around you up close, so it's not easy to handle more than two in a not-fun way. Maybe that'll get better as I get more skills and better gear. And they don't leave during the day too (for explained reasons).

Now for the pros:
- Fantastic atmosphere and setting. Despite the lack of story-telling in the untouched looking town, it helps make it look pretty and has a nice small town feel to its setting and atmospheric direction, and just has a lot of personality in general. Helps you imagine living a life there before its recent disaster. Kinda like Everybody's gone to Rapture, just Halloween. And that's not even considering the crazy visuals in the environmental/level art during the story.
- VERY satisfying gunplay. Although abilities are more limited compared to previous titles, the feedback in the sound and reaction for shooting enemies always feels GOOD!
- Unique approach for an Akrane game. You could definitely tell they were warming up to something like this with the invasion mechanic in Deathloop (a really good game, btw!) But this is a full 4-player co-op, open world. I've only played solo, and the open world stuff isn't as tight or well designed as their previous games. But you can definitely see effort into make these maps fun to explore and loot. Just not so much into making them have all sorts of different ways to handle level design in locations, with a few exceptions.

The game is now GOOD and really playable, after 3d update and past half a year, its not difficult but fights are tense now, you have to use 1-3 weapons to defeat sertain enemys, minibosses and else, as long as your abilities and ult (at realease the AI was very weak and now it is better, espicially vampires, its hard to shoot em without the UV lamp and other staff. 
There r now bad technical or gameplay bugs now, they all r fixed, The game runs very smooth (144fps without DLSS) on 4k (but i use top end PC)
 P.S. Dont try to play it like other Arkane games, its not stealth game but its immersive and can be (should?) played solo for tense and immersive experince!
(played it on gamepass also) Does not deserve all the hate its getting. pretty fun i think.

The game wont run on new specs "PC's" i had an older PC where i did play Redfall on back last year, this year "2025" i got a new PC and installed the game to play it again, its on a never ending loading screen and wont run, i then tryed my old PC and it works fine there, i then googles and seached up on it and for some reason the game wont run if you never had it installed before, if you had it installed before May 2025 you should be fine, but it wont work on new PC's that never had it installed, so do not buy this game, you cant even get a refund any more.

This game does not deserve all of the poor ratings it is getting. Pretty much open world where you can run and gun as you please. Silky movement and the weapons are great. Graphics are awesome and the maps are very good too. 

Admittedly there are issues that have come to light playing further into the game. Its far from perfect but there are a lot of good things in this game too. 

The main problem that I see is that the guns and skills do not adequately reward you to be able to deal with the tougher enemies that follow. Also the combat movements when under severe attacks are somewhat clunky and very slow, when enemies are numerous and some lightening fast.

This game was never intended to be an easy walk in the park, but as I see it there are some serious balance issues here. 

However, I cannot fathom why people are not happy with this. Certainly at full price not so hot but definitely worth it on sale, absolute.

So... I enjoyed this game, actually. It's got some glitches still. Some bugs. I started it several months after it came out so I was hoping it'd clear up a few of them... is it worth 70$? Nooo. Maaaaybe 50$ once they clear up the bugs. But my friend and I paid 70 for it and decided we'd co-op and get our moneys worth. We had a co-op bug right off the bat where if a person doesnt play it before co-oping and just joins your game their level and equipment progress is lost, which was... bad. But if you play a bit before joining another persons game that clears up. So, a little bumpy to start.

But once you get past a some of that its pretty impressive. The setting, the location... reminds me of The Secret World's first location. Sea side east coast stuff with utterly ruined residence with personality, the setting is awesome. The vampires are really creepy and you can hear them whispering and sneaking about, the solo playing and team plate are completely different experiences and it takes a while to really get used to the game. My friend and I have gotten jumped by too many vampires at once and died many a time and it was pretty fun because eventually we started -not- dying against them. And again, the location, the scenery, the graphics (Doctor Venture's voice actor snuck in there kind of surprised me and.. creeped me out a bit). Im still working through it with my friend and enjoying reading the little bits of lore, learning the rules of the vampires and how they got there and their backstories and just absolutely ruining them. Its an expereince. The character dialogue is entertaining and when you co-op they occasionally have exchanges and talk about stuff and make jokes.

Would recommend... maybe a bit later when its on sale, in a year, when perhaps they clean up a few more of the bugs too. But really rich game. Just one of the sort you should catch a year later after some effort got put into making it more sleak.

I'm a huge Arkane Studios fan. I got Redfall as soon as it came out, but....saw the reviews and decided to wait for an update. The update hath come, and while the game remains far from perfect, I'm still enjoying it.  My biggest beef is that it feels deeply imbalanced on solo play. Sometimes I'm hit with a bajillion vampires and I die right away. Other times, most of the city is empty.

Still, I AM really enjoying it, and I keep opening it up to play for 1-2 hours each day. It has VIBES and that's one of my favorite aspect of all Arkane Games: the vibes. I absolutely love the way they build their worlds.  Prey + Dishonored 2 + Deathloop are my top 5 games of all time. No, I've not yet encountered a mission with the mindblowing level design of Dishonored 2 or the absurd fun of Deathloop or the sheer terror of Prey...

But I keep playing Redfall and having a lot of fun. Plus, I'm genuinely hopeful that Arkane Studios really will keep adding to this and improving it. I love what they do; I know there was a lot crap behind the scenes that left this game falling short; as an author who exists at the whim of her publisher, I get it. Viscerally.

I was super wary opening this up a few weeks ago try, bracing for it to be terrible...but I've been not only pleasantly surprised, but outright entertained.

Lore is great, story...backstory all the context works. Only janks are similar to any game that is ported over to PC I.E. Menu is a bit strange at first and some of the key mapping is wonky. Reminds me of The Division actually combined with Far Cry..add Vampires. 

BUT...this is squarely a 30 dollar game. Arkane-Austin has put out Dishonored, Prey and Deathloop all great titles.

I played through the game once, reaching level 18 with 12 hours of gameplay. 
Performance was good after updating drivers and optimizing settings with GeForce Experience.
Annoyingly, FoV adjustments required manual editing.
The gameplay loop resembles Far Cry, minus vehicles.
Combat is similar to Doom with exploiting enemy weaknesses but less enjoyable.
Abilities felt like Overwatch that got better as you leveled them, but felt balanced.
Leveling is decent, though I only reached level 18 of 40.
Item management is swapping out weapons quickly lose power as you level, the world scales with you.

Overall, I think it's an enjoyable game. I won't be playing through it again though. I would recommend it if the price is right.

At time of writing this i have just over 10 hours on the game. i played this game when it first came out, i was hyped for it and was excited to play... but it was actual dog water. i payed 70$ for it and returned it after only around 30 min, as it was unplayable with frame rate issues and lagging while playing co-op. I was very disappointed, the game felt empty and just not finished. I saw that update 2 came out and wanted to give it a try to see if it was savable so I got it on sale... and I will tell you, this game is actually pretty fun now. I'm about half way done the game going for 100% and enjoying it quite a bit. Don't get me wrong the game still has issues but it is definitely much better and shouldn't get so much hate. 


Need to do with game:

Fix ai still - When sniping ai they stand around when one of them have been shot, they need to become more alert, actively take cover and search for you better.

Vampire nests - These are fine and all but they should be limited and not respawn as you destroy them, maybe keep one somewhere on the map after completing them all for replayability. Also why not throw a achievement in there for taking them all out.

Vampire combat - Vampires definitely feel much stronger then your normal enemy but sometimes they are just boring, they run at you, swing, sometimes teleport away, and repeat. definitely could use some improvements.

Weapons - There's definitely a lack of weapon variety with limited customization. modifying attachments, a gun store, etc, would be nice

Inventory - This isn't all to bad but an ability to lock some of your weapons so you don't get them mixed up with all the guns you just looted would help, there's times I scraped the wrong gun just to find out it was my best gun.

Skills - Skills are pretty decent with neat ability's but the leveling system feels slow, I'm level 13 after completing half the game and still need so many skill points. a few more skills would also be nice. like carrying capacity for med kits and even inventory space for guns.

Safe-houses - These are lacking heavily, run past enemy's, turn on a generator, repeat. a more outpost feel would be nice with them enclosed with walls or something. A more of a far cry outpost feel like having to eliminate all the enemy's would definitely add more to the game.

Trapped souls - This isn't a bad concept just a bit annoying. I've ran around the map and destroyed them all, and they just respawn, its quite annoying, making them disappear forever when they are destroyed would be good, and you could even add a achievement for it.

The fire station - This could have had a better execution with features like missions for upgrading the base, and even base defense mechanics just to add more replayability and excitement.

Overall as of the current state of them game i'd give it a solid 7.5/10 and worth around 45$. For what it is, its a valid game, I enjoy it a lot but it definitely could have been executed better and thats sad to see. I really hope a Redfall 2 comes out and it can be what Redfall was supposed to.

Honestly I don't understand the hate. I played it for free on gamepass just to see what was up and I actually enjoyed it so I bought it on steam. It may not be a game for everyone and thats fine but I don't see why it has so many negative reviews. Ive had a lot of fun just sneaking by or obliterating vampires and cultists. Its basically vampire dishonored. If you like the dishonored franchise give it a go. If you are unsure of spending the $70 try it on xbox gamepass. But dont let the reviews persuade you like I did at first.

Update: So since I finished it I figured i'd post an update. I still stand by what I said. I enjoyed the game. Throughout the entire game I never had a crash or any major bug. Occasionally the menu would glitch but swapping tabs fixed it. Could it use some more to the game overall? Absolutely, it was pretty repetitive but still had its fun. Could have used more story and missions.  Beat it in a little over 20 hours. Doing most missions (probably missed one or two side missions).

 The Vampire nests didnt really seem to have a point other than some chances at good loot and money and just something else to do, overall pretty underwhelming. They made a bubble in that area that made vamps stronger but they didnt serve a purpose otherwise and didnt effect the completion of the game. The little red gas bodies on the map seemed to randomly respawn so clearing them was kind of a waste of time imo. 

Downsides: Make sure you finish everything you want to do in Redfall before going to Burial Point because there is no backtracking that I found once you go to the next area. So if you miss anything you have to wait until the next play through. Also once you beat the game theres no "cleanup" for anything you missed. Thats the game and when you click play again it starts you over but you keep your weapons and all the gravelocks and stuff you found in your previous play through. 

Im not sure theres Gold snipers, stake guns, or UV lights because my entire plathrough I kept getting the same variety of guns so it does seem like its very limited on gold tier weapons which cant have their skin changed or stake changed which was kind of a bummer. The only way it seems to get gold guns is to hit the randomizer in the "gun shop" and hope for luck or kill the Rook which is like a mini boss that spawns after you kill enough vamps and always guarantees a gold weapon. Other than that I never saw a gold weapon from looting.

10May24 - Changing my review to negative since theres no hope on this game ever getting updates or fixed now that the studio was axed. There was a lot of potential here. just need more time and love to it imo. And chances that no offline mode coming means there wont be more playability once the servers get axed too. Its too bad. Was nice having a vampire fps game, something other than zombies for a change. So anyways dont waste your time since the company is gone now.

As an admirer of Arkane‚Äôs work, I decided to give their latest game a shot. I initially played it for an hour via Xbox Gamepass before purchasing it at a discounted price of 26 euros.

Having spent three hours in the game, I can confidently say that it has been an enjoyable experience so far. The storyline has piqued my curiosity, and the weapons pack a punch both in terms of feel and sound. The game‚Äôs textures are of superior quality, with VRAM usage hovering around 11+ GB at 4K FSR2 Quality. Even with maxed-out details and Reshade Pathtracing enabled, I‚Äôm getting a steady 50 fps, which is quite satisfactory for me.

I would advise potential players not to be swayed by the Steam reviews. They seem to have triggered a negative chain reaction, with many people blindly following the opinions of certain reviewers or YouTubers. I encourage you to try the game for yourself. It retains the signature Arkane DNA and offers an intriguing story.

My gaming rig consists of an AMD Ryzen 5800X, an AMD Radeon 6900XT, 32 GB RAM, and a Samsung 990 Pro.

Update: After spending more time with the game, my appreciation for it has only grown. The game clearly bears the Arkane stamp, and the attention to detail in various locations is evident. The AI could use some improvement, especially in terms of situational awareness, but it does pose a challenge when faced with multiple enemies. After 33 hours of gameplay, I‚Äôm nearing the end, although the game does feel a bit stretched out.

Final Verdict: Having completed the game, I can say that I enjoyed it. While it may not be Arkane‚Äôs finest work, it was a worthwhile experience. I would rate it a solid 6.5/10.

The good: Overall game with potential, somewhat unique mechanics, solid writing and a nice art-style. With a simple sandbox, and unique setting. It definitely has the base design to be something good.
Had some good fun for a few hours using some we-mod cheats, and playing it more as a sandbox than a real game.


The bad: Unfortunately its not finished and not good for actual game-play. Completely destroyed by its clear lack of passion, polish, and even finish.
This game is unfinished, missing animations and textures, bugs, broken areas, invisible enemies, fire and explosives with irrational radius, few quests, mostly fake and copied structures, small overall map, non-narrative campaign for the most part, little to no inventory management, boring guns, no customization past a few basic skins, no deep collectors item, no worthwhile loot rarity system for exploring harder areas, and literally every other possible bug that comes with a game that has no soul or purpose to exist.

This game appears to have been launched in a pre-alpha state.
And as of this week, the studio is shutdown and the game is 100% dead.
