I don't see what all of the negative hype is about this game.  

It's an incredibly fun co-op shooter that feels like Far Cry or The Division. The vampires are very well done and have caused me to jump MULTIPLE times when I'm coming around a corner or up a set of stairs. (My favorite was literally walking up a set of stairs and seeing the legs of a vampire, who was just sitting at the top waiting for me.)  The battles are balanced, the weapons are great, but the sound really makes this stand out.  Grab your best pair of headphones and tap them up a notch.

The world is wonderful - climb to the top of the lighthouse and look around.  That's just an amazing view.  The missions are great. Go back and play Far Cry 4 - it's right in line with that.

Issues?  Sure - every new game has some issues.  I was able to play Redfall just fine from Day 1.  And it's continuing to get better.

Do yourself a favor, look past the negative reviews, and go enjoy this game.

Overall it's a well balanced FPS; I have enjoying playing it this far. The map is big enough with a lot of opportunities for exploration in between quests.

There are two things that I don't like:
1) The limitation of weapons one can use; it's 3. It's not enough; it should be at least 4.
2) You can't save and if you die you return to the closest base.

Alright, I've been patient enough. After having waited for over 4 months for Arkane to work on this game, I'm seriously extremely disappointed. We only got 3 updates, 2 of which were "hot fixes" and 1 of which was a "Regular Update". This first "Regular Update" was released 3 months ago. The updates have helped a bit but not nearly enough to say this game has no issues or even remotely playable.

There has been NO communication whatsoever from Arkane, they still tweet somewhat regularly but it's all stuff like "Bribon deserves all the pets." and absolutely NOTHING regarding the state of the game, no road map, just nothing. 
Will they ever actually fix Redfall? Honestly, I seriously doubt it at this point, wouldn't be surprised if they just completely abandon this game without a word if they haven't already.
I hate to say this because I actually like most of Arkane's games, but I lost all trust in them. It wouldn't even be that bad if they actually communicated but of course we're left in the dark.


Edit: Got another "Regular update" today (6 October, 2023), yes still the same year miraculously, 15 GB and apparently lots of improvements. I'll update the game and update the review later on.

Yes, so far this will mostly be about the optimization of the game because honestly, fuck everything else if you can't even run the game properly, then who cares about what is being added?

Alright so I played for like half an hour so far, these are first impressions after the update so take it with a grain of salt. So far the game is definitely better optimized, still having a couple decently big frame drops here and there in the cities, sometimes during fights, but only for like a second. Out of cities I have around 90 - 100 FPS, in cities around 60 - 80, in fights around 60 - 75. Sometimes my FPS dips down to 50, the worst dip I had was 24 but only for a split second.
I don't have the best PC but definitely not the worst, here are my specs for those who want to know so you have some sort of idea if this would run well for you (Graphic settings on High):

Motherboard: B550-A PRO
CPU: AMD Ryzen 7 5700X
GPU: AMD Radeon RX 6600
RAM: 32 GB G.Skill DDR4-3200

So far it's definitely looking better which I'm glad to say.
I'll keep playing more and I'll keep updating this review. Let's hope Arkane keeps updating the game but actually communicate, give us some sort of idea what is going to be added, ANYTHING. Besides that, good shit so far Arkane, better keep it up, but for fuck sake, once again, communicate with us.

5 November update: FPS has remained the same as mentioned above which is a really good thing obviously. There are some weird glitches in the game, for example:
When climbing a ladder you sometimes glitch out when reaching the top and you fall down.
There have been issues where half your character glitches through the floor and you rubberband with every step you take.

The NPCs are IMO still too easy, even on the "Midnight" (Hard) difficulty, very squishy. Yes this also counts for the big bad vampires.

19 November update: There are some really frustrating bugs with some of the characters. As Layla you sometimes will be stuck in the Umbrella animation and can't interact with anything or use any weapons. Jason (Layla's ult) sometimes just freezes which also causes her to not be able to do anything. Remi's robot, Bribon has probably the worst AI I've ever seen. Jacob sometimes pulls out his ghost sniper and it just disappears as if you didn't use the ult. Devinder seems to be the most polished character.

At the time of writing, this game is 4 months and a few days after release, and from a gameplay standpoint, this feels identical to the horrible state this game launched in. I'm not going to pretend I know the state of things at Arkane or who might still be working on this game, but this is a terrible blemish on a great year of releases that seemingly has no plans for support. 2-3 rounds of updates over the past 4 months has changed NOTHING about actually playing the game. Mind you, I'm only on High settings with DLSS enabled and the game has low frame-rate (30-50 fps) and multi-second long stutters at frequent intervals. Frankly, there's no excuse for the state of this game and still having it be publicly available. I'd love to see this game in a playable state, but I fear that may never happen.

I bought the deluxe edition off CD Keys for cheaper than the regular version on Steam. I have played through the game on 2 characters and here are my thoughts. The game has a solid premise and is "fun" but I cannot recommend it for the price or length of the game. If you can find it on a crazy good sale or have game pass and can play for free then give it a try, but don't have high expectations.

Pros:
- Difficulty does not effect achievements or in game drops (from what I can tell)
- Fun premise, think Borderlands and Resident Evil 4 had a vampire Psycho baby and let it run wild.
- The characters are all unique and their abilities make each one fun in their own way.
- A decent story that unfolds through a play through with added bits in "files" you can find and audio collectibles (gravelocks)
- Each character has a legendary weapon type specifically for them.

Cons:
- A multitude of glitches that have yet to be patched. From main story missions glitching on steps until you exit, change difficulty and reload (sometimes multiple times if the quest has several steps that can glitch), side quests showing up that you've already completed, environmental collision, poor enemy AI (even on harder difficulties), sound glitches that make alarms continue going off until you exit the game and reload, 
- Overall limited weapon selection. Few legendary weapons that are shared between all characters: 4 pistols, 4 shotguns, and 3 assault rifles. All other non legendary weapons have little variety and aren't far off from the legendary in stats
- No random match making, you have to have friends lists
- Must always be online to play even in single player
- Story is fairly short, you can play through the campaign on easiest difficulty in about 8-12 hours depending on if you want to explore some side quests (which are also limited)

This game had so much potential but sadly I doubt it will ever get fixed to the point it should have been at launch. Maybe we'll get another No Mans Sky rise to glory but I doubt it.

THIS GAME COULD HAVE BEEN SO GOOD. (TLDR below)

Especially the coop, my husband and I livestreamed this and thoroughly enjoyed the character dynamics (however limited because after the first half they just kept repeating the same dialogue content) the story was fairly good for the lack of care put into it and even hours of streaming later we never got to finish it because the final boss battle glitched three times in a row on different places and honestly we were so frustrated we called it quits and put the game to bed. It started out so great and then slowly got more glitchy as you progressed. I am so disappointed because of the completely wasted potential of this game. Allegedly, the people working on this didn't want to make it so didn't care? I have a harder time finding sympathy because like yeah working on something you don't like SUCKS but 90% of people do that everyday and this was your job? However I 100% admit that I have no foot in this race and no experience to speak of so what do I know?

TLDR:  Did we have fun playing it? YES. Would we recommend it? No. It's not worth getting your heart broken over.

It breaks my heart but where Deathloop wasn't for me yet I could recommend it to others I just can't recommend Redfall. There's nothing it does that you can't find done better elsewhere.

+Arkane stylised characters return, mostly work out. The animations are a little stiff, more noticeable on the vampires imo.

+The setting's interesting, who doesn't love vampires? Open world town to explore, the vibrant Arkane style also applies to the environment. There are a lot of interesting scenes to be found in the world that make you want to find out what happened there.

   

-The game commits the 2 cardinal sins of collectables: it doesn't track completed pickups on your map and the reward for collecting them is minuscule.

-Safehouse missions: If you accept a safehouse mission then quit before completion it doesn't stay in your log, you need to go back to the safehouse you picked it up from and restart it.

-Ammo counter bugs out and loses track of your ammo.

-Playing on a 4090, 7800X3D with 64gb DDR5 while most gameplay is smooth there are noticeable hitches when reaching denser regions with lots of environmental details or effect heavy scenes.

-While the game is open world the town is divided into 2 maps and once you enter the second you can't return to the first. I can't recall if there was a warning about this (in case you wanted to finish any side missions or collectables) but there is no reason you shouldn't be able to choose to go back to the first map.

-Arkane games aren't exactly cutscene reliant to my knowledge, mostly delivering story through in game dialogue, audiologs or written pieces. Redfall has written pieces but most of the significant story beats will be through cutscenes of still models or in-game memory echoes of still models. It's not terrible, the voice work is good, but it's not great.

-Lockpicks: There are a lot of locks to pick in this open world game but rather than being a skill, it just relies on consumable lockpicks which cap at 3 (for three out of four characters). Weapons can be found in every type of container so it seems you're never not going to want to open a container. You can buy more from safehouses/base but fast travel to and fro just to buy lockpicks breaks the flow of gameplay significantly. I guess this could be less of a thing when playing as a party, more lockpicks in total but for solo it's not good.

-Skills: Having set characters with set skill...sets detracts from the appealing thing about Arkane games imo. Their best game Prey 2017 is a masterclass in giving you a world to explore with clever level design that allows the player to overcome obstacles both with basic exploration and with their choice of skills; climb across pipes and vents to reach a drop ceiling, shapeshift into a coffee mug to fit through a gap, hack the lock, use strength to pry open a door. In Redfall one character has a translocate that allows you to bypass some obstacles, another has a leap ability that gives you some extra height. Every character has lockpicks and electronic bypass kits but not enough to allow you to interact freely; you might use your last pick on a door only to find the next room full of locked chests you now can't open without cutting your trip short for a supply run.
I don't see myself replaying Redfall but if I did, I don't think I'd play on a different character. Losing the translocate would render Redfall very mundane to me.

-The different weapon types each have uses but you can only equip 3 at a time. In a better Arkane game, you had a weapon/ability spiral so you could scroll through everything in your inventory and each ability.

-Characters with periodic background speech delivered through radios etc may continue to speak after killing them.

-There's an overall lack of polish in the world noticeable when items overlap (multiple item boxes in exactly the same spot, other item boxes placed so close they're half inside each other), inconsistent climbing mechanics (some waist high walls you can't climb and some you can, ledges you can't climb that you should be able to, ledges you climb but then slide off), barriers blocking pathing (an open path where you'll need to jump over an invisible obstacle).

-Enemies in general do not have great AI but some such as the Angler can do a lot of damage that seems excessive (casts a hook that grabs you, pulls you in, takes off something like 30-40% health and you are vulnerable to other enemies during all this). You'll also notice that normal vampire swipe attacks extend quite a bit further than their animation indicates.



To sum up, it's not a completely broken game. I found the world just interesting enough to finish the story, there's a lot of environmental storytelling and atmosphere is appealing. The story itself isn't groundbreaking but it's not bad. There are some ways in which you can find alternate paths, use abilities to find different approaches but very few in comparison to previous Arkane games. It is not the worst game ever made but it is probably the worst Arkane game ever made.
The story has a little room to be expanded and the Bite Back edition advertises there will be 2 extra characters coming but with how poorly Redfall has been received I'm not sure how much attention Arkane can afford to give it or if it would even help.

Redfall is ultimately a game that radiates quite a lot of fun. Finding loot and taking on the vampires is very entertaining, but it can be a tough job on your own and you are of course limited in your skills.
Each character only has two, plus another ultimate. The game therefore seems to have more of the co-op functionality, in which the four of you can use the strengths and weaknesses of each character and creatively eliminate the vampires.

Watch a snippet of gameplay here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JC0W9BJxWw8

Vampires are not the only threat.
Most of the islanders have joined cults, worshiping one of the great vampires in the hope that they won't be drained themselves.
And then the private military company Bellwether also shoots anything that moves.
Only at safe houses and a hub you will encounter friendly faces and you can buy weapons, health kits and other useful items.
Speaking of weapons, there is a lot of diversity.
You can expect common weapons such as pistols, shotguns and sniper rifles, but they all have their own rarity, perks and properties. Redfall also has a number of unique 'shooting irons', such as a stake launcher and UV beam.
Those last two are mainly for use against vampires, who appear as stronger opponents than the human foot soldiers.
When you have reduced their hit points to zero, you must finish it off with a wooden stake for the heart.

The game also works perfect on the steam deck: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VhwPQduMOpw

Vampires also have special powers. Think of teleportation, being able to drain life points and using a human as a shield, a bit funny though.
It is therefore wise to equip your loadout with weapons that are useful in different situations.
Fortunately, due to the great diversity of weapons, this is quite possible and it ensures that it remains fun to find loot in the game because it is not repeated so quickly.
In the beginning you will notice that as a player you are controlled fairly tightly.
You have not yet discovered much in the world, the side missions are not there yet and you have not yet found the safehouses with associated missions. This allows time and space to get to know the different skills and to absorb the lore that the world has to offer.

The game also has good support for ultra-wide resolutions: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eyPFkg5mdMo
Not worth it, not even for free.

Initial 4.5 hour assessment:

I love the spooky Halloween/ Harvest themed town, the vampires look pretty cool...and Boy is it satisfying to stake vampires! If only there were more ways to stake them, based on your angle of attack (i.e. behind, to the side, in front...etc). The gameplay is pretty good, but the enemy AI often run around damn near in circles, before they decide you're there and turn around to take aim. Sometimes the AI even run past you all together. Most other games the AI may get momentarily startled, sure...but they always and immediately raise their guns to fire. These particular cultists, however, seem unsure about their allegiance.

Gameplay is incredibly classic, like playing Timesplitters, Halo 1, or the original Perfect Dark, in that you just feel like a floating camera with a gun floating closely by the side of the screen. Aiming down the sights is not so much the feeling of a gun being pulled up to your face, as it is a gun model floating to the center of the green, to signify looking down the sights. Coupled with their being no melee weapons, assassination moves, aerial stealth kills...it's just a clean-cut and completely classic retro shooter, but with sliding. Still, it's quite an alright game.

The graphics are great for the art style. The art style for the characters resembles something like Fable, in that it's kind of cartoony, but done in a realistic looking environment.

Micro-stutters are very present in this game: I can be running a solid 80FPS, 4K and walking up and down a strip of area, hit the stutters and suddenly drops to 41FPS (in half), on a dime. I can then walk through the area where slowdown momentarily occurred, several times and the issue does not repeat, so it is not an issue that is relative to where you are or what is happening at the time. It's like lightning and will not strike in the same place twice. This paints the feeling that it's maybe a memory unloading issue, or, perhaps a memory leak. 

Lack of AI squad is disappointing, to say the lease. I mean, it's marketed as a squad game...so where's my NPC squad? I had imagined it would be a bit like Gears of War, or Mass Effect in terms of AI squad dynamics.

All-in-all? This game still has the potential to be my favorite loot shooter since Destiny! Even with all the critiques.  I just feel like it should have aimed to be more like Doom 2016 or Doom Eternal, than a squadless squad shooter. The setting and uniqueness of the games is fun in its own right, barring the poor voice acting.  

I have faith Arcane will fix and polish it--hopefully even do a Cyberpunk level overhaul but I know that's a rare thing to find...and since the developers are not talking, or announcing their plans, it is more likely that the devs may opt to go the Mass Effect: Andromeda route and just get the game playable and bail...which is the route that the recently released Forspoken also took. Arkane's silence is a bad sign, like when your aunt goes to return that insane infomercial purchase that she made, only to find out that the company closed its doors and shut its lines down the very next day (lol). Sorry...funny but not funny.

[h1]Basically a budget title[/h1]

Revised review after update 4:

This game is some simple fun - but don't buy it at the current price, get it with gamepass or at a deep sale.

This game can be fun at times, but don't expect deep gameplay mechanics. Combat can be fun, but it's pretty basic and there are just two types of enemies: Humans and Vampires, plus some bosses. The two maps are designed aesthetically with a lot of love, but they are a little sterile and lifeless nonetheless. The loot and level systems work, but are nothing to write home about. The game can be played coop, but there is no (!) way to play with randoms, there is no server browser or matchmaking at all, so you have to invite friends or play solo. If you intend to play solo, it can be played offline after update 4.

One last sentence to the technical state: There are some bugs, but I didn't encounter anything serious. The performance has been improved vastly thanks to the updates. I consider it fine now.
I am convinced that this game was some sort of test and developed by AI

Uninspired and unfinished. Absolute disaster of a game. Weapons are weird. Stats are just there. The special abilities add nothing. The cutscenes don't even move. It is very obvious the developers involved did not wanted to make this game. They probably already puked after they had to make Wolfenstein: Youngblood and it shows in Redfall. A vampire co-op shooter could have been so cool, but you need to have good design, a variety of enemies, a decent story if you're gonna call it stroy driven and also good levels and balance to be able to make something like that work. Arkane truly lost it. Such a shame. Avoid.

Co-Op is Fun

I usually play Arkane games single-player because that's the only way to do it, but for this one I'm playing with a friend.  I'm not sure how well the game would go over solo, but co-op has been fun.  The world building is good, the staking satisfying, and my awesome robot dog Bribon rules.  

We're probably 75% through the game and I'm comfortable saying this is no Dishonored or Prey, but it would be hard to reach those great heights.  Redfall is solid and I would recommend it when it's on sale.

I mean in most Zombie games you have the same setup, humans and Zombies. While this may not be a Zombie game it still has kinda the same vibe its just vampires instead of zombies. The characters I think are cool especially when you're playing co-op and they start talking to each other. Which I think is kinda cool because I've never seen anything like it in a co-op game before and it offers a unique experience.  The story is not interesting but the game play is a lot better than some people might think. Although the guns are not very impressive since its a lot of the same stuff with better states. It dose not really have a lot of weapons that are cool. Nothing really makes say oh wow that's a sick looking Weapon.  I mean even games like State of Decay has Cooler Weapons than this. Like the CLEO tech weapons which I thought were bad ass.  Its not perfect and I don't think its a game that's worth 70$ and 100$ dlc with a bunch of content that's not very impressive but if you can get it on sale at a very low price or try it for free on game pass its  worth a try. This game actually isn't as bad as a lot of people say it is. Yes, it has it's small minor bugs and glitches just like ALL games do when it's first released, but they have been fixing it. You have things you can do no matter what, whether it's the main quest, side quests or even just some other objectives to help you level up and get better equipment. [h1]Not as bad as you think it is.[/h1]

They fixed lot of bugs and it's way better now.
Redfall is still not what I would call a great game but it's far from being garbage.
Full price it is certainly not worth it due to the clear lack of polish but if you find it on a good discount it's well worth a try in my opinion.
I played for around twenty hours so far and I can say I'm mostly having a good time playing the game, there seem to be a decent amount of content if you explore and do side missions.

Redfall deliver nice graphics with cool visual style packed into an interesting open world map to explore.
Most areas are well designed and you can still see the Arkane dna here with lot of verticality and different paths available to you for your missions and exploration.
Fighting vampires and humans is refreshing and it's a breathe of fresh air compared to your average zombies slaying apocalypse.

Redfall gunplay while not stellar is enjoyable for the most part, sadly when playing solo the combat may feel clunky and unfair when facing lot of enemies because some of them can teleport and warp to random locations. The vampires have questionable reach to their lunge attacks and human gunners also hit really hard and you can easily die in a few seconds if you don't have any cover since the game really love to throw swarms of enemies at you, clearly some balancing issues here.
To put it simply the combat is enjoyable only when facing three or four enemies, when there's more things can quickly turn into a cluster fuck.
Despite it's problems the combat still qualify to something I would categorize as decent and thanks to the different classes available each with their unique abilities it actually give us more replayability.
There is a progression system and a skill tree for all classes, you gain XP by killing monsters, completing missions or discovering stuff on the map, it's nothing too deep but it's appreciable.
Sadly the loot system is boring and poorly thought out and there is not enough different weapons here.

On a technical standpoint well unfortunately Redfall still have many annoying bugs left unpatched like the House of Echoes mission where you can end up being softlocked because you cannot interact with the psychic echoes.
Enemies AI can glitch quite a lot here, sometimes they may shoot you through walls, they can get stuck in geometry or for some reasons they may completely turn invisible.
Pretty often you may find npc civilians stuck in a t-pose scattered around the map
The game's performances clearly leave something to be desired, framedrops and stutters can occur for no apparent reasons.

There is also huge problems with visibility to spot many items required to progress the missions, it's just tedious running around in circles trying to find these poorly highlighted minuscule damn items.
They claim to have fixed the infinite loading screen issue that can happen if you alt tab when initiating a fast travel across the map but it's still there.
On a positive note I haven't experienced any crashes in twenty hours, the only time I was forced to alt-f4 was when the infinite loading bug happened.
Anyway for me these technical issues are unacceptable coming from a huge studio and publisher like Arkane/Bethesda even more so when they price the game that high.

TLDR: Not entirely a bad game at all but far from being as good as previous Arkane masterpieces. Wait for huge discount.

[h1]Rating 6/10.[/h1]

Review update after October 6 patch:

As I mention in my review, this game could end up around 7/10 with proper polish and updates. Well, after spending quite a few hours with this new update - I'm ready to give it at least 7.5/10.

Do note that this is subjective and has a lot to do with me enjoying exploration, looting and the overall setting very much. For people who're not into this type of game - it might still read as average at best.

But, for me, this is now around what I originally hoped it would be - and that's saying something.

Also, this is the perfect Halloween game - for sure. But they really need to reduce the price a bit. 70 euro is too steep - especially given the abysmal launch.

-----

This is a hard game to review objectively.

Naturally, it's impossible to be fully objective - but I think it's useful to try and understand how other people operate and what kind of preferences exist out there.

In a vacuum, this game is a middling open world shooter - with a decent amount of lore and loot to find. It's playable solo, but I feel like it was designed around the coop experience.

So, if you play it as intended - there's fun to be had, as long as you keep your expectations in check.

Now, I haven't completed it - and I don't know how this game works in the longer term. I played most of my time with the Game Pass version.

But, I've played my fair share of coop looters - which is essentially what this is. From this perspective, I feel qualified to estimate the overall rating this game should receive.

As it stands, after the first patch - I'd say this game is around 5/10 for a solo player - leaning towards 6/10 as a coop game.

Positives include a neat concept with an intriguing setting. Surprisingly, there's also a lot of optional stuff to discover if you explore the various buildings and areas.

Negatives, sadly, are represented quite significantly. Everything about the AI is undercooked - and the world feels more dead than undead, if you know what I mean. Stealth is incredibly basic and seems to be made with minimal effort. Beyond that, the story is presented almost like an indie title would do it. This is in stark contrast with the asking price.

As for the average - I'd say the loot and combat would qualify. It's there and ranges between decent and boring - but overall just OK.

If they manage to spice it up a little more, especially when it comes to AI, world activities and enemy density - as well as polishing it to a higher standard, I think this could end up around 7/10.

Keep in mind that I'm a relatively harsh critic - and a lower score isn't a death sentence as far as I'm concerned. It's simply a more conservative approach to evaluating the good with the bad. 

Beyond that, I tend to find that Arkane games get more credit than they really deserve, but again, that's subjective. I've liked all their games for the most part, but they struggle with the finer things, including balance and especially the item economy - both of which are way, way too lax in all their titles to the point where you can trivialize any challenge - even on the hardest difficulties - once you've established your arsenal a bit. This is no different.

However, there's enough good for me to recommend it - but it's most definitely not a must have, and I certainly don't think it's worth anywhere near what they're charging.

So, wait for a sale - and go in with tempered expectations - and you'll find an experience that's significantly better than what seems to be the mainstream consensus.

I never really write a review for games, but this one I'd to make. This game had so much potential but due to silly decisions this game is very bad. Even if you look beyond all the bugs and exploits, just ask your self do you expect with a co-op game a matchmaking system. If your answer is Yes then this is the wrong game for you. I can keep beating this dead horse but that's pointless.  

Would I recommend this game ? HELL NO!

Kill some vampires with friends. 
Had some trouble with re-binding keys, but repeated, then was OK.

I'm a huge Arkane fan, but this game is not representative of Arkane's design philosophies nor their gameplay standards. There's news about mismanagement and loss of staff during the game's development, and you can clearly feel that.

Gameplay has tons of issues, from weird connection bugs that refuses to let you connect to Bethesta servers, to spawning enemies right in front of you, to clipping geometry that traps the player, lighting issues, T-posing, etc.

Even with all of that aside, the gameplay is extremely limited. There's no "choose your own path" ethos in here, just shoot vampires with different guns. You can't distract them with bottles or throwables, you can't close-quarter takedown them, you can't engineer clever conflicts between factions. 

Quite the disappointment, but I am curious how Arkane will salvage this project.

My brother and I had high hopes for this game. We completed it but it is a let down in almost every respect. Buggy, a poor narative, and repetitive game play. It is such a shame to see Arkane put out such a stinker. This probably should have been cancelled. Avoid unless you have a few friends that want to blast through a vampire themed co-op game and its less than $10 or through a subscription service.
Playing through the campaign mode with a friend, and we've been having a blast.  Fun to explore the town and stake the eff out of some vamps while we're at it.

The game itself is a bit below average, at least when I played it; there is little of the heart you'd expect of a game with Arkane as the developer. It became clear when I tried to teleport through a window into a locked room and, unlike all of the other windows in the game, my teleporter bounced off. This is trying to be more like Destiny or Borderlands: A coop looter shooter with an open world, but it lacks the complex depth of Destiny and its raid content and the comic absurdity of Borderlands. It just isn't challenging or satisfying to play. I just kind of kill everything I encounter or die instantly due to difficulty spikes. The map is also quite large with a lot of empty space and no way to drive, which feels wrong. I didn't hate it, but I probably won't play it again.

3.5/10

Got this game reasonably cheap and still disappointed. I dont do reviews very often, but this is the first time ive left a negative review for a game on steam. Whenever you load into the game, it is a blurry mess for 20 seconds until the game loads its shaders in. Controls have huge input lag that is only mostly fixed with the low latency option in the settings, but you should never have to do that to get the game to work properly. Characters are completely boring and forgettable, and although you can put the shader problem down to how garbage Unreal Engine 4 is (Hogwarts Legacy deserves far more criticism than it receives for its garbage performance on PC). Cutscenes are static lazy crap. The gameplay and loot mechanics ARE decent enough though. With sometime i think maybe this game could be turned into a semi decent looter shooter but the fact Microsoft thought this was acceptable to release in the state it was in, and have the nerve to ask $120 AUD for it is disgraceful. Maybe once its discounted to $30 or less i could recommend it but not as it is

A friend gifted me the game and I've been playing both SP and co-op.  
Co-op is a buggy mess, but I haven't come across anything game breaking, and it's still a lot of fun. The interaction between the main chars is cute, and sometimes hilarious.

The story is interesting - but it requires some leg-work and note-reading if you want to see the full picture. All notes you open are saved in your archive though, so you can pick up fast when your friends are in a hurry looting and read everything later. 

The world feels quite empty, there aren't enough enemies re-spawning in the streets or buildings (and definitely not enough car or burglary alarms). When you have roamed around and killed everything once there's just the small events (nests and rooks) left. You are forced to continue the main story to find more stuff to do, and I wish there were way more small encounters and more side quests. 

Pick your character with care, there's only one save... I play Remi on Daylight difficulty - I don't want a challenge, I just want to be entertained -  and random encounters are very easy while most bosses are too hard to be fun solo (in co-op it's just right). 

I do recommend the game, it's a lot of fun! But the game in it's current state is *not* worth the full price. It really feels like it's in early access. Get it on Game Pass or wait for it to either go on sale or (hopefully) get a massive update.

Game is just so terrible that I can even finish it to get it off my backlog. Wish I could get a refund even at 9.2 hours. The AI are still terrible and the optimization is miserable maybe they will fix this game in a year but don't waste your time and from the sounds of it the developers didn't even want to finish this game. So terrible and I loved arkanes other games this one is just so upsetting
worst game ever

Meh. That's all I can really say about this game. It's not terrible, but it's far from good. A few creative ideas on display, but I don't like the cartoon art style at all, the story is fairly mundane, finding bits of lore is unsatisfying (partly because you never know whether or not you've seen an item, because it never disappears from the game world or otherwise lets you know you've picked it up), and the depiction of the Reverend is absolutely ridiculous and at times deeply inappropriate.

The shooting doesn't feel solid or satisfying, and though the game seems open world, it's actually a pretty linear campaign. You can play as a few different characters, but you can't swap freely between them. The save system is not as generous or intuitive as it should be in a game where you could die at any moment. Might be worth playing if you like vampire lore and the game goes on sale, but otherwise, a purchase I definitely regret.

This game was a disappointment. I supported this game fully until it released. Multiplayer matchmaking isnt avaliable and the game is always online... WHY.... makes no sense. co op is invite only. The games optimization, i thought would get better but hey its whatever right? its just a single player or co op game. Yea nah i expect so much more for my money. Gaming industry really hurting ig cause THIS. WAS. BAD. 18 hours and ive already finished two playthroughs of the game. Yea no content what so ever and not a sign of any dlc add on that was promised as a "guarantee".  Damn... all those streamers you paid to play your game and you still could save it by putting in even the smallest fraction of effort. Games dead and meaningful updates in sight. NoGGNoRE Arkane, How You Have Fallen From Grace Disgust Me.

Not nearly as bad as people have said. In fact, I think the bones of the game are actually quite decent, borderline good even, it just needs some TLC (I'm giving it a 6/10 here but in time I think it could become a solid 7/10 at the very least.) From everything I had heard prior to playing it, I was actually pleasantly surprised when I finally gave it a chance, and would definitely recommend it if you can find it on sale. With future patches, the game should continue to improve, so for those who think the normal price is a little steep (which it is, especially at the game's retail price), wait a bit for the price to go down because at that point, a lot of the bugs and technical gripes others and myself have had with the game will probably be fixed, leading to a much better experience. That said, don't buy this expecting an experience like Prey, Dishonored, or even Deathloop (or basically just any Arkane game for that matter), Redfall is very much its own thing in that regard, for better or worse.

Mostly Negative is a pretty accurate review, I have played it start to finish with 2 others and have seen most of the glitches and desync this game has to offer. The concept of taking back the world map from the enemies is great the whole colony stay in 1 building is terrible, if they had small branches of the faction move out to "safe locations" to make you feel like you achieved something that would be great rather than just killing vampires till the rook shows up. 
Followed by using the stake launcher for an easy 1 hit kill on the rook and insanely easy legendary weapon farming. 
To then head back to the only compound to restart the next mission... BORING.
The ability to move backwards and forwards between maps shouldn't be limited to 1 run or 1 play through with a specific character that takes away from the game quite a lot, Having to start a new character because you missed a single item for 100% completion! YUCK! How ever it is good that you don't have to re-find all grave locks you have already picked up from the initial playthrough. 
This game had the potential to be so much better than it was, Maybe in a year if the bugs have been ironed out ill play it again and amend the review but then again maybe Arkane Austin and Bethesda have already scrapped the idea to fix whats wrong with it.

listen although this game has gotten alot of bad rep, i have been playing it for close to 38 hours now and i still haven't beaten the game the comments from some people having beaten the game in 6 hours doesn't seem possible to me i feel like alot of people are looking at some gameplay where there has been alot of bugs and crashes and just agreeing with everyone that the game sucks. so first of all the game requirements recommend you install the game on an SSD which at first i had the game Installed on my regular hard drive. this game runs night and day so long as you follow the recommendations, on my HDD game ran very slow lots of latency issues and crashes. however the game loaded on my SSD zero issues so far aside from some foliage textures taking a bit to load in which is common in an open world game. those who cant have fun playing this game are in my opinion the game perfectionists; They find one thing wrong and decided its garbage. when i play this game i get the feeling of if borderlands and far cry teamed up to make a post apocalyptic island taken over by vampires and there is quite the variety of different enemies and how they function. anyone who enjoys and good story and some decent gun-play should definitely try out this game.

RE-review.

When I first played Redfall it was a janky mess that was "interesting" without actually having much value, there was a lot of "ah, I wonder what they were trying to do there" or "isn't it a shame that didn't quite work out" and a lot of "what the hell were they thinking?!"

Mostly, the price tag was stupid, releasing it on xbox gamepass at the same time meant no-one would buy it, and the prospect of DLC characters was laughable.

But then the game got patched, and slowly from the mountainous turd there were some small glimmers of potential - all leading up to Update 4.

Update 4 is an enormous undertaking, not least because it came out after the company had died.
It rebalances huge amounts of the game, including the ability to earn skillpoints beyond levelling, new weapons, new arenas, a bunch of QOL options that are unlocked and a secondary progression system through the neighbourhood renown they added.

It does not completely revive redfall, ironically staked to ash and not rising out of its coffin - but it does turn the half-formed mess into a much better experience.

If ever it's cheap (or free) I recommend giving Redfall a go. It's a far cry from other Arkane games, but there's some fun to be had here, and if nothing else I'll be sad it never got the chance to be the game it so clearly COULD have been.

As much as I would like to defend this game, being such a long time fan of Arkane Austin games and their style (having hundreds of hours in both Dishonored and Dishonored 2 combined (though most of that in the first game) and having enjoyed Prey well enough)....

I can't.

The game is redeemable, with future updates and content.  The gameplay itself isn't the worst thing in the world.  But frankly the game is a 6/10 at best, and the absolute silence from the dev team and lack of updates in over a month (and no, the backend update a week after launch doesn't count), the game is officially dead on arrival.  I'll probably continue playing and replaying it with a friend of mine, but ultimately I've fully lost hope in the game being salvaged to even an 8/10 state at this point.

Communication was all that was needed, really.  Sure it wouldn't have saved this failure of a launch, but it would've helped soothe the worries and the poor launch for those of us who saw the potential of a stable game in there.

Edit:Leaving the rest for posterity. Do Not Buy This! The studio was closed down and all development ceased. There will never be DLC or Offline support for the game so not only will you never get the DLC eventually you will not be able to play the game either.

Finished the game on Midnight difficulty (Highest setting without NG+) with 2 friends

Interesting premise but executed like garbage
- No animated cut-scenes
- Poor story telling
- Forced story events are usually still transparent models talking with no graphical aid for visualisation
- Majority of the lore is hidden in notes and world curious that are annoying to find and interact with and boring to read
- Because of poor story telling, villains are not very interesting aside from "Typical megalomaniac on a power trip"
- Meaningless/non-existent interaction between the playable characters, almost like it was designed to be a single-player game

Performance is garbage despite mediocre graphics
- Mid-tier laptop (6800HS + 3070 Mobile) cannot keep 60FPS on 1080P minimum settings (DLSS does nothing and sometimes makes it worse)
- Decent PC (5800X3D + 6900XT overclocked) can hardly keep over 90FPS on 1440P medium preset
- Turns into a slideshow in some scenarios with drops to 4-5FPS

Gameplay
- World is 95% (approximation) empty space, 5% Points of Interest with enemies
- Boring travel point to point due to lack of enemies, despite heavily implying the town is overrun with vampires
- Character personalities are anaemic
- Character skill trees are uninspiring, with one character having major advantage in utility compared to the others
- Some skill upgrades are conflicting
[b]Example[/b]: Jakob's scanning Raven's damage upgrade means enemies become alert and stealth is lost, not exactly beneficial when sneaking or long-range sniping as they will always know where you are and rush you
- Dumb as bricks AI for both Humans and Vampires
- Most vampires can be circumvented by being on higher ground (insert Star Wars reference) like car or van or having a chest-high object between you and them
- Inventory and Shop UI is very clunky and annoying to use

Guns
- Uninspired choice of standard weapons (Pistol, Revolver, Shotgun, Assault RIfle, Sniper Rifle)
- Weapon balancing is terrible
- Vampire-specific weapons are unique but sometimes unwieldy as most engagement involves human targets
- 3 active weapon slots felt restrictive as at least one is taken up a vampire-specific weapon (though this is personal preference issue)
- Most gun stats such as accuracy are not well explained
- Attachments on guns are seemingly randomised and not indicated in any way.
[b]Example 1[/b]: Sights on an Assault Rifle can be iron-sights or Holo/Red-dot, despite the model and rarity being the same
[b]Example 2[/b]: Sniper rifles can be silenced or un-silenced and has no indication unless you equip it and inspect the model or shoot the gun
- Numerical Bonuses on rare guns (green and above) tend to reset when reloading game session [i]So say goodbye to that new legendary weapon every time you sign off[/i]
[b]Example 1[/b]: Increased mag size from 15 to 20 on a rifle will revert back to 15 after quitting and resuming your game
- Unique bonuses (non-numerical) such as being able to kill a vampire with a bullet weapon without staking them is kept

Gunplay
- Most guns feel clunky to use
- Aim-Down-Sight sensitivity is VERY low with no dedicated sensitivity setting, making it hard to track moving targets, much less getting head-shots with precision weapon
(Although the AI are generally dumb and loves to randomly stop moving quite often, they are also prone to making micro-movements to the left and right which can be incredibly frustrating for anyone not using a shotgun)
- Not much variation in engagements

After giving it a solid play, finishing the story as well as all the side-missions we could find, it had no redeeming qualities.

I wanted to like this game, I truly did. I enjoyed the gameplay for the most part, the story isn't half-bad, but the bugs have broken it entirely for me. I have played co-op with family since day 1 and have run into a few annoying bugs and one that has now repeated twice that has entirely ruined the game for us. The devs have known about the random bug since day 1 where if one player leaves the game and comes back they lose all progress from the start of the play session. They have said nothing. They have done nothing. At this point, after losing an entire day worth of play AND the ability to have the god token item thing that is necessary for further progress, I'm simply not interested in giving this game another chance. We would literally have to start over, from the beginning, simply to allow me to play with my family further. This is an absolute embarrassment of a game, an embarrassment of a studio, and an embarrassment of a publisher to allow this to continue as it has. Cyberpunk corrected a lot of their issues and issued a public apology for their terrible launch. The fact that Arkane/Bethesda don't even have the courtesy to send out a "we're working on fixing this, we know it was bad" communication to their buyers is some of the worst, most pathetic, and childish head in the sand nonsense I've ever seen from any developer or publisher. I, for one, will never touch an Arkane game again.

Good concept, bad execution, Redfall is if you put Borderlands, Fallout and Bioshock franchises in the mix and you would get Redfall. I can honestly see what they where trying to do with this game, However it has some amazing problem. Graphic glitches, AI glitches, brightness problems, weapons underpowered, rapping up and down of difficulty. Sometimes you may have a fight with a vampire or horde grunt that you with easy take out with one shot with only a pistol in hand, other times they will be a bullet sponge and you will just die with in one hit. Even on Dusk (easy) setting. Glitched out pick up items, glitched out objective items and not you mention the final bosses, being so easy or complete bullet sponges to. Even though can be highly addictive to play, it can be very frustrating with the many, many, many glitches both graphically and AI. This game need the be patched and balanced better. Also please patch the way that players can accept and cancel main missions on the briefing tables. And also patch in a way that players can accept more side missions then one main mission and one sub mission.

I don‚Äôt often leave reviews on games but this one kind of deserves one. I wanted to get this game on release but saw all of the bad reviews so held off- I saw it on offer on a site so took a punt. To start with do not buy this game for ¬£60 as its just not worth that money, sub ¬£35 is justified IMO. The game has loads of potential but quickly becomes a repetitive cycle of missions that have no depth and a continuous cycle of running somewhere, killing vampires and doing it over and over. Once you learn how to kill the different vampires it becomes stale. It‚Äôs playable, I‚Äôve played all my hours so far on my steamdeck and it‚Äôs only 6 hours in that I‚Äôve discovered bugs and stuttering. It is almost a time killer with a smidge of good story and ability to get me hooked. The gunplay is ok and the ability tree is decent too. I was expecting to play and it be an absolute mess and it‚Äôs not. This seems like a negative review but I am looking forward to coming home and playing more even though it is a bit samey. For me it‚Äôs not a ¬£60 game, if it was sold at ¬£35 or less this probably would‚Äôve had a better launch, but there is fun to be had, so I‚Äôll give it a thumbs up! :)

Got the Bite Back Edition free with a graphics card but pleased I didn't pay for it. The Graphic style is similar to Dishonoured but at least that game was fun with different ways to play. Redfall is a shooter, plain and simple, and every situation is to go in guns blazing. Now that might not have been to bad had the missions been fun, but they are dull and somewhat repetitive, especially the safe house missions, which are only two per safe house. The game world consists of two towns you have to liberate, but they are not very big, and fast travel points scattered around makes travelling easy. The only bugs I found myself was getting stuck on things like a rock or tree branch and unable to move so was forced to reload, and fog glitches where the fog becomes massively pixelated. Can I recommend this game? not really at the price point, as currently while writing the Bite Back Edition is ¬£83.99 which is way to much for so little entertainment. But if you want a vampire shooter I'd say get it on sale when the price drops massively like 75% off or something.

Game is better than most reviewers say, but far from perfect. Graphics are the greatest problem, they're really outdated. I like way how vampires are depicted, details of interior in houses from Tiffany like lamps to boxes of pills and violent scenes of vampire apocalypse and general quite good horror vibe, but that's about it what is positive on Redfall's grahics. light, shadows, smoke or liquid look really bad, like from 2000's game, maybe even worse. This is I think the reason, why Arkane has made this weird thing with frozen wawes of ocean water around the island, so they didn't have to create rivers and lakes of water and show us how bad they can be at it. Thinking this way, they also shoudln't include that killing red mist into the game, because it looks extremly ugly, like from some 10 Euro indie game made by two amateur developers in their free time. Also spectrum of colour palette used is not very aesthetic exactly. Character models aren't most modern and beatiful, but Arkane is notoriously bad about this, look for Deathloop or Prey, at least they're trying to compensate it by this simplyfying artistic stylisation. Story, diagolue and lore are more focused and deeper than in Deathloop for example, which was strongly multiplayer orientated, but only a little, it's not as good as in Dishonored. Making only low budget comics-like cutscenes, probably maybe, because they wanted to save money on lipsync was quite dissapointing. Sountrack was above average, like in all Arkane games, but not as that epic as in Prey. Gameplay was ok, combat is fun and over the top, shooting mechanics can pass, but I've seen better, even from Arkane. Quests started to be quite stereotypical in second part of game and that's quite alarming for around 25 hours of gameplay. Next time, I'm going to think twice before pre-purchasing new Arkane game....

Ive played the 18 hours with a friend of mine. and there are a few major things both positive an negative that id like to point out. Start

Positive:
* The world is really interesting to explore. Even though the story isnt that special. With fun collectibles that provide passive stats. 

* Different systems that are explained over the course of the first  location you play on (yes you go to a 2nd map) for instance:

- the rarity of weapons determine what attachments could be on it. (but isnt guarenteed) so even the same weapon with the same rarity can have different attachments like a silencer on it.
- The Rook. In the world, the vampire gods can get mad and this can get to a critical point, where they call on the Rook. This "boss-type" enemy isnt too hard to beat if you can focus him. He drops a guarenteed legendary weapon. But he's really bad if he is summoned when you're doing something else. 

* Really nice game for Dishonored fans. A lot of the artstyle is similair and the story telling mechanism is exactly the same, with still images of the involved characters with narration. 

Negative:
* It isnt clear at the start, but the game gets an insane difficulty cliff once you get a little further into the 1st location. it seems like it is a tutorial area that isnt pointed out as tutorial. (i dont know this im just speculating) because many people played this game for like an hour and have decided the AI is ret*rded.

* The AI can definitely get a difficulty increase. Even if i haven't played the highest difficulty yet.
* The AI doesnt provide a big enough challenge to use your characters abilities. Especially at the start me and my buddy would forget we had skills we could use. Later this changed with the Vampire nests coming in.
* The game still need a lot of work and sometimes the developers seem a little tone deaf to the situation of this game and its reviews, (for instance publishing a buzzfeed style "wich character in Redfall are you" quiz when people were begging for updates and improvements. 

TLDR:RECOMMEND?

YES -> With friends
NO -> Solo

It is now 20 days after release. No communication from the developers, no patch in sight except for a small hotfix.

I finished the game in under 40 hours, I did enjoy playing it for the most part but it has some serious issues.

Good:
- I enjoyed the world. It looks nice and New England-ish. I did not mind the emptiness that much, it brings some tension to roaming around. What is around the corner? There is a lot of wasted potential here, though.
- environmental sound design. Just roam through the neighborhood and listen to it; hum from a transformer, gas flowing for a heater, much more. I did enjoy that.
- the idea of the vampire apocalypse in an isolated town is ok.

Bad:
- silence from the developers. I think it is too late now, soon there will be no players left and interest will be gone.
- horrendous enemy A.I. Every alerted enemy just runs straight at you. No tactics, no cover, just Zerg rush. Remember F.E.A.R. from 2005? THAT is how you would expect a team of soldiers to act.
- low-res shimmering shadows. Come on, you have to be blind to 'miss' this, it was a conscious decision to not make it better.
- flashlight does not cast a shadow.
- psychic echoes look cheap, take too long and are uninteresting. It sucks the life out of the story (pun intended :-p ).
- wasted potential in the world. Yes you have feuding factions that fight each other with bad A.I. , it could have been so much more. Where are the survivors in the streets? If there are hostages, why not have people hiding barricaded in their houses and defending themselves? Where are the animals? Rats, cats, dogs, you name it.
- single slot save.
- bugs in side mission progression. Mission 'Eclipsed' did not end for me despite having all its objectives checked. This means achievement for all side missions cannot be obtained. Add to that the single save slot and lack of a proper load option, dooming you to replay 50% of the game for another 'chance' to get the achievement. How about "no"?
- bugs in inventory. Old guns and remnants get marked as new over and over again every time the game is started.
- bugs in world POI discovery. 2nd area mission table keeps popping up as newly discovered in every session.
- points of no return. If you pass certain points (transition to next area, and after the ending) it is not possible to return so you'd better have prior knowledge of them and do everything you want to do before it is to late. Same goes for achievements, you need prior knowledge for some. Only fix is to replay the game which is just stupid, not going to happen, I can't be bothered.
- vampire lairs are not made for single players. Hard work, lousy incentives. Why bother?

And probably lots more.

It is clear the game is undercooked. Corners were cut, it is not 'finished'. 

Overall I will not recommend playing this game unless there is a miraculous turn-around in the near future. Fix the bugs, fix the A.I., allow players to return to the other area and continue after ending, add proper save/load system.

Also it would be nice for the devs or publisher to have the common decency to let gamers know that complaints are heard and fixes are being worked on. I love Arkane games. Dishonored, Prey and Deathloop (even Arx Fatalis) are pieces of art, but this unfinished Redfall is unworthy for the likes of Arkane. A blemish on your reputation, and yes you are only as good as your last game.

Oh yeah, got the game with a video card. I will not mark is a 'received for free' because IT IS NOT FREE. This is a deal between the publisher and the manufacturer of the video card; money was exchanged, part of the price of the card was 'reserved' to pay for it. On that same note: technically the game was pre-ordered and registered in Steam before it released, but I did not receive the pre-order bonus (so like, where is it? cheap... not bothered).

While I can't recommend the game without it being patched, I can't deny how much fun I'm having with it.
The only issues I ran into were traversal loading frame drops and a few pop-ins, but none of the major widespread bugs.
I'm playing solo and having a blast currently on my second playthrough, but I wish there was a character swap in the main hub or safehouses. My first playthrough was with Devinder, I had a lot of fun, but I'm enjoying Jacob a lot more.

Jacob is like Corvo (Dark Vision) and Colt (Aether)
Layla is like Typhon Morgan (Backlash, Lift Field, Phantom Genesis)
Remi is like Engineer Morgan with a robot companion
And Devinder is like Daud (Arc Mine, Blink, Bend Time for vampires)

Main missions have multiple enemies and Arkane's signature play-your-way style.
My only real complaints about the game are the lack of variety of abilities in single-player and not enough enemies and survivors in the open world map. The game was pushed out way too early, but I still enjoyed it a lot more than Deathloop. 

And I don't get the whole cut-scene backlash. Except for Dark Messiah and Prey, Arkane always uses still/animated slideshows for their cut scenes, unless it's in first-person perspective. Dishonored DLC, Dishonored 2, Death of the Outsider, and Deathloop all had still/animated cutscenes, with a few first-person cut scenes.

I don't understand how someone can think that releasing this was going to recoup costs in any meaningful fashion. Yes, there's times where a product is struggling and it might be a somewhat wise move to pander to the Sunk Cost fallacy, but Redfall isn't one of such occasions. The game's had years in the oven, about as much as your average tentpole release, and what we've received is worse off than No Man's Sky's first release, and certainly worse than Cyberpunk 2077's.

Let's be clear here - I do not blame Arkane Austin. As to why, it's because the guys who gave us PREY or both Dishonored titles have since left both the Austin and Lyon offices. This is an Arkane Austin title in name only, and feels much more like something that should've been marketed as a first outing from an indie studio, something we'd find acceptable if it were Early Access material and if we had the clear understanding that the enemy AI, weapon balance and general plot of the game were all placeholders.

Consider another mostly-vapid Early Access title like V Rising, for instance. There's almost nothing there, beyond the expected grind and the notion that once you've built up your keep and dominated all bosses, you're more or less due for a restart. In V Rising's case, you at least get the sense that the game is being actively worked on. Things could improve over time, and will definitely change.

Not so with Redfall - and that is what's utterly baffling.

If that's all you have to offer as a studio, you don't try and recoup your losses, especially not as part of some weirdo attempt to tout it as one of XBOX Game Pass' more Premium offerings. You could cut your losses, scrap the project - and re-evaluate your design document.

Oh, and above all? Ignore focus groups. I work in Marketing, and I know for a fact that most panel-selected "gamers" who get paid to chew on stale donuts and drink free coffee do not know what they want. They know what they like, sure, but they're not in the best position to articulate it. Neither is your board of shareholders. If someone with stocks on the table tells you to work on a concept your team isn't known for successfully tackling, that's an immediate red flag.

Redfall is everything that's wrong with the video games industry as of 2023. Good on you if you've found a few hours' worth of fun with some friends and the dumb enemy AI, but those same friends of yours are worth far, far better. Why play this, when you've got Tiny Tina's Wonderlands or any of the Borderlands games?

Just finished the game and all the side quests and now I am qualified to say this game is bad. It was literally painful to finish.

I did see the attempt to create a story-driven experience: Jacob's background, pretty and immersive interiors here and there. But then none of those were actually finished. The last couple of quests in the main story are not even properly written, we get 3 empty flashbacks for each of vampire gods that don't add anything to the lore, story or character development. Just finished up my time with Redfall, I completed all the side and main missions in the game and tried to do as much as I could really. I played on the normal difficulty and found myself finished up in about 13hrs, which for the price they put on this game is ridiculous. 

Some points to note below:

- Story was pretty meh and cringey throughout, nothing worth gripping.
- World is beautiful, it felt like they spent most of their time building this world and it does pop!
- Gunplay was meh, felt exciting in the middle of my playthrough with different options, but I ended up sticking with the same gun types as I felt comfortable with them.
- I played Solo as the game obviously advertised Solo & Coop play. This did not feel like a solo experience at all, not being able to pause mid-game, when you died it just put you at the nearest fast travel point and you could just walk up and continue the fight which made dying rendered useless. Parts of the dialogue were built for multiple people, at one point I walked up to a gate and it referenced multiple people in the dialogue and i'm just stood there on my own. Some fights were pretty overwhelming for 1 person but I'd imagine a doddle with 2+. 
- The text heavy pages/books/lore got boring really quick and I completed ignored them after a while as I just wasn't gripped into it at all.
- Resonating with others, I agree with the AI, just needs smartening up.
- FPS was all over the place, I play at 4K 144hz on a 4090 and I was just struggling in parts of the open world. Entering any other realm net me a solid 140fps, but the main world would just see drops all of the time from 80ish down to 30 and giving stuttering.

Finally the biggest disappointment from me is the radio silence from the devs, there is some good core gameplay here but bugs need fixing and performance needs an overhaul. I hope to come back to this game after some updates and maybe then I could recommend to friends to buy the game, but not in the state its in now.

It is criminal that they dare charge AAA prices for such broken crap.

In the end, get on sale. Not worth the 70 dollars! Was a buggy mess at launch that kept me from being able to push through and continue playing by the time they patched it. Might try again when they release DLC character since I can't get a refund on this one.

You can't kill a Vampire without a stake and so you will fail until you buy the Bite Back Upgrade. Redfall was ninty-nine dollars. After playing the first mission can I say this game is worth the ninty-nine dollars? No it is not. I have games that I have paid less than thirty dollars (GTA5) that have much better graphics and game mechanics. Would I buy Redfall again; had I known and have the experience of playing? Yes, I would buy it again, I like it; it is unique and there is not another Vampire game that I have liked at all. I was wanting a vampire game that I want to keep playing and Redfall is it. I'm sure improvements will come with future updates. Cheers!

[h2]YES...[/h2]
- It's a good shooter
- Interesting open-world exploration or sight-seeing
- Stealth and Action possiblity with AI adatpting to it
- Idea is somewhat new and unexplored
- 4 playable character with distinct combat/stealth mechanics
- A full skilltree with manifold skills
- A loot system with alot of items laying around, making the world "lived-in"
- A rarity system that adds boni on you weapons
- A level system that make your old weapons obsolete and keep you searching for better
- A variety of weapon types to choose from and to customize your playstyle

[h2]BUT...[/h2]
- Horrible shooting animations, lagging reloads (rubberbanding magazines lagging behind the animations)
- They made so much effort to be interesting and diversified but then just plain copy-pastat all the rest of the assets. "Dungeons" (Hearts) are only just not enough variety to stay interesting
- The Human-AI is not optimized for neither stealth or shooting and they switch between those two modes it jarring and results in T-Posing, gliding around, rubberbanding, deforming (e.g. holding their weapon behind their back to shoot at you and more)
- Vampires is not your everyday concept for horror, but could be soooo good if they wouldn't have littered the whole world with them and made them extreme push-overs 
- Don't bother about every one of the characters, one has UV powers and teleport. Every other it focused on the humans that are already easy as all heck. Please make at least TWO usefull against the 2 types of enemies...
- Every skill needs to be skilled in order to get in the upper skilltree, rendering the possibility to decide obsolete
- No item is used in any meaningful way, the give you health by chugging any drinkable, eatable (may it be chips to full on bottles full with alcohol) and the other give you "support" what is essential just a unfitting word for mula, money, kaching-kaching. You EVEN SPEND IT. Where on earth you spend "support" on weapons. Make it money ffs.
- The "rarity" system is completely obsolete, because every unique weapon is not at all unique and you find them at specific points after a short wait of a in-game day or smth like that
- You always need the new weapon, because the enemies scale with your level so even your best weapon ts bad fast. Not like other games where a "normal" weapon is worth a level or two and unique weapons worth five or more. It feels immediately outdated and you need to skavenge more robbing you essentially of gametime that could be spend playing the story and having fun
- 2 weapon variations for every type of weapon for a looter shooter is just not enough and boring as HECK

[h2]AND...[/h2]
It's sadly the principle of "death by thousand cuts". 

Map Problems:
- Small bugs in Models, 
- off-limit housing in an exploration game,
- to little loot in a looter shooter,
- HOLLOW-MAN VOICE LINE SPAM,
- detection through solid objects,
- Hitscan in a 2023 game,
- Damage range dropoff (like I play a game of nerf against aimbots with nailguns)
- Enemies plain missing / not spawning in

Coop Problems:
- Coop Partner interaction voice line spam (all two of them),
- Coop Hit-box Wandering,
- Coop animations are bugged,
- So.much.missing.collision

No eye for detail:
- floating world-objects
- models clipping through walls,
- low-res textures,
- bugging/skipping/vibrating/missing assets all over the game

Poory optimized rendering pipelines
- textures blurry,
- laggy on mid-to-high settings on a high-end-pc,
- framedrops of doom,
- stutters
- and crashes

I want to like it, but it drained every drop of fun out of the experience for me. That's the only "Vampire"-Mechanic they nailed. It's dry as bones, sucked empty by the lack of creativity, attention to detail and plain "don't care" attitude by the devs/publisher to the obvious flaws this game has.

I honestly feel like everyone is being too harsh on this game.

I'm not going to say it's amazing. And it DEFINITELY isn't up to the standards of Deathloop, Dishonored 2, or (my favorite Arkane game) Prey. Not even close. And I won't pretend that I'm not disappointed about that. I am. I went into this hoping for basically a Borderlands game but with the quality and wonder of the previous Arkane games. And it is NOT that.

But at the same time, people calling it the "worst game of the year" and "not even worth playing for free on game pass" are being hyperbolic and cruel. It's not THAT bad. I don't find the game world to be empty like other people are saying. Especially once (slight spoiler) vampire nests and the Rook Storm are introduced. I find the gun play satisfying enough, I enjoy the character abilities a lot, and the story is nice! I've beaten the game as Devinder, I've started the game as Jacob & Layla to try them out, and I'm currently playing multiplayer as Remi. And I'm still enjoying it a lot. Enough that I still plan to play through the game again (at least a little) as the extra characters they plan to release later.

The ONLY actual problem I have is the difficulty scaling in multiplayer. The game can sometimes be challenging solo, but in multiplayer, it is so easy it's boring (unless you have already beaten the game once and set it to the highest "Eclipse" difficulty). The game needs to either SIGNIFICANTLY beef up the enemies in multiplayer or make the hordes much much larger.

But every other complaint I've seen people mention? I'm not saying they aren't legit, but I don't think they're as bad as people are pretending they are. Although, to be fair, I don't really care about graphical glitches. I find it silly when people act like that sort of thing ruins a game. But if graphical issues are SUPER important to you, that will definitely be a problem.

Overall I would say that the game is good but not great in solo...and okay in multiplayer. It's definitely not as terrible as some people like to say, but not as good as I was hoping it would be. And the few legit issues it does have seem like things that could get patched.

Feels like a parody of a triple-A game made by a parody of a studio released by a parody of a publisher that is owned by Microsoft who feel like a parody in themselves when it comes to gaming.

As many others mentioned before, Redfall plays like a 20‚Ç¨ - 30‚Ç¨ early access game created by an indie developer who hasn't really figured out yet what sort of generic game they want to make.

It tries to be a shooter, but the mechanics are basically worse than those of many games from 10 - 15 years ago.
It tries to be a story driven adventure, but lacks both an interesting story and any engaging storytelling outside constant voice-overs and a lot of dull flashbacks.
It tries to be an open-world game, but the world itself feels surprisingly static, without much sense of wonder and barely any reason for exploration beyond the main story missions.
It tries to be a stealth game during many missions, but once you bring a couple of friends with you pretty much everything can be and will be steamrolled.
It tries to be a multi-player game, or it was at least marketed as one, but it even lacks basic features one would expect from an always online single-player game.
[b]However, worst of all:[/b] It tries to be a game about Vampires, but neither re-invents their interactions or depiction nor conforms to the long established norms of the genre.

If one looks a bit closer at some of the mechanics and past the bugs, glitches or quirks, one has to wonder if the studio could have made a decent game with another year or two of development time or if we finally have entered the era of gaming where people happily pay for perceived quantity of content over any resemblance of quality of that content in video games.
Maybe MS goes for a "No Man's Sky"-style rework of this game, but personally I'd guess some game devs in Austin will be looking for a new studio soon.

At least Redfail has also some funny moments... finding PlayStations placed in the game world fits this lackluster XBox exclusive very well.

Oof. I am a huge fan of Arkane games and I was very excited for this game. The biggest thing is that this game was marketed as a co-op experience, but there is no public matchmaking. This is a huge mistake, considering that all 4 characters seem to require other teammates to really shine. This, combined with terrible and untested AI and the mostly empty open world that feels like a chore to walk through, it‚Äôs definitely not worth any amount of money. It‚Äôs fun for a bit, but every fight has the same loop, and the bugs don‚Äôt help. It would be nice if studios actually launched their games on any system before collecting the audience‚Äôs money. This is a scam, at best.
Worst game I've played in over 10 years, BF2042 is about 10x's better.
Terrible. Seriously just pass on this game. Under any circumstance or excuse you give yourself

Disappointing release from Arkane. It is an ok game if it had been release by a relatively unknown developer, but this is Arkane with Microsoft behind it and this is the output? Massive disappointment. Go play Prey, Dishonored, or even Borderlands instead.

Not as horrible as some have said.  For me, video optimization and such are things that can be patched, but game SYSTEMS can't really be changed after launch.  And the weapon system just...doesn't work.  The random spawning of weapons just creates a boring tedious system of having to unequip old version and requip new version of the same weapons.  It would have made more sense to have a sytstem to upgrade the weapons a la Dishonored upgrade system at the Black Markets.

But ultimately what killed the game for me is that it is NOT fun for single player.  The powers of the characters are clearly meant to be for co-op.  And the story isn't as rich if you don't play co-op (and have the characters befriend and talk to each other).  I love Arkane games because I love great single player, story driven game with cool powers and excellent level design.  This has the elements of all of it, but it was clearly designed for co-op as its primary focus.

In the final analysis, the video issues and bugs probably would have been overlooked if the gameplay was actually fun.  Alas, it is not.

Needs work, but there's definitely a good game in there- I'd give it a few months unless you're like me and don't mind working around bugs. 

Writing is on-point, making Peter Thiel and his acolytes into literal vampires that you can kill is a pretty fun concept. I enjoyed Remi as the single-player protagonist, and the major NPCs were mostly likeable characters with some interesting stuff to say over the course of the game.

The combat could use some polish but generally felt good, all the weapon classes felt like they had unique strengths and weaknesses and the special vampires had neat gimmicks. As a looter-shooter it has fairly simple but generally well-balanced perks, and what seem to be a fair number of different weapon parts a la Borderlands; sights and suppressors definitely matter, the others may just be cosmetic. I found myself using blue and purple weapons over yellows frequently, the M1911 with silver bullets is the only one that really stood out to me as busted.

Give it a shot now if you liked Prey/Dishonored and don't mind bugs, otherwise I'd give this one a couple months to work out some kinks.

I, for one, really love this game. I know a lot of people have had performance issues, but I expect those to be ironed out. If you somehow have a smooth experience or are willing to wait for the patches, you'll look at a beautiful game, with fresh mechanics and an interesting story.

The combat is challenging and I haven't had any encounters with non-reactive enemies so far. Being able to blast through 3 vampires or more at once is really rewarding. I love the level design, and it's clear to me that a lot of love has been put into designing the game, despite all the negative reactions. Maybe time will tell. 
	The dungeons could use a little more variation, though. They're optional, but they're a nice change of pace and scenery, so I wouldn't mind a few new levels there. Cheers!
