I was really looking forward to Redfall. Story driven open world looter shooter with vampires? Sign me up. I even paid full price for it. Unfortunately Redfall just...man, it sucks.

It's not story driven - there seems to be a story here amidst all the notes and recordings but it lacks depth. There's an open world, but it's empty. I frequently run for several minutes across the world and encounter no enemies at all and nothing interesting to investigate. There's loot, but even though it uses a coloured rarity system the level is really all that matters. The shooting is awkward. There are only a few types of vampires and they also share very few models. 

The game itself is buggy. Controls randomly stop working, menu elements get stuck on screen. You can't pause when playing singleplayer. I really wanted to like Redfall, but it's such a chore to play that I'm not going to continue.

I do think it could be made good, but the game would need to be overhauled rather than just bugfixed. 4/10.

A lot of ink's been spilled over this game already, so I'm going to write about a couple specific reasons why I don't recommend it, at least at its $70 face value. Before diving in, I want to say the graphical issues haven't really bothered me. The art style is very Arkane, and if you like the look of the DIshonored games, you'll like the look of this one.

First and foremost, this game is most like Borderlands, but unlike Borderlands, lacks for variety in its gameplay. Go to a slightly different area of town, shoot the same 10 bad guy models, of which there are 3 variations (SMG guy, shotgun guy, sniper guy), hope for loot. Instead of weaponry exploding everywhere, maybe a bag with some loot in it drops.

Which leads to the second big issue with variety. If it's going to be a co-op loot shooter, the loot and gun play needs to feel great. The UV gun is hilariously fun against vampires, but overall there's a maybe 15-weapon pool, and not a lot of diversity in that pool. However, that's not the most infuriating aspect. That award goes to silencers, which actually work and give you stealth, but there's no way to tell if a gun has one unless you equip the weapon, and you can't add them on later! Not to mention shooting just doesn't feel very tight. You'll line up a headshot with a sniper rifle (with no stabilize button, btw. Come on, it's 2023, and my character is THE SNIPER GUY), and it'll whiff by a foot. You can't tell if it's you, the game, or both.

I have primarily been playing this game in co-op with a friend on Gamepass. The multiplayer is...decent, if I'm being generous? The game certainly feels better with friends, but is hamstrung by bugs, missions hard-locking if your friend takes some actions, etc. Even more annoyingly, there's no drop-in, drop-out element. If your friend DC's, your session terminates and you're back to main menu. Friends can't join on you either--they have to be invited to your session.

What's most upsetting though is that this is a game I actually wanted to like, and just...struggle to find positive things to say about. If my buddy isn't available, it just lives in my library gathering dust. It feels like even after the long delay, this game still walked out the front door feeling unpolished.

Redfall, very clearly, has been received poorly, however I don't believe the game is as bad as most are describing.  You have the obligatory performance issues on random rigs, some AI Jank that can easily be patched, the normal kinds of bugs that you find in an open world like this which can also be patched, etc.  Nothing I would consider game breaking or detrimental to the game, its no Cyberpunk or Darktide release.

The storyline seems meh so far and the world does seem empty..especially in this day and age where we're so used to open world games having literally 20 things to do around each corner.  Maybe this is a good thing, maybe it's not...that's yet to be seen by me. The graphics seem nice, though I think the flashligh is a bit flat and lack luster.  The combat unfortunately is mediocre at best, but perhaps that's just the character I'm currently playing I plan on trying others when I find the time (Grown up life, am I right?).  I have, unfortunately, not been able to play with anyone as no one wants to buy the game with the bad press it's getting so I don't have any idea how the multiplayer is.  

I've experienced some bugs, the biggest and most annoying one for me is enemies will just suddenly stop registering damage and I'll have to stop firing and start again for it to start doing damage again.  It's not me missing or anything like that, they just simply stop taking damage and it appears to be random so it's not anything I can easily reproduce from what I've seen.  For the most part my game play has been unbugged and the game runs well on my Ryzen 3950x and 3090 Ti at  5120x1440.  I've not had any noticeable hitching or frame drops, I've not personally noticed any memory leaks or any strangeness when running the game.  

Is this game great...no, by no means.  Is it bad...to some I'm sure it is but honestly it's not as bad as the hate seems to be making it.  It's a pretty bog standard open world looter shooter with what I would consider normal issues for a game of it's type.  Give it a try, if you really hate it then steam has a great refund policy.

I've seen a lot of flack for this game but while I have some gripes I've still really enjoyed it. I've so far really enjoyed the visual style of the game. The vampires look nosferatu levels of monstrous which is a nice change from modern depictions. The playable characters all seem really unique and despite playing single player I haven't found any situation I can't handle with any particular characters skill sets. Some of the old Arkane "play-your-way" stuff is even still here despite the relative size of the world to their old games (certain buildings will have multiple entry points etc.) For me at least the game performs really well on a intel i5 12600 and a RTX 2080 super on ultra setting at 2k resolution.

My issues with the game are mostly the sort of things that have been included to facilitate multiplayer. The lack of pausing and saving in single player mode for example. The customisation options for guns are a little minimal so buying a particular type of weapon isn't a guarantee of a particular characteristic (silencer). All the other issues are things I would expect to come out in the wash (buggy ai, some non-gamebreaking glitches, etc.)

Overall, I'm having fun in redfall.

TL;DR - Can I recommend this game? Having finished it with a friend on the 3rd (of four) hardest difficulty, I guess the answer is no. 
It is good, in places. It's fun, in places. But if I recommended it to a friend, I'd inevitably feel embarrassed at all the bugs and poor design choices made by the devs. 

Redfall is a game that really needed another year or so of development to realise it's true potential. It's closest to a looter-shooter, sort of like a Borderlands game, but truly open world. It's got two maps that admittedly aren't huge, but you can freely sprint from one side of the map to the other with no loading screens. 
It's full of that Arkane style we all know and love, but at times it does feel empty. Big areas with no enemies that you just skip over heading to the next waypoint. Lots of scattered journals with lore dumps that you are mostly going to skip over and ignore.

The game works as follows: You quickly make your way to the quest hub and pick up a main quest and perhaps a side mission and head out into the world to complete it. Rinse and repeat. They are either fetch quests or kill quests. There are a handful of quick travel points spread across the map, as well as half a dozen safehouses too. The safehouses need to be unlocked, and each have first a quest to complete (one of four types), and then "kill a mini-boss" quest to complete. The safehouse unlocks are required to complete the main story. After you have done the main quests, you defeat the map's boss. Then you move on to map 2 and do it all again.
The loot is quite generic and has a level stat and a quality level. It's not that easy to work out when a weapon with level X is better than a lower level weapon with a better quality, other than 'are numbers bigger ok i pick this one'.

All together these features would make the game acceptable. But what really let's the game design are the cutscenes and AI. 
Firstly the AI is quite basic. Vampires will always teleport and charge you. By backing away and jumping you can usually completely avoid their attacks. The human enemies have that fun feature of once you're spotted, everybody knows exactly where you are instantly. Retreat and hide and reposition, it doesn't matter. They still know where you are. And obviously there have been multiple instances of enemies standing still and glaring at you and doing nothing, seemingly unable to attack.
Secondly the cutscenes. They have clearly been done quickly and spat out. There's no character animation. You're basically watching a comic strip of images with a narrator over the top. Even the few in game ones that you watch (past memories of bosses giving us story exposition) are with static models, very similar to the game Tacoma (an indie game with approx. 4-10 devs). It feels rushed and half-hearted.

Slap on top a plethora of bugs like weapon glitches, unable to melee/stake enemies, T-poses, graphical oddities, a weird one where I slid down some stairs and carried on across the map and turning my vision upside-down, disconnects and the inability to reconnect to any game in progress, fps drops, makes this a poor poor recommendation. 

The problem is in six months many bugs will be squashed, but the rushed feel of the game will remain and will never be fixed. Arkane have already moved on to the next game in line, which I will not be buying.

It's a nice balance between exploring and high stress, high action and deadly combat. Playing intelligently will get you far. Wish more was lootable, but overall very playable. Hasty people or those who don't cooperate with their team will likely die quickly. And they will have earned it.
That being said, the main story is seriously lacking, there are plot holes you could drive a triple semi through, and when we "got to the end" my first (and ongoing) reaction was that this is the first 2 thirds of a story; why the unprintable heck did it get bought and then released without being actually finished.

Got it for free, still not worth playing. AI far too easy even on hardest difficulty (they cant pathfind at all and struggle to hit you even standing still), can literally count the pixels on objects at the highest graphics settings, storyline that consists of reading random papers you find (isn't even worth doing) and bad performance on a 4070 ti somehow despite looking and playing like a 25 year old game. The only thing that made this game a challenge was that ammo was so hard to find for the higher tier guns, but then you just find this magical ammo box that refills everything infinitely. The gunplay is not rewarding or fun, why does a starter pistol do 10 times more damage than a shotgun hitting all pellets at close range? Disappointed. Will consider re-downloading to try again once they improve graphics and AI, but it's a 70$ unfinished product atm.

This is not a great game. 

Even if everything worked, I would have difficulty calling [i]Redfall[/i] a good game.

But I wanted to give it a thumbs up anyway. Partially because I find the hate bandwagon surrounding this game distasteful. I loathe the hyperbole in the negative reviews. I've played worse. A lot worse. I played [i]Fallout 76[/i] on release. 

[i]Redfall[/i] is not a terrible game. It is... aggressively mediocre.

[i]Redfall[/i] does not feel or play like an Arkane game. It is painful to reconcile that this came from the studio that gave us [i]Dishonored, Prey[/i] and [i]Deathloop[/i]. But it [i]does[/i] feel like a Bethesda game. It feels appropriate for a studio trying to pick itself up after the trainwreck (of a train carrying dumpsters, all of which were on fire) that was [i]Fallout 76[/i] and deliver something that's not half-bad.

The open world is well-made. The island of Redfall is fun to explore and have firefights in. The graphics are usually solid, with some occasional greatness. The characters are conceptually unique and fun.

Sadly, the story could be a lot better. I found myself daydreaming of better stories for the game. Worse, the lore is dull. The bits that aren't related to the vampire apocalypse don't flesh out the world in any interesting way. The bits that are about the ongoing horror rarely provoke empathy and never offer intrigue. 

An example of a particularly bad offender is one of the first notes you find: "Fear". The note is a father saying how his wife and baby are staying behind in a shipping crate while he goes out for supplies. He asks how so many normally good people could become cultists for monsters, and tells us the answer is fear. The note isn't written to anyone in particular and has no reason to have been written at all. The father isn't asking for help or pleading for his family or railing at the enemy. There is no quest attached, no exploration it points to. The note is in the cargo container it talks about, and everyone is there dead (except the devs aren't going to show us a dead baby). Worse, the note points out something bizarre, something [i]mysterious[/i], and then tells us there isn't a mystery here and the explanation is as banal and cursory as possible. It reads like the devs telling us not to bother looking beyond the surface level for narrative content.

Still, I had a lot of fun running around the world with my best friend, shooting vampires and cultists as we set up safehouses and stalked the vampire "gods" that rule the island.

And there were moments of brilliance. I won't spoil with an example as they are few and precious. But those moments told me the kind of game this could have been. And should have been.

I would have given this a thumbs up despite so many lackluster elements, but the game has bugs and issues that just started to sap the fun I had found in it. 

Monsters scale to your level, so those bigger damage numbers never feel meaningful. To the contrary, I find myself avoiding combat because I didn't want to level. Leveling just meant that the guns I found which I liked would lose their effectiveness. Sure, it meant I also got skill points, but that brings us to other problems.

The characters are not well balanced. And even when their powers work right, some of them are too situational or limited to be desirable. While Devinder's teleporter is beyond amazing, Layla's elevator is clunky to use and drastically less versatile. And I seriously question the mindset of the devs who decided that a powerful female character's ultimate power should be having a man come and save her. Honestly, that feels gross.

I mostly played Jacob, whose power set seemed custom-made for me. Except of his powers, only the invisibility cloak worked properly. The scouting raven was a crapshoot at best who would regularly fail to notice enemies I could directly see and whose damaging ability procced once in a blue moon. Likewise, by the time we reached Burial Point, the "powerful" headshots that his ultimate was supposed to supply regularly did almost no damage. The ultimate became a liability, locking me out of using effective weapons whenever the spectral sniper rifle decided it wanted to be a nerf gun. Beyond invisibility, Jacob's best and most reliable ability was the special skill of carrying more lockpicks and rewire kits. And even that had an issue: when starting or joining a game, any ammo or supplies carried above the amount allowed without skills would often be lost as the game applied your skills after loading your inventory.

My best friend and I will likely finish the game together. I have no desire to continue to play solo. Nor will I return to it after we finish. 

The game is not worth full price, but I can still recommend it on deep discount if you have someone to play it with. Just don't expect an Arkane game. Expect a fairly fun if generic looter-shooter with a vampire theme.

I would give this game 7/10, and this review will be a little "long" due to that rating. 

I really like this game, it's a lot of fun, I also don't really have any performance issues, it works as it should. I gotten two bugs so far, that isn't game breaking, and that's two different vampires just floating in the air, but don't get damaged when you attack them. But other than that, it's a lot of fun. I like the different types of vampires, I like the different kind of cultists and the story itself. How there's multiple but divided main quests, some fun sidequests, helping the neighbourhoods to make sure the safe houses are actually safe. I haven't tried it out co-op yet, but it's still a lot of fun to play solo as well. 

But I got some things I need to mention that brings it down for me, enough to not give it a higher rating. Ideas that could maybe, be fixed, or not. I don't know. It's more or less just nitpicking from my side.
1. The nests respawns. Which doesn't make any sense if you think about it. You help out in the different neighbourhoods, and then cleanse the nest to get rid of .. well. The nests. So for me it doesn't make sense that all the sudden there's a new one that spawn almost on the exactly spot you already cleanse. It's an annoying grind.
2. You can't pause the game when you are playing solo. I get why, but it's still an annoying factor. I understand you can't do that when you are playing with others, but when you are playing solo. Nah. I don't like that. They should have done like Sons of the Forest.
3. This is just a nitpicking point for me, but maybe other likes it. But you can't upgrade your weapons. So you get this amazing legendary weapon. You level up. Find better weapons but not good in the extras thingies, and have to leave that legendary weapon behind. I don't like that, I wish to be able to upgrade my already good weapons in damage, and level. Use the currency you have in the game to be able to do that. Just, something.

But, despite those three points, I still recommend the game, a lot. Tons of fun :)

Do yourself a favour and play this game all the way through. Just finished the story with friends and really enjoyed the story. Since the update Multi is working better and game seems to be saving game play better.  No I just need to finish the game on solo. I'm looking forward to the Dlc. :D

Is it fun? With friends, yes very much, i am enjoying it and i am looking forward to overhauls and fixes (though i do not justify that it came out in this state).

Now... it's pretty fucking unforgivable to have a shitty mouse sensitivity bar that only counts in integers, some people like me like shooters very much and like their sensitivity to be VERY precise, if not i will feel uncomfortable and generally have a worse time playing, but it even more unforgivable to NOT have a ADS Mouse sensitivity multiplier! WHY !? ADS-ing in this game is pretty shit, they put an arbitrary multiplier and, at least for me, is pretty fucking slow, i hate it.

Now, from Jr Dev to Dev studio:
- Change the hit detector and pathfinding on the vampire, you can get them stuck in stuff like cars, they think they can hit you but there is a car in between so they do not hit you, and since they think they can hit you, they just don't go around the object in between, ez kill stupid vampire, how does this made it past play testing?

- For the human enemies, they feel like they shoot randomly and barely hit anything, but when they do, they generally hit fairly hard, i'd rather have them hit me more often and less hard, it would make the player feel "overwhelmed", forcing me to take cover, because, OH BOY i do NOT take cover i just run to them and overwhelm them myself, i know they will miss most of their shots, so i am pretty much able to take out a group of 4-5 without much trouble.

- And lastly the games, a lot of times, and in boss fights, feels very tailored to 1 or maybe 2 players, underbosses have very little health, even though they are "special" and the main bosses are the same, 2 of my friends and i killed the first mayor boss very easily, felt very very anticlimatic, specially since he had a "super villian" origin and was supposed to be very powerfull, i didn't even noticed if the boss did any special attacks or anything... having said that, the 3-4 times that my friends and i have actually all died was because the game decided to spawn about 10 vampires and another 10 humans and... well vampires hit often and hit very hard (the pathfinding idiocy i described earlier is barely present with friends, since they chance target).

As for the length i am 19 hours in and i haven't finished it, whoever says it's a 10 hour game either speed ran this bitch, or is just lying, as any open world, take your time, read stuff, do side missions, have fun.

I do not like that it is quite broken and feels more like an early access, but the game itself is quite fun, hopefully they will not abandon it soon, hopefully more content and fixes will come because it's fun, it's just not finished.

This release did Arkane very bad, Arkane Lyon has done an amazing job with their games. 
Actually i would've wished they made this game with Void Engine and not UE4...

I will gladly change my recommendation if and when some of these changes are released.

4/10.  This was a baffling game.  

On one hand the story and voice acting were intriguing and engaging.  I enjoyed learning about the main story through a well thought out combination of in-game notes, voice recordings, and in-game  "psychic flashbacks."  Reminded me a bit of FEAR where you're trying to figure out what caused this, who the mysterious cast of characters are, what are their backstories, etc.  

On the other hand, the open world gameplay is barren of enemies and the enemy AI that is around is just plain awful.  It's downright embarrassing for a AAA game that was $70.  For much of the game you are just walking around between the town and coming across set pieces where you think, "this would be fun to fight around if there were enemies," but they're nowhere to be seen.  There's also a ridiculous amount of bugs.  Enemies that are stuck standing still, enemies that are there moving around but can't be attacked, loading to black screens where other players can see you but you can't move, killed enemies falling through the floor so you can't loot them.  

Bottom line, don't buy this game for anything more than $20.  Maybe ever.  Even if they fixed the bugs I think the core problems with enemy AI may be too much to overcome.  High five to the story writers and voice actors of this game.  Everyone else involved, shame on you for releasing this garbage.

This game is a looter shooter similar to games like borderlands. The map is a medium sized open world, however many of the buildings are not enterable. Enemies do make some pretty basic moves, but for me the Vampires have been a more interesting enemy. Below are my pros and cons.

Neutral comments:
Environment is non interactive. Car windows do not smash out, tires do not go flat. Doors do not change with damage. 
The only executions are staking vampires.

Pro:
Gun play is fun and satisfying for me,
Characters are pretty cool.
Straightforward gameplay makes it quick for me to get the handle of.
Music is actually pretty good, I usually mute the music but this one i keep on.
Vampire enemies teleport short distances causing me to miss shots and keep mobile to avoid getting mobbed down.

Cons:
Enemies arent very challenging on Medium difficulty. Minions tend to miss their shots if they are about 30-40 feet away even when you are standing still, though enemy snipers havent missed me yet.
Vampires can be encountered rarely during the daytime. While they react to the UV spotlights, they do not react to direct sunlight.
Vampire pathing doesnt let them climb things to chase you and their attacks are easy to dodge.
Vampires are mostly a threat when there are 4 or 5 of them.
When loading new parts of the map, my frame rate takes a dip due to the amount of stuff loading. I am running everything on max graphics and I am rocking a RTX3060, 32GB ram, and a Ryzen5600x

What I want to see in coming updates:
Enemies need a buff in both AI, Accuracy, and Attack speed.
Something to help the framerate drop in new areas.
Maybe a vampire mode? Where you get to play as a vampire and take over the map and kill rival vampires?

All in all, I would reccomend playing this game when it is discounted or on the gamepass. I paid the full price by choice as I love vampires and want to support the devs. Let's not forget how No Man's Sky went. It is an amazing game now too!

Combat is very simple no challenge to that what so ever. Vampires don't seem good path-finding. to have  At time character models also do not load in. If you're looking for a fun co-op shooter to play with friends turn to the border lander's series, call of duty, and/or red dead. This game is not worth the current price.

For all the negative reviews out there this game is surprisingly fun to play. The game came with my video card and I really didnt have high hopes for it. This will allow me to game some while waiting for Diablo 4.

What can I say, it's addictive fun. I'm playing at medium difficulty and I can enjoy myself at that level. The graphics are fine, and with some patches the issues with stuttering when traversing in some areas, and the AI getting iffy at times, and other assorted bugs, will hopefully get sorted out. I got the game when I purchased a nVidia card, I'm not sure if that means I got it for free. I'm figuring "free" means a promotional copy.

"I'm getting stretched out," moans my character as I walk towards a cultist, firing my gun. He doesn't realise I'm there - he's got question marks over his head and he's looking directly at me, but no one around him retaliates. The AI is less responsive than my grandma before we pulled the plug (don't worry, she was brain dead and electricity ain't cheap in this economy.)

I've got special abilities - I don't  need any of them on the hardest difficulty.

I stand beneath a giant, frozen-in time tidal-wave: there's something off, though...The shadows make no sense, shadows are cast on objects that aren't consistent with their position to the light sources.

A vampire tells me I'll never see the sun again as we stand in a sunny street.

My friend doesn't walk, and neither do I: most of the time we simply *slide* when we're not half in the ground. Redfall thought it had a problem with Vampires, but it's really the gun-toting psychic mole people.

I return to my special Firehouse to find the NPCs all T-posing. Often, there are duplicates of them. The priest - who I think is a man every time I look at her - has a clone. This clone has ascended to Godhood: her head IS a light source.

There's a story. The kind've story where a greasy, slick corporate representative walks up to you with a skateboard and their hat on backwards and says "Hello, fellow kids," or Hillary Clinton tries to convince you she's not a bearded-dragon wearing a human-suit by telling you cute anecdotes about how she has hot sauce in her purse.

There are games with this same formula more than a decade old, with a lesser budget, that work better than this game. Everything feels wrong: the walking, the gun play, the vertical tool tips that take up a quarter or more of your screen in combat and require you to hold a key for several seconds to dismiss them. It's almost like Redfall got very cursory play testing. I can't blame Bethesda though: Fallout 76 ended up being successful, so why wouldn't this? Why bother releasing games in finished states when you can just push them out like an unripened turd and still have people buy it. 

Thank God Phil Spencer apologised for the state of this game, because that really makes up for this being pushed out. Someone cue up the clip of the BP Oil CEO saying "I'm sorry" that South Park did a few years ago.

The only thing Redfall got right is that it has an "uninstall", but you could argue it's deadliest flaw is letting you install it to begin with.

Some additional research has revealed that the Austin Branch of Arkane Studio is looking for an entire team of people to develop a game. Probably the one they just released.

Edit to initial review:

It has been a month since this game released. I posted my initial review with a recommend with the belief that the dev team would take immediate action to rectify some of their most glaring mistakes and to fix the game breaking bugs that have undermining playing the game (I am still experiencing post-hotfix crashes upon loading in). Since release, I have seen no news from devs regarding a game plan for fixing the obvious bugs and glitches that we have all experienced. There has also been no word on how they are planning to move forward from this disaster launch. This is beyond disappointing given the public failure and the fairly vocal admissions from the dev team that this game was a train wreck throughout its development. 

To have no plan, no major fixes, and no promise of delivering on at least some semblance of the quality that was promised after a month is pitiful. I am not feeling hopeful that they are going to take responsibility for fixing this game, so I am changing to not recommending under any circumstances. You can read my initial review if you want to see what I was hoping for, but this is where I stand now.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
So, I have very mixed feelings about this game:
Initial/Current Cons:
-World feels empty (lacks mobs, can't enter most buildings, small maps)
-Story is boring and lacks clear immersive plot (lack of cutscenes cinematics, lack of clear main plot purpose, not many quests and they don't build plot lines)
-Buggy (originally just the stuttering and freezing, now game breaking constant crashes after hotfix)
-NOT ENOUGH CONTENT/QUALITY TO JUSTIFY PRICE TAG 

This last one hurts. It feels like a betrayal of the community for putting faith in them to at least provide us with the most basic, minimum standard that a games plot line and core building blocks used to demand. I understand inflation plays a role in this price jump, but that Microsoft pushed this, and then by their own admission failed to invest the  resources into this game necessary to bring it up to promised standards simply because it was already under way is a slap in the face. With gamers now facing these kinds of price tags and receiving quality and content quantity of this level, it destroys trust and studios are going to be facing these opening week severe review bombs and backlash for it.

Now, I said I had mixed feelings about this game. When I initially started playing, I came in biased. I impulse bought the game the day before it released despite telling myself to hold back and wait to see reviews. Before I could play, floods of negative reviews came in regarding quality and content, which killed my initial disposition towards the game. These reviews were accurate and my initial start was buggy and empty (cons above). I asked for refund, but missed the 2 hour cut off by a few minutes (take that as you will). I decided to invest in the game a bit more, restart, change the graphics based on posts to reduce stutters, and upped the difficulty as far as I could (Midnight). Here is what I found when I put a few more hours into the game:

Potential Pros:
-As you progress slightly past the initial fights and quests, it seems like you get a higher spawn rate of elite vampires that spice up combat (combat AI and spawn rates still need improvement)
-Once the initial stuttering was fixed with graphic/video changes, game was largely playable (Still lacks dynamic fighting that this kind of close quarters vampire combat game should have - I still feel like I walk into battle, would prefer to need to run, parkour, and have higher level of melee given what we fight)

This does not appear to be much in the way of pros, but I think that these are core issues that would have likely improved dispositions towards the game and could leave people with a better opinion later when this game gets needed patches and eventually (at this rate soon) goes on sale. There are still severe core issues that probably are unfixable now that the game has launched, but for what it is, if these elements are fixed, they will get a reasonable following. The game should not have ever been hyped to the extent that it was nor been the roll out game for a new pricing regime. These are company mistakes that Microsoft and the studio should learn from. If the game had improved difficulty and combat by drawing from recent games like Dying Light 2 and even Cyberpunk (I know its a sore spot but the core game mechanics were interesting and it had a decent plot), this game could have been decent in my opinion.

I am recommending this game purely under a condition that they invest time into actually fixing issues that are within their power to fix. There is no reason to believe there will be a full plot overhaul (at this point simply implementation) and integration of more dynamic combat and open world mechanics to the extent of the examples above. 

I also do not recommend buying this game at current list price at any time. Honestly, you should wait 4-6 months before even looking at this game, then wait for a 50-75% off sale. However, I choose to have faith that by then the studio will have found a direction to work towards and salvage the game in part.

Redfall is a massive stain on the legacy of Arkane, and an absolute travesty of a videogame. When I heard they were releasing a co-op shooter, I thought it was a strange move, but they would knock it out of the park like they'd done with their previous games. But everything about this experience is a failure. 
The world and story are lifeless and bland, with little to know meaningful environmental storytelling like you'd find in Prey or Dishonoured. Enemy AI is atrocious, with absolutely no intelligence behind their combat or movement. The gameplay is clunky and overall just feels off to play. And to tie it all together, performance is abysmal. The worst though is that the game is just plain bad though, disregarding the functionality and performance, there is nothing endearing or enjoyable here, no personality or identity, it's lifeless.
This is another case of a developer falling into the live-service trap, and if I didn't buy this from another storefront, I would have refunded immediately.
Save yourself

If it gets the patches it deserves then I'll pick it back up in the future! Feels like a perfect autumn game, shame they weren't given the time to release it more towards the end of the year.

It's Far Cry 5 with loot, vampires and odd graphics (seriously, the people look weird). If that sounds fun to you, check it out. It's nowhere near as bad as the internet dog-piling would have everyone believe. I've had a lot of fun exploring Redfall.

Redfall is an open world FPS featuring both single player and co-op modes. Starting the game, you can choose between four playable characters, each one with their unique abilities. The game is set in the town of Redfall (Massachusetts, US) during a vampire apocalypse that blocked the sun and caused the waters to recede. As one of the few remaining survivors, you will fight against multiple vampire Lords while investigating their appearance and trying to break the island‚Äôs curse. Unlike zombies, there aren‚Äôt many games featuring vampires, so it certainly feels refreshing to play one (while we patiently wait for [i]VTM Bloodlines 2[/i]). The setting often reminded me of [i]Salem‚Äôs Lot[/i] and the more recent [i]Midnight Mass[/i], which I love. Unfortunately, the story of Redfall is not engaging due to the lack of interesting secondary characters & antagonists. Cutscenes are like cheap static images from a storyboard showing how the real cutscenes should have been, if they were really made. I can‚Äôt understand how they let this happen and, considering the AAA increased price, this is totally unacceptable. Main quests are decent enough thanks to the variety of locations, while secondary ones are the classic ‚Äúgo there and find this item‚Äù or ‚Äúgo there and kill this enemy‚Äù. Keep in mind that completing some secondary quests is also mandatory for unlocking the final main quest, in case you are thinking of simply rushing through the story. You can‚Äôt replay any completed quest, so right now some achievements can only be obtained if you make one or two more playthroughs or if you are lucky enough to play the same mission differently through co-op.

The gunplay has been improved thanks to the collaboration with ID Software. While still not perfect, it feels smoother than any previous Arkane game. There is decent variety in weapons too, ranging from pistols and shotguns to flareguns and stake launchers. Each weapon can be customized with different skins and has a level or rarity in the following order: white, green, blue, purple and orange. Unfortunately, you won‚Äôt find any unique weapons and you will often swap between the same ones with different levels. For some weird reason there are no throwables, such as grenades or molotov. The game‚Äôs tutorial tells you that stealth is also an option, yet it feels really bad, like there isn‚Äôt even an animation for the silent takedown and you just punch human enemies in the back hoping they will instantly die (sometimes they don‚Äôt). Enemies are not very varied and you will often fight vampires, gangs of human cultists and mercenary soldiers, who also tend to fight each other. Their AI is one of the worst I have ever seen and completely ruins the combat experience. Enemies often stand still and stare at you or look in the wrong direction even when you are shooting at them; they have incredibly slow reaction times so you can kill them easily. Even the final bosses are affected, with Jacob‚Äôs invisibility power capable of breaking their AI as it continuously swaps between normal mode and combat mode.

If you played [i]Dishonored[/i], [i]Prey[/i] or [i]Deathloop[/i], you know that level design is what Arkane makes best. Redfall‚Äôs environments are fascinating to explore, buildings can be accessed in multiple ways, interiors are greatly detailed, particularly the ones connected to main missions. Level design is what kept me playing the game, wanting to know what I could find inside the lighthouse I saw from the distance, inside a hidden cave or a giant mansion heavily guarded. It‚Äôs a pity that the rest of the game doesn‚Äôt have the same quality. While Arkane said the game was perfectly playable as a single player (and that is true), the experience is built around co-op, so it‚Äôs not really much fun alone. Characters are meant to compensate each other and while playing as Jacob, who is a stealth hero with the abilities of detecting enemies behind walls, becoming invisible for a short time and instantly sniping everyone, I realized I could use some more offensive abilities to make combat more varied and engaging. Despite being alone, characters and enemies often refer to you as a group of people, fast travelling starts a 5-second countdown, missions must be accepted in a briefing room so you must always fast travel to your HQ to start them. All this was clearly designed for co-op, yet for some reason there is no public matchmaking, meaning you need to have friends who are willing to spend this amount of money to buy the game and invite them to your lobby. Even then, only the host maintains the story progression while the other players can only keep the experience and gear collected, so when they return to their world they must play the story missions again. I think this was a terrible mistake and that Arkane should have just copied [i]Borderlands[/i], where you can join public lobbies and skip missions already completed on someone else‚Äôs playthrough. Another horrible thing is that even when playing alone the game constantly needs an online connection. If for any reason you lose it for one second, you will get kicked and lose any unsaved progress. This is unacceptable, if I‚Äôm playing alone there should be no reason to stop me from going offline.

Technically speaking, the game is plagued by many problems: textures not loading or taking too long to load, enemies glitching inside walls or suddenly spawning close to you, enemies walking backwards, objects floating mid-air, dead bodies changing their position, hero t-posing in the character menu, crouch and start button no longer working (on controller), parts of the world feeling empty and much more. It seems like the game was heavily rushed for release, which is also visible with the poor performance. It doesn‚Äôt matter what settings you change, you won‚Äôt notice any frame-rate difference but you will often get frame drops that will ruin your experience. The game also includes Denuvo anti-tamper, which may be the cause of some problems.


[table]
    [tr]
        [th] ‚úÖ Pros [/th]
        [th] ‚ùåCons [/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]
‚Ä¢ Gunplay improvements for an Arkane game (thanks to ID Software)

‚Ä¢ Fascinating setting and detailed interiors
[/td]
        [td]
‚Ä¢ Bland story and secondary characters

‚Ä¢ Cheap images as cutscenes

‚Ä¢ Always online (even when playing alone)

‚Ä¢ One of the worse AI in videogames

‚Ä¢ No public matchmaking and bad co-op progression

‚Ä¢ Horrible stealth implementation

‚Ä¢ Impressive quantity of technical issues

‚Ä¢ Poor optimization and Denuvo anti-tamper
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]


[h1]Verdict: 6/10[/h1]
Despite a bland story, horrible cutscenes and lack of interesting characters, Redfall could be a sufficiently enjoyable co-op experience if you like the setting and can wait for all the technical issues to be fixed (as well a substantial price-drop). The always-online requirement must be removed, online matchmaking must be added, the co-op progression must be expanded, and the optimization must be improved. Right now it is impossible to really recommend Redfall with all these issues and the insane price, but this is still an Arkane game, even if it‚Äôs the worst one they‚Äôve made to date.

Performace has a lot to work on, but generally I find it really fun to play and usually average about 60fps@1440p High settings with a 6700XT and 3600X paired with 32GB@3200MHz.

The gameplay loop is addictive, the missions are serviceable, and it's a nice co-op romp.

As of this review, I've played an hour on Steam and 10 hours through Game Pass. No crashes or major issues other than random FPS drops. If those don't bother you, it's worth a shot. You can see within 2 hours if it's worth your dime.

Some of you might‚Äôve thought I was silly for giving Redfall a positive review when it first came out ‚Äî especially with its original price tag. But I didn‚Äôt just judge it by launch day. I looked ahead, saw the potential, and I‚Äôm proud to say I still stand by that decision. And now? I‚Äôm SO proud they changed the game price ‚Äî a big step in the right direction.

Let‚Äôs talk positives first:
Redfall nails multiplayer and interaction. It‚Äôs got that classic co-op magic ‚Äî from hoarding loot and exploring every corner of the map to laughing at weird glitches or strategizing through chaotic fights. The story is strong, with a sort of retro Left 4 Dead vibe and killer cutscenes that feel like they belong in a comic book. There are tons of skins for characters and weapons, multiple difficulty levels, and a satisfying level-up and ability system. No two characters or enemies feel the same, and I love how you‚Äôre constantly stumbling into random encounters around the map. The combat even lets you shoot while downed (which saves lives more than you‚Äôd think), and characters have unique voice lines that make them feel alive. You can dodge attacks, and yes ‚Äî sliddeee.

Now the not-so-great stuff:
The original pricing was definitely rough, and only one save slot per person is really limiting, especially when you want to restart a character. Some guns can‚Äôt be accessorized (missed opportunity), and the intro screen is not only boring ‚Äî it‚Äôs loud. There's lag in some areas, which will likely be fixed in time, and it‚Äôs a little annoying that you have to check the missions tab to see if something is complete. I also really wish we could decorate the safe house ‚Äî there‚Äôs so much potential there. And for my Remi mains: it would be awesome if her launch pads could double as explosives.

Graphics-wise, if you like that gritty, stylized retro vibe from Left 4 Dead, this is your lane. And while the story already brings a lot to the table (with a few light puzzles), I‚Äôd love to see even more side quests you discover naturally instead of everything starting at your safe place.

For starters, I have been playing this on the Steam Deck with minimal issues, aside from a few crashes.

Look, I'll be honest with you: a lot of the negative comments and the criticism is absolutely founded. For example, the game shipped out with buggy AI, capped FPS that still stutters, a talent tree that cannot be respec'd, and a whole host of issues.

Having said this, I've still found some entertaining gameplay value in this title. For example, the stealth mechanics are barebones but still make for some interesting combat options. The gunplay and the mechanics of the guns feels great but it's mired by an odd UI inventory system; there are moment of genuine eeriness when haunting voices coming from another room chant "the blood the blood the blood the blood the blood", but after a couple of hours, it gets stale.

I am hoping that this game will get better because it's too late for a refund, so I suppose the TLDR: absolutely avoid this game until it's deeply discounted.

Nothing original. Routine gore comedy. The gore value is supposed to give the viewer a trendy feeling. But there's nothing new here. Therapy scene was stolen from Austin Powers but with more gore of course. Silly fighting scenes, the usual underdog antihero guy who finds a girl he likes. Silly mafia villains. Hollywood thinks very lowly of it's audience. I like Nicholas Cage but other than a cliched silly Dracula with too much gore makeup and bad teeth, he adds very little here. Nicholas Hoult is the sympathetic guilty-victim. His part is thin with a very silly superpower boost. There's implied depth to his character but nothing of any substance in the script. At best a one time view for curiosity. The game thinks of much more than it is.

At the time/price of writing, this game is not worth $70. I went into the game aware that the campaign was fairly short compared to other games in this genre and price range, and was fully prepared to accept the 20ish hours of curated content for a decent endgame cycle. And that's where it finally lost me... This is the first looter/shooter I've ever played that has ABSOLUTELY NO ENDGAME CONTENT, a topic that seemed deceitfully avoided prior to release.

I'd change this to a positive review with a free update that adds, at least, something to do after the campaign other than doing it again... or half my money refunded.

Spent a good amount of time doing all the missions, looking for collectibles etc. Here's my thoughts after completing the campaign.

PROS

Good atmosphere
Good soundtrack 
Solid story, I liked the ending
Combat is solid
Staking vampires is incredibly satisfying, does not get old. 


CONS

A number of strange and just plain dumb design choices. The world is open, but not really. You have to be on the specific missions for things like keys to spawn. There's no real point in exploring if you arent on the correct mission.
There are two maps, but after you finish the first one, you can't go back. When you finish the final mission, the game ends and you are forced to do NG+. You cannot go back for side missions or collectibles.
The collectibles are ridiculously tedious. They are very well hidden and you cannot track them.
The talent tree has tiers, you have to save points for higher levels so you end up saving a lot of points. 
The AI gets stuck on things and is pretty dumb in general.
Why are lock picks limited? Why is not just an unlocking mini game? 

Overall, fun if you like the core gameplay loop but very rough. Certainly not worth $70. 6.5/10

[b]Short answer:[/b] If the game piques your interest, then get it on deep sale. I had a decent amount of fun with it at times, but I can't picture even a fully-patched [i]and[/i] enhanced version of this game that is worth its $70 price tag. The price is pretty insulting in its launch state.

[b]Long answer:[/b] There's a decent shooter here buried beneath a mountain of bugs, an uninteresting story, and some questionable design decisions.

The guns are pretty satisfying in both sound and feel, and their power generally feels significant so long as you keep up with the looter shooter grind by replacing your favorites frequently with their higher-numbered counterparts. Think Borderlands with a much more conservative number of items to sift through. I appreciate the streamlining. The game is also generally good at providing a decent number of fast travel points, preventing the fatigue of running all the way across a zone.

But that's where the good stuff ends for me. That traversal is actually slowed greatly by red mist scattered generously throughout the map, and which can only be eliminated (temporarily) by shooting a target with a specific weapon type--one which you may not generally bother having equipped. You'll either have to open the cumbersome menu to swap out weapons in one of your (extremely conservative) three slots, or use one of a few of the characters' traversal mechanics on a very long cooldown in order to bypass the red mist. By the way, the game [i]doesn't[/i] pause when you're in menus, even when you're playing solo. (I understand the developers are supposed to be working on an offline mode that I assume will actually behave like a proper single-player game, but it is not ready as of the time I'm reviewing it.)

Beyond the frustrations of movement, there are numerous game-breaking bugs. You will find progress thwarted by immortal enemies or key items falling outside of reachable space. You might get booted from the game even when playing alone because you lost connection to a server. These are things that can theoretically be patched, but the rate of development being done on the game post-launch is (so far) not encouraging, so I wouldn't hold my breath waiting for fixes.

Even if you somehow dodge bugs, you'll be faced with a predictable, fairly boring story accompanied by uninteresting fetch quests that clearly try to tug at your heart strings. And speaking of fetch quests, you'll often find yourself having to scour every inch of a building to find the magic collection of pixels representing an item you need to progress. At times, it's infuriating.

Redfall will waste your time in numerous ways. There's some decent combat with some heavily-repeated enemy types in there, but the story is unremarkable and the map is somehow even more frustrating to traverse than Borderlands' open, empty spaces (on top of having plenty emptiness of its own).
Despite what the community thinks the game is really fun

What a disappointment. Gameplay is nothing spectacular, storyline is absolutely standard, NPC are not interesting, weapons are generic.

I was awaiting this game because I'm easy to please when it comes to vampire games, and had planned to play it with a friend. While I had fun with my friend, this is not really difficult : having fun when playing coop is dumb easy, as long as there is a vague gameplay.

Still, the fun I had killing enemies with terrible AI doesn't make the flaws of the game less apparent. But the real shame is that it could have been so much better. There are ideas beneath the pile of blandness. The bits in "memories" have interesting visuals, for instance, that hint at environments that could have been spectacular to play through. Some skills are somewhat amusing to use.

But... this just doesn't come close to being enough. Also, the storytelling is terrible : why so much text, in my fast action-paced shooter ? Who's got time to read tons of diary entries or letters ? Why do the memories kill the pace so much too ?

The enemies : not very varied. Four or five types of vampires, and cultists that all act the same (shoot you), and they take a crazy long time to react to having you in front of them.

We played in highest difficulty and took less than 12 hours to finish, while doing all the side quests we found on our way and liberating all safehouses we found.

All the time I found myself comparing this game with another, far superior "Coop FPS with set characters and quests" : Borderlands. And Borderlands is better in all regards :
- Fun, varied weapons
- Varied builds
- Amusing quests
- Entertaining dialogs
- Broad type of enemies

This is not worth 70‚Ç¨. I had much higher expectations of Arkane and it's a shame they delivered this.

If you want to play a coop shooter, just buy Borderlands instead.

Alright time to review since I have put in more than enough time to have a valid opinion and not 10 mins played and crapped all over it before I even got out of the tutorial(cough cough) Love the game! I get everyone will have their opinions and different experiences based on the rig and or console you are running on but for me, no issues. I have had fps drops from time to time but honestly I have had that with every game i play so its nothing new and nothing to cry about. I have never been kicked, no lag, graphics are all on max and I am usually at a stable 130+ fps. Yes NPCs are silly but that doesn't make or break a game for me since who cares?? I don't whine and go on a massive rant because the npc isn't realistic and if this is something that bothers you to the extent of throwing a massive toddler tantrum then go touch grass and step away because dude... you are too involved. Its not that deep. Game is more than playable and its even....ahh wait for it... ENJOYABLE (BOOM) if people would just step down off their high horse for a sec... imagine...

There is a great game somewhere here, but it is unpolished and kinda ugly. Some Arkane brilliance does show from time to time, their level design is still there, but this is no Prey, Dishonored or Deathloop. It seems like a mixture of a half dozen half baked ideas put together and Arkane just wished for the best. AI is total sh!t too. Exploration is interesting, Redfall is a nice town to explore, but this exploration is buried by the combat...which I did not enjoy, partially due to the poor AI and I feel like the hit boxes don't always workout. This game needs serious life support or last rites.

P.S. The optimization is just fvcked.

So, I would not recommend to buy this at this time. Wishlist this and wait until the performance issues are repaired and more content is added. 

Bad first, the performance is trash. for how it looks, this should not stutter and drop FPS as much as it does. 
A lot of people here complain about the game being empty and the AI being dumb and yes, the AI is absolutely lobotomised. Some simple changes to normal enemy behaviour, such as seeking cover, reacting to allies dying and faux flanking would give them a lot more life. I always liked how the AI in the Division 2 functioned in their open world.
The vampires are fine. They jump around chaotically and hit you. 

I actually like that the town of Redfall is largely abandoned. Its creepy. A few more random events here and there, aside from faction encounters could be fun though. Again, a lot can be taken from the Division 2 playbook. D2 was formulaic, but full of stuff to do.

The artstyle and the athmosphere work great together. If the environment was a bit more dynamic, with rain, wind or even storms, it would elevate the experience even more. I love the vampires. They are always gloating, they wear high collars and have slicked back hair. The fact that you have to stake them to kill them. Just great. Even the human factions are kinda interesting, but they don't really function differently. Cultists have poison grenades and PMCs have turrets. Thats pretty much it.  
Guns are strange. The animations and sounds are serviceable, even cool sometimes, but aiming feels... swimmy? Might be my settings though.

So me personally, I can spend a lot of time in this game. It works for me, even if its absolutely halfbaked. I can definitely understand a lot of the negative feedback, but this game can still be repaired, if technical fixes and additions to content can be expected.

It's good fun, don't believe the anti-hype. 

The art is GLORIOUS and the world-building is thick and rich. The playable characters interact with one another in an organic fashion, and have charming conversations. There's a metroidvania feel to exploring the world of Redfall, as you unlock various areas and become strong enough to go to new places and face new enemies.

Certainly not without its issues currently. The combat feels a bit stiff, and mouse aiming can feel sluggish when switching to it from other games. The ability to collect items and notes can be hampered or delayed at times. The player skills and powers are a bit lacklustre for now, and thus can be easy to forget.

Recommended to enjoy the game with your usual co-opmates, don't take it too seriously. It's not L4D, but it's not meant to be. It's an open world vampire-killing exploration story, with spiritual references to a bunch of games, and pure Arkane blood running through its veins.

Reccomended also to let them iron out some bugs, tighten up the meta, and tweak the performance before you pass your final judgement. Currently it's not AAA but it definitely has the potential, and I have strong faith that it will get to where it should be after a few patch cycles. 

Remember the Bethesda bug curse, and the pandemic that knocked a lot of projects around.

Overall recommended; if you can look past the launch clumsiness, find yourself a nice discount somewhere, and are willing to stick with the game through a few growing pains, I think you'll enjoy the world of Redfall.

Loving the game so far. I have been stealthily exploring every building, trailer park and neighborhood in between missions. The ambiance and feel of the world is great if you take the time to look around and enjoy it. I like how the story is being told so far through not just the story line missions but also through other means found while exploring. For myself the game looks and sounds great with the exception of the occasional FPS stuttering. It does have a few issues that I feel need some attention. First and foremost is the enemy AI. About 30% of the encounters I have had feel very fluid and action packed. While the other 70% of encounters have felt like I am either playing Whack-a-Mole or red light, green light with the enemy. They will just stand there for 3-6 seconds and look at you. Once you start shooting them, they might start looking confused and walking around like Pres. Biden trying to leave a stage or they may just stand there and take their death.  My second issue is the lack of match making. I can't really understand how that was never implemented to start with as it is pretty standard for today's games. I don't just friend everyone that I come into contact with while gaming. So with a smaller group of friends, getting a group together is kind of a pain in the butt. Hence the reason I haven't spoken to how any of the group game play feels. I am really looking forward to whats to come with further updates and expansions for Redfall. 

PS: For everyone whining about the cost being $70 USD - $100 USD. Get over it. It's called inflation. If you don't understand that or if you don't like how much something costs, simply don't buy it and move on.

Ok, the negative reviews are a bit harsh. Give the game a chance. It is like Secret World and Dishonored had a child game. I am enjoying the game play and have no technical issues. I have run into a couple gun fights where the enemy hit box is very small. Overall, I like the atmosphere and theme. looking forward to the game being optimized. Net net, breath and enjoy the game this software company tried to develop. Over time it will be as good as Dishonored. Side note, for those that complain about the exaggerated characters features then I guess you never played a Dishonored game. Before you judge please take into consideration that it take a lot for a game studio to develop a game. For me the Dishonored style of character is awesome & different. Side note, I had the game on the XBOX PC game pass and opted to buy it on Steam to support the studio. Yes, I am a veteran gamer and have patience for games being released!!

I really wanted to like this game.  I liked the Dishonored games and loved Prey, so I assumed I would get something along those lines and pre-ordered.  What I got instead was:

1) An open world with virtually nothing interesting to discover
2) A game with essentially 2 different enemies to kill endlessly 
3) character choices whose abilities barely have an impact on gameplay
4) Miniboss encounters so poorly designed that you can 1-2 shot them before they even make a move.
5) a set of two types of quests (fetch and kill this miniboss/boss)

It's pretty and it was fun for about the first two hours, until you realize the aforementioned points.  Don't spend more than $15 for this game.

So, I know alot of people have been feeling the hate for this game, I have read ALOT of reviews and seen alot of repeat issues being mentioned, I am playing on EPIC setting on a relatively new PC and i have had no fps drops , no latency, no performance related issues , and i know several people who have also played with similar setups and have had low to zero issues in this department, so the game would seem ( too me) to be set up with higher system requirements than was originally stated, in order to run smoothly. Not a complaint just a observation. As for the AI , people have complained about it but i have had enemies take a hit and seek cover, Vamps shade step around my arc lance ( Devinder ) to dodge it, the AI seems solid at some points and basic at others, Definitely not the glass lickers other reviews have suggested but still open for improvement. The gunplay is rather nice, I would have liked some gun modding as an option, but the fact that i can loot the same gun and get three different scopes, and 3 different sets of perks is kinda nice, i haven't experienced the hit registration issue others have mentioned,  that could be a latency issue on their end. As for difficulty , the first region of the game felt a little easy even on midnight (second highest difficulty ), but once i got to the next region the entire difficulty dynamic shifted and i am considering adjusting it back down to normal, haven't yet , i enjoy the challenge. Overall  this game feels like it has ALOT of potential, i am enjoying it, I will NOT recommend that anyone with a older system pick it up atm , from what i have read you will be forced to play on low settings and may end up still being annoyed, but if you have a newer system and enjoy looter shooters, definitely recommend. hope to see more dlc and improvements in the near future.

About 6 years ago i was in a bad car accident that left me paralysed from the neck down and mute. My only real, effective way of communicating is by blinking (once for yes, twice for no etc). I have always been a huge gamer and my brother has too. When i lost the ability to play for myself i fell into a spiralling depression. All those hours i spent with steam friends, all those amazing memories, never to be repeated. My brother, bless him, picked up on this and offered to play the games I wanted to FOR me while i sat behind him in my wheelchair and watched. With tears in my eyes i agreed and i have been playing vicariously through him ever since. When Redfall was announced we both became super hyped and i couldn't wait to watch him play it. After pre-ordering it and waiting about 3 weeks the wait was almost over. He pre-loaded the game and after 2 more excruciating days of waiting we finally got to play it. He wheeled me into my favourite spot just behind my old computer chair loaded it up and selected our character. After watching him play for 4 agonizing hours i couldn't take it anymore, with the holy will of God himself i screamed internally at my muscles to obey me, I just needed them this one last time, I had to make it stop. With every ounce of strength i had I slowly pushed myself out of that wheelchair and hobbled over to the computer. Not knowing how long this divine power would last i shoved my brother aside and desperately fumbled with the mouse and keyboard to write a refund request. As i watched and waited for my confirmation e-mail with tears in my eyes i knew that while my body had been healed, my mind would never be the same. 

God bless you Arkane Austin for giving me my autonomy back.

Its a soulless game. The story is unintresting, the world is empty and my god is the AI dumb...

Pro's:
-The looting system isn't half bad.
Thats it really

Cons:
- Very boring and unintresting story.
- The 4 characters you get to play are the woke, overenthousiastic hipster type. The way they behave themselves and talk.... In a vampire apocalypse? In a vampire apocalypse people would be scared shitless.... The people like the playable characters would be among the first to die in an actual apocalypse...
-The quests make no sense. Things like, fix the popcorn machine and put flowers on my brothers grave.... Come on... Its an apocalypse!!! It breaks immersion completely.
- The open world is empty and feels lifeless.
- The gunplay is mediocre at best.
- The AI of the enemies is dumb as hell.
- The game is way too easy and needs alot of balancing. The stake launcher for example is way to OP.
- The game is terribly overpriced. They dare to charge 70‚Ç¨ for for a game thats barely worth 15‚Ç¨...
- Big list of ingame bugs that should be fixed

Conclusion: This game is the perfect example of what is wrong with the gaming industry. Especially when it comes to AAA games. Developers and publishers these days are releasing broken and empty games.... Its completely unacceptable and nothing is being done about it. If a product comes on the market for sale that product should be 100% finnished. Not 70% or in this case 40%.

I had just exited the beginner's ferry, maybe 5 minutes into the game, when I had to get up to drain the lizard.

As I stood there, a mere 10 feet away in the bathroom, door open, I heard my character taking shots from enemies that DID NOT EXIST when I hit the pause button mere seconds prior to my getting up to pee.

I mean, really guys. If I hit the pause button just to get up to pee and you pop enemies to kill my character, am I supposed to sprint back from taking a piss, streaming urine all over the carpet, just to save my nascent character from death? Did you not think this through?

"No big deal," I thought at first, "I'll just restart the game with a new character". Except when I tried, I didn't see an option to start a brand new game from zero with a new save.

I mean, fuck. A goddamn drunken chimp with downs syndrome high on crack could do a better job considering the ramifications of a player pressing the fucking pause button. Or at least, for the love of all that is holy and not, let you start over. Fucking Christ you guys, what the fuck is wrong with you?

And you did worse than that. Bethesda, Microsoft, you were inferior to a goddamn drunken chimp with downs's syndrome while high on crack and you charged me $70 bucks plus tax for the privilege of suffering your stupidity.

Refunded, and it'll be a cold day in hell before I buy another Microsoft exclusive, including Starfield. I'll be doubling-down on PS5. I'm sorry, Valve, that you'll be caught in the crossfire, for their stupidity here, and I'd encourage a serious discussion at the highest levels about the fail involved here as of late, because this is far from the first time such bad things have been unleashed upon gamers at large.

Can't recommend this game at the moment.  Its plagued with bugs and disconnects.  The world feels empty when traveling from place to place. Cool little horror shooter with some nice atmosphere.  AI can be awful at times and the pop in and shadows aren't great on max but when ray tracing comes this will look and feel even spookier.  I dunno, 65%.  Not as bad as some people are making out, shame it wasn't a cheaper game or it was left in development longer.  The first Island area is definitely worse, has some badly optimised areas where fps tanks for no good reason, but the second area is so much better, more detailed, full and haven't found any drops so maybe the first area was tagged on or something.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. NO MATTER IF ANY OF THESE ISSUES GET FIXED: 

- AI is borderline braindead. 
- The missions are either boring Fetch Quests, with no substance, or Lore missions that make you wait 30mins until the dialogue ends. 
- There are no cutscenes at all in this game, the lore is below average, constant frame stutters, the open World is empty to a point you just fast travel to the nearest safe house to complete the missions. 
- Most Characters have borderline useless abilities. The XP throttling is SUBSTANTIAL to a point where you complete the game without even unlocking half of the skill tree. 
- There are like 7 different guns to choose from. No variety, no costumisation.

TL;DR Game is bland, stay away forever

Not sure where my opinion on this game is coming from but I completed the first stage, did some exploration, looked at all the stuff, looked around the menus, talked to all the npcs, everything feels... just ok to me. I know the entire internet hates this game and with plenty of good reasons but udunno. Maybe after everyone yelling I went in with lower expectations. Maybe I'm just more tolerant of gaming in general (a friend definitely accuses me of this regularly). -shrugs- Maybe im more tolerant of it because it was free with my purchase of a 4080 rtx from msi. 

Anywho, so far I like it.

i7 13th gen 4080 rtx 32gig ddr5 ram. All option preset to RT (second highest). 60fps smooth.

Does it have some bugs on release? Well yeah, from indie to AAA, there are bugs on release. None crashed my game, corrupted save date, or hurt my PC, just some known shippables to give us Arkane fans something fun, even if a little buggy.

AND WOW IS THIS GAME FUN. 

Honestly, once you get past the issues that are sure to be ironed out soon, you will find yet another signature Arkane game. A fun lore to explore, many ways of dealing with situations, and that amazing semi painted art style we fell in love with back in dishonored. Just exploring Redfall has made the last week so much better, and fighting vamps and cultists feels very satisfying. It still needs a bit of work, so if you are hesitant, feel free to wait, but DO NOT forget about this, cause once the fixes roll out, you don't want to miss this!

But don't buy this game, not even if it goes on sale, this game is not worth not even 30 euro. I felt robbed but hey from mistakes we learn.

I wanted to like this game, since it checks off the usual interests - open world, supernatural, exploration, Autumn setting, characters with abilities.

Gave it a good 20 hours at time of review, to see if the lackluster introduction gave way to improvements. Even with few bugs, it's still been "meh" most of the time. Story hasn't been told in a way that got my attention (normally something I am very forgiving about), the environmental storytelling has been sparse for an open-world game, the human enemies all feel very samey. Boss fights have been lackluster.

The one part that has caught my attention at all is the Grave Locks you can find, but while it's the most interesting story element it's delivered piece meal through 2-3 sentence voiced lines from items you have to scour otherwise lackluster areas to find them all -and there's a lot of them. 100 to be exact, with no way to track the locations you've already searched, and no indicator of how many are in the first area and how many are in the second area (important thing to know for collecting, since you can't travel back to the first map without starting anew in NG+. 

Feels like the most "we need to pad out the time played on this game as much as possible" feature I've seen in a long time.

I think the devs were just out of their depth on this one.

Writing this review at about the 8 hours of play mark. All in all a good game. It isn't breaking the mold on anything but has a nice open feel without being too bloated. Multiplayer is straightforward. The performance is good with only a few issues like minor pathing issues for mobs, occasionally graphic hiccups, but nothing that has interfered with play-ability. Things I enjoy: The amount of world components that you can use to make combat more interesting. The simplicity of the mechanics and quest tracking. The pared down equipment and skill charts.

I'm going to say that I recommend this game to players for the dream that it represents, not because of what is here... and I will elaborate on that first.

The Dream: Have you ever wanted to be a badass Vampire Hunter in a post-apocalyptic setting, gunning down hordes of Ghouls, Freaks, Vampires and the like? If that box is checked then this game is for you.

However:

And this is a strong one... due to the way the game is set up, I cannot recommend this for anyone who doesn't have an extreme hard-on for the idea of being a Vampire hunter... because of numerous bugs, one of the characters being basically useless (We'll get to this) and the game-progression/ general gameplay system being overly flawed (I will loosely explain this... but since its so new, y'know...)

Numerous Bugs: So sometimes vampires will just not attack and not be attackable... sometimes certain numbers glitch out, the party system will sometimes not work and if you don't play in Borderless Windowed Mode then the screen will essentially fuck up and you'll pretty much be screwed.

Broken Character: So Layla, the Psychic doesn't really feel all that Psychic... her first ability only affects humanoids... because they're the only one's shooting bullets... her basic passive increase point literally makes food items more potent (you can't pick up food for later)... rather than do something exceptional, like get more lock-picks or get more money or have a bigger health stack... her second ability is literally a aerial traversal skill that is beat entirely by another team member's (Devander's Teleporter), leaving her ulti... which isn't even a psychic power, the only really useful skill in her tool-kit. In a game where people have invisibility, teleportation, explosives and robots, would it of killed the dev's to give the psychic girl actual psychic abilities rather than dollar-store green lantern powers and a Vampire Boyfriend? I'm just saying... some things in her kit need a SERIOUS rework because the others can ez solo while she's lagging due to lack of utility.

Game Play/Progression: This is a serious one... Dev's, you better read this one CAREFULLY. It is 2023... we do not make a multiplayer game where a restart is required to play a specific section of a gameworld... fix it. Now. You are killing your fanbase before it begins... also, when you do fix it... and you know what I mean, since you put a literal ENDING in a multiplayer game... add some end-game content loop. Need inspiration? Look at skyrim, go play as an imperial and do nothing but collect rare gems, wealth and priceless artifacts and stick them in a chest... you will be BEYOND inspired to do some badass Vampire Hunter shit. Just saying.

Final Thoughts: What's here is fun... its great! But seriously... the things I listed, the negatives... they need to be addressed... and soon. I'm going to give this game the benefit of the doubt... I did pay 100$ for this game after all... but if things go sour, all I've got to say is that more love and care needed to go into making this game a more seamless and enjoyable game... because I also gifted it to someone for, yes, the same amount... I payed 200$ for this game with the hope and intention of it being good... so while I'll be patient and wait... I will seriously be considering how I spend my money in the future... as for the gameplay... don't finish the main quest till you get bored of the first area... and so on... You'll get a lot more hours out of the game. In fact, I haven't left the first area... and I've played every character in it, but friends of mine have and I'm none too happy about what they've told me the, "End-game experience," is...
cant wait for the full game to release!
