Redfall is a massive achievement in failure from Arkane Austin, the minds that were behind masterpiece immersive sim Prey.Frankly to fail this hard is equal parts negligence on all parties. Bethesda, Microsoft and Arkane. Worst of all this is a powerful idea and concept for a game! It dares to try but like a backfiring car engine instead throws soot and only exposes how ugly of a job was done on this game. I cannot see a majority of people getting a hour in on pc unless they are already big FPS fans or have friends for coop.

I have only played one character so far. The psionic, Layla. Her abilities range from being "hey this is kinda fun" to "this is quite possibly the most useless thing ever". Her shield umbrella doesn't block melee attacks in a game that has half of the enemies jump into your face to attack you. Hilariously stupid. The other half are ranged enemies that can pivot quite easily to your flank and get free damage in. WITH THE UMBRELLA UP. It is not a 180 degrees of forward protection. You cannot use weapons, heal or anything that might be remotely useful. It runs so contrary to how the enemy design is, that it's genuinely baffling. That's a lot of the game for me personally so far.

Performance is inexcusable, Arkane has done decent enough PC jobs before. Prey at least ran fairly smoothly when it was released. Same deal with dishonored although Dishonored 2 had it's problems. I have seen rainbow vomit on textures failing to LOD properly. So many framerate issues and all with DLSS enabled on performance. Simply awful.

Finally the enemy design. It's just simply terrible, the AI is so poor that there have been times i've accidentally stealthed entire missions because enemies were too dense to patrol or were patrolling and had a direct line of sight and just kept on going anyway. Same in combat.

I'm not done but i'll write a more complete review. I am severely disappointed in arkane most of all.

I've completed the game twice now after very casually playing through it solo and taking my time to do all the missions I could find. TLDR, I still recommend this game, flaws and all, though I think it should really only be a $40 game. I think the $70 price tag is really steep, especially for what's on offer. Regardless, if you want to know more, I'll get more in depth in the following paragraphs.

I'm probably one of a few people who like the game. This is not a hard game in any way, its really more of a casual romp through a decent open world, sometimes you get "spooky" things to happen, but nothing truly scary will ever hit you. Its best to view the game from the perspective of a really low budget adventure-horror movie protagonist, where the enemies are just thrown into the meat grinder that is the hero.

If I had to say anything that I truly disliked about the game, its actually the music, it jumps up at really random times, and not in an exciting or "spooky" way. You'll snipe a single guy and intense combat music jumps up for like 5 seconds before cutting away, kind of jarring. The game also has a rough time performance wise because as you move around the map, it has to load things in, and that typically can cause a good second or two of lag when entering a new neighborhood (zone) or if a large number of enemies spawn in due to story. If they could improve the performance of the game, that would help it drastically. I encountered a very small number of bugs, such as staking specific objectives while crouching causing me to get stuck under the environment, or occasionally being unable to crouch after leaving a Psychic Vampire Nest. Annoyances at best, nothing game ruining.

It feels like a Dead Island game but maybe a bit bigger? Cultists are the most common threat on the island, but the fun part is the Vampires. Basically just always have a shotgun on hand so you can abuse the stake attachment and you're set. My ideal loadout would probably be an automatic rifle, a shotgun, and the UV lazer for all around good coverage. The UV lazer slowly petrifies vampires, letting you instantly kill them with melee. The lazer is also pretty much necessary to deal with environmental hazards the Vampires leave in areas, which is more of a very minor inconvenience, and at some points I've actually enjoyed the challenge of dissecting a large area of all its hazards with the lazer; just wish there was a cheaper alternative, like a flashlight upgrade or something.

Staking vampires is very satisfying and I find myself occasionally picking fights with groups of vampires just because I like the staking, its very nice. You can also get equipment after a certain point in the game that grants you decent boons, one of which is "Regain x% of health when killing a Vampire." Its worth it to continuously bum rush Vampire Nests just to get equipment with this modifier on it, because the staking animation gives you invincibility frames, allowing you to quickly heal off the kill and then tanking hits from any other vampires in the vicinity.

The AI is definitely a bit jank for cultists but most Vampires have no issue getting right up in your face and making sure you understand why its a problem. I have beaten the game, all bosses and enemies defeated, and honest to god the only enemies that I disliked were the "Anglers" and the final boss. Angler's straight up just suck ass, if you got caught with an empty clip, prepare to lose a chunk of health. The Final Boss was really more of a set piece, which is a shame because I really enjoyed shooting up all the other bosses; if the developers had simply split it into phases with a real tangible health bar it would've been much cooler.

I'm almost certain that the devs fully expected people to play this with friends as opposed to alone because once or twice I got a dialogue line that was definitely meant to be played in a lobby instead of in solo mode. Wasn't a big issue honestly, more of an interesting quirk. A good number of perks in your perk tree also mention helping allies, or you might have things that mention buffing allies in a radius, so yeah definitely feels like they expected people to go in a group instead of solo. Editing this paragraph post game completion, there's literally achievements that can only be obtained by playing with others and raising "trust" with their characters, so yes, definitely expected people to be playing this multiplayer instead of alone.

As a final note, I'm not sure all of the characters are built equally; I picked Jacob as my Hero instead of Devinder because I wanted a more stealthy approach to combat, and originally I regretted that but I don't mind it so much anymore. A lot of Jacob's abilities sound really good if you had them fully upgraded, but upgrading them is a chore because higher level upgrades demand multiple perk points to activate; its much better to just get all the base upgrades asap on all of the abilities instead. This frustrates me a bit more than it should because it feels like I'm purposely being gate kept from playing with the upgrades I want; I suppose that I could hold off on getting cheaper upgrades to get higher level upgrades, but then I'm weaker over all for a whole 'nother level, which is a bad plan in a Dead Island style game. This really might just be a me issue though, not sure how others feel on the subject.

Back to Devinder, he has a number of abilities that just seem so much better than what most of the other characters have. The player doesn't exactly lack for firepower, so what it really comes down to is how easily you can manage a group of enemies, and I think that Devinder would probably be the best for it. The fact that one of his abilities literally just dunks a UV light ray probably makes him the best right off the bat because it absolutely destroys vampires and if I had to hazard a guess, it probably works against environmental vampire hazards which means you could carry a 3rd gun of your choice instead of having to  carry the UV lazer just in case you need it.
I'd have maybe given Layla a shot if it weren't for the fact that her abilities annoy me, and the combat Engineer looks cool but as I mentioned before, you don't need extra firepower and the AI for cultists is so jank already that there's no need to distract them. The reason I give Jacob a passing grade is because his abilities fuck even more with the enemy AI, even vampires, and his Hero ability to summon the ghost gun is really strong; it can outright kill vampires without having to stake them, even if they need a few shots to go down.

Closing statement, I enjoy the game, its definitely a different kind of game than Arkane's other stuff, I think its rather reminiscent of Dead Island with the loot, healing, weapons, and world over all. I've enjoyed my time so far, but realistically I got my enjoyment out of it at the 30 hour mark. Nests ended up being my favorite thing to do, just running in and splaffing the heart as fast as possible. I still recommend this game as I've stated before, but they need to reduce the base price significantly; there's just not enough content here to justify the $70 price tag. Again, not a reduced price via sale, but a flat reduction of the base price. $40 dollars is the honorable thing to do, $50 is the economic thing to do.

Most of the people here that are complaining, just love to complain and complain like there is no tomorrow. Probably because their life sucks. Yes, the game can definitely use some work, but that‚Äôs alright and they will sort out the bugs and AI in this game. This game can always be improved and it will be come better. Is the game worth $70? I‚Äôd say no, but should be around $40 to say the least.

Overall, I‚Äôm having fun with the game and that‚Äôs all that really matters.

Mid game that felt like it should have been an Xbox One launch title not a Series X exclusive nearly three years after launch. While I had no performance issues whatsoever not being able to turn off DLSS and only run Frame generation is super petty.
The game is so mid I can't even be mad at it. It's uninspired and tries to mix things that just don't work well together.

A generic game that doesn't justify $70 cost.

Graphics are Arcane recognizable style, but while those were good in Dishonored and Deathloop here they don't fit: usual Arcane is using closed and tightly packed places and here it's and open world that feels weird with that style. Some of the assets are reused from previous games and there is no upgrade on the technical side of things.

Same as many AAA releases these days the game does not have proper PC controls and has hardcoded keys you either can't reassign altogether or reassigning them does nothing. Was it a last minute addition that no one even bothered to test? But they did bother to increase the price by $10...

Gameplay looks basic and following all the known patterns of an "open world save the city from a plague game": we've got survivors to rescue, camps for fast travel/ammo refill to establish, resources to grab and infinite colored loot to pick, compare and discard to pick more - it's World of Warcraft decades ago (OK, maybe traditions are not bad, but in this case better honor first the tradition of having properly assignable keys on PC). Skills are generic "be better at the skills you're given" type and character development seems like just going through levels and gradually acquiring all of them. There is nothing that makes the game stand out, no personality, it's more of a checklist of things to do than a classic Arcane style mystery to solve.

This review is written after two hours of playing. For an obvious reason. And I've got no incentive to go past those - because the game did not convince me it can hold anything new and interesting to play for.

Redfall, the latest release from Bethesda, is a game that falls far short of the expectations set by its predecessors. While the premise of a vampire-infested open world had great potential, the execution leaves much to be desired. It's evident that the once-revered Bethesda company is struggling to maintain its reputation for delivering high-quality gaming experiences.

One of the major shortcomings of Redfall is the technical aspect. Glitches, bugs, and performance issues plague the game, detracting from any sense of immersion. It's disheartening to see a title released with such blatant technical deficiencies, and it reflects poorly on Bethesda's commitment to delivering polished products.

The narrative, another cornerstone of Bethesda's games, lacks the depth and complexity that fans have come to expect. Redfall's storyline feels uninspired, failing to captivate players with the engaging storytelling that made previous Bethesda titles memorable. The characters are forgettable, and their interactions lack the emotional resonance that could have elevated the overall experience.

One redeeming aspect of Redfall is the visual design. The game showcases a visually appealing world, with well-crafted environments and atmospheric lighting. However, even this positive element is marred by the subpar animations and character models, further emphasizing the lack of attention to detail in the game's development.

The most disheartening aspect of Redfall is the apparent mishandling of Arkane Studios, a once highly-regarded developer. It's clear that the studio's creative prowess is being stifled, and their potential is not fully realized in this title. The lack of innovation and the recycling of gameplay mechanics from previous games indicate a stagnation in Arkane's ability to push boundaries and deliver fresh experiences.

In conclusion, Redfall is a lackluster addition to Bethesda's portfolio, showcasing a company that seems to be losing its touch. The issues plaguing the game, from technical problems to uninspired storytelling, underscore the need for a reevaluation of Bethesda's development processes. It's disheartening to witness the decline of Arkane Studios under the Bethesda umbrella, leaving fans longing for the days when both entities were synonymous with groundbreaking and captivating gaming experiences.

I went into Redfall with little expectations, aside from it seeming like Borderlands with vampires and I was not far off. My main confusion was with the campaign and how it would progress or keep me interested being isolated to a town map. It does a decent job at keeping you on task as you roam across the city and recapture safehouses that each have their own area questlines. You fight a boss for each area after doing enough quests and pick up side quests along the way. 

The gameplay itself feels surprisingly good, each character has branching skill trees and you're constantly changing out loot for better stats or rarities. The map is littered with loot and guarded treasure, while most houses or buildings require lockpicking or hacking to enter, along with tripmines, safes, and alarms to disarm or loot. I was worried about the difficulty being too easy, but there are four modes to choose from and it's giving me a run for my money on solo hard mode. There are also lots of cosmetics to unlock just by completing quests and challenges.

My biggest gripe is that the co op was not thought out at all. Hosting a game is invite from friend's list only, which means you'll likely be playing solo unless you have friends to play with. It's annoyingly difficult to play co op at all otherwise. They need to get public servers and allow public hosting if they want co op to happen.

Overall I wouldn't jump on the hate bandwagon just yet, Redfall has potential. If you aren't bothered by pretentious FPS gripes and you enjoy looter shooters then you should pick it up, it's actually a solid game with decent challenge and detail put into it. The more you look around the more you seem to find.

(Since the developers have been unable to deliver on key features involved with the genre like multiplayer matchmaking, I can't leave a positive review so I'm changing this to negative. There WAS potential here if you focused in the right areas, but you've proven that you could not deliver. We haven't even seen the two additional characters promised at launch and I would get a refund if I could. Redfall is a crippled experience from what it could have been.)

I'm just disappointed, as an Arkane Studios fan, I loved their games especially Prey. But this, this game with the AAA price tag, launched with utter garbage optimization, woke political agenda, broken enemy AI, absurd enemy respawn and is just an average looter shooter at best.

The Dishonored character design is still there though and I love their art style, just screams Arkane when you see the models but jeez its so cringe seeing that trans reverend with the trashy getup showing off their tattoo. Millenial cosplaying as a reverend at a Halloween party on a vampire apocalypse, jesus!

Enemies respawn so quickly after you clear out a certain area when you just turn your back a few minutes and the AI is worst. They get stuck and some npcs even fall off the mesh and can shoot through walls. Even some of the dead npcs keeps talking. The performance, its annoying when the game stutters. You see those bunch of birds flying in the sky? How bout those Airdrops parachuting down? Also when you enter a different neighborhood. It even stutters when you just open the menu and sometimes during fire fights when you ADS/scope in. The game is fun when it works, the graphics are beautiful but these micro stutters even with a RTX 3080 card is taking some of it away.

In the end, it does scratch some of that looter shooter itch, you get a chance to loot high-end rarity weapons even at the early part of the game, finishing off vampires with a stake is so satisfying, the guns and character customization is a good addition but for its current price its just not worth it, wait for a sale and probably further fixes/patches.

I almost refunded due to that. 

I didn't encounter any crazy bugs after the patch but the game play is just not fun! Enemies are extremely easy as everyone says. They are all bullet sponges. You think you're going to do some cool take downs or finishers? Not in this game. I absolutely love stealth! But all you can do is bash them to death! It gets very boring, very fast.

The world itself looks "ok". Being a UE5 game it was very disappointing. They have cool locations but it just doesn't look good! Everything is "closed" and there aren't many open interiors. Does anyone not learn things from other games?? We LOVE to explore interiors. 

The animations of the characters are horrible. The voice acting is horrible! I found myself just saying "STFU already!"

I can't believe this is what gaming has become. Stalker 2 PLEASE SAVE US!!.

Leaving a tentatively positive review.

I loaded up the game for a short while to test the performance claims of other reviewers, concerned that this game might have been unplayable and result in a refund. I was pleased that the game ran flawlessly on max settings with DLAA (not DLSS) and frame generation with a completely stable 120fps@4k. GPU usage was between 57-81% & temperatures not exceeding 56 degrees.

The very minor issues I encountered were a handful of textures for the landscape took ~2 seconds to load in after rebooting the game instead of being instantaneous like the rest and there's a very brief, maybe half a second, stutter when loading areas as you move further through the map but that's not unheard of in games so I don't mind.

I always keep my system perfectly optimised for gaming and every software component updated so if you're encountering issues I'd recommend doing the same as there's more to a computer than just your graphics driver. Additionally, I've noticed a lot of reviews that are disappointed with performance are running old hardware. Try to keep your expectations realistic for how old your system is and check the system requirements, you won't always be able to play a modern game at the same resolution and quality presets that you could for one 6 years ago with the same tech.

I'll update my review as I play more with the wife in co-op later on and include any issues we might encounter but for now I've no real complaints.

Update: Co-op worked perfectly fine, no issues or bugs that prevented progression or hindered what we were working on at that time. Smooth performance persisted, never dropped below 120fps. Though after experiencing more of what the world and story had to offer I'm changing my review to not recommended as the game is for the most part quite lifeless and you'll spend more than half of your time just running through empty streets, finding a handful of enemies here and there but they never seem to be doing anything which makes them feel alive past being targets to shoot for a few minutes before you mop up their loot then continue trekking down the barren streets. The difficulty is also ridiculously easy, I didn't once feel that I was in any danger despite playing on the highest difficulty which further takes away from the enjoyment in my opinion as I enjoy being challenged.
It is obvious they spent most dev time on world building and lore. Even if the game fails, the story of Redfall should continue. this game is very jenk but also very enjoyable.

Traversal options? Front door or a window.

It baffles me how the studio that made Prey delivered this...

Not like this Arkane. Not like this...

A game that offers tips telling the player that the most direct route to the objective is the most dangerous and that finding alternative routes is better.  In a game where the open world is pretty much already mostly empty of enemies.

To enjoy this game, I recommend the direct route to all objectives. Ignore the tips else you will be bored wandering through empty streets without anything to shoot at. Plus the objectives is where all the real fun is at. 

With this more direct method, the game has been awesome!

Some quick comparisons of a similar game:
If you Love Dying Light 2? You will love this game!
If you Hate Dying Light 2? You will love this game!
Better than Dying Light 2? 100%, you will love this game!

[url=https://linktr.ee/factorofgames] Factor of Games [/url] Steam Deck Preview Here: https://youtu.be/BxfPGb3KwEg

The game from the outset looks like Back 4 Blood for apparent reasons. There are some nice improvements, notably there is a single player component, and graphically it's a better-looking game. The real issue I have with it is that even with a Singleplayer campaign, it will live and die on the support from the CoOp audience. At $69, with many folks being let down with AAA PC releases in the past couple of months, a large portion will be holding off until substantial discounts for the game start hitting. This has me on the fence around recommending it at this point, unless you have Xbox Gamepass and just essentially play free for the next few months, then see where the Steam audience stands towards the end of summer.

Otherwise, my thoughts on the Steam Deck performance are good. It usually runs in the 40 - 50 fps range (It can dip to 30fps and climb to 60fps) and looks good on low settings with FSR 2.1. My main concern, again, is that the lack of audience will be problematic for Steam players early on. I have a poll up on my channel, and about 4% of the votes say they will buy the game on Steam. It's not 1000s of votes, but it will likely end up with hundreds of votes, and if it tracks anywhere near other new release polls I've done, it will stay in the single digits. If that holds true, it won't make me feel fantastic about paying such a high price out of the gate.

You can check out the Steam Deck footage for the game above and vote on the poll while you're there!

Enjoy!

Maybe Im one of the lucky few, but Ive encountered next to NO performance or gameplay issues other than some brief 5-10 min issues of trying to launch a multiplayer session and not being able to until several restarts.

Games running at a pretty solid 80-100 FPS almost at all times, gameplay feels smooth, and enjoyable. If you are a big fan of the Arkane style its honestly a pretty welcome addition, it doesnt inovate the "arkane style" that much but it does bring a fresh new setting and exciting enemies and story/lore.

Its so far 4 hrs in an easy 8/10 for me!

Unlike the majority of the negative reviewers of this game, I have actually played this game more than one whole hour. My friends and I have had a great time playing this game so far. It is a great looking game, the story is okay, the audio is good, the coop is overall very smooth, and the combat, while not the most challenging thing ever, is enjoyable. There are some issues on day one, but that is to be expected. Is it the most amazing game ever? No. Is it as bad as everyone is trying to make it out to be? Not at all.

As with any new titles now days; I can't wait for that patch to fix stuttering.
70 bucks is a bit of a stretch tho, kinda regretting not waiting for sale. I guess I've been excited for its release despite my better judgement + a love for Bethesda. This game is fun but def overpriced for what it is.

My suggestion is to grab when it goes on sale and issues are fixed.

I won't deny performance could be better, occasional hiccups aren't that big of a deal for me but I'm already "used to this" in the Unreal Engine games, because the engine itself is flawed. Game wise, this is fun, open world reminds me of Dying Light a bit, but here you actually use guns, instead of just whacking at things in close quarters combat. Main characters look like they would in any Arkane game, but other NPCs, aside from vampires, look bland, enemy cultists all look generic and friendly NPCs are missing some of that charm from their previous titles. Weapons feel punchy and fun to use, not sure how I feel about the "rarity" so far, as high tier weapon drops seem too common. Dynamic day/night cycle makes it really fun to roam the world and engage into different threats during the day/night. Vampires are less likely to be encountered during the day, which is precisely when cultists like to roam around. Hard to say for now but if enemy encounters are random this will work nicely as it won't get as stale so fast.

Currently my only gripe with it is the fact that idle AI really does seem broken, cultists seem to get stuck on random objects when idling/patrolling, vampire AI is fine as it doesn't physically walk unless engaging you, so they move around just fine. Seen people mention COOP is broken, but I can't comment on that as I got the game mainly for SP.

Super bad. Gameplay and graphic feel like a 20 years old halflife 2 mod. 

Refunded the game.

Shame on you Arcane!

Played with friends, having a blast, abilities are unique yet can be mixed up together for multiple combinations and one of the most unique character trust factor which brings new story arc in character's dialogue and is pretty unique.

**4 hours at time of writing.*

This game is receiving a lot of hate, which I suppose is understandable. It is not the game we were expecting, and for being a co-op focused game, not having a matchmaking system is a huge downfall.

CONS: 
1) This game is meant to be played with co-op, although you CAN play solo. But co-op makes the game much more fun due to synergy and increased difficulty. Unfortunately, at the moment, there is no matchmaking, which means playing solo, or get friends who have the game.

2) The biggest letdown is the world is beautiful, and has a very nice atmosphere, but it has so much dead space that it makes you wonder where everyone is. I think a lot of people expected a L4D2 type experience, but this is mainly an FPS with loot, and a lot of empty space.

3)Much of the game feels as though you are just looting and exploring, with battles being an afterthought. Most battles only consist of 4-6 enemies, so battles end before you even get to flex your skills, abilities, or tactics.

4) The stealth mechanics are a joke. There is no execute for backstabbing someone. It just whacks them, and if they have enough health, they will just get mad and alert someone. This game needs some serious Farycry melee executions to encourage a stealth gameplay for those who prefer it.

PROS:
1) It is not all bad though, far from it. The weapons feel fun and sound beefy, audio is great, atmosphere is great, getting swarmed by vampires can get dicey very quickly, especially on the harder difficulties.

2) Many different ways to approach enemies, though it will pretty much always come down to a firefight. But you have options on how you approach it, such as sneaking in somewhere, getting up high somewhere, running in guns-a-blazing, whatever you prefer.

3) Runs fine on my rig. Yet to have any problems outside initially crashing on launch. But that was due to a hardware issue, not the game.

4) Story so far is interesting, especially if you take the time to read the lore. Not much depth to it, but still a fun concept.

Overall, I would give this game a hard 7/10. But it has the potential to be much better than that if Arkane and Bethesda listen to players. This is going to be one of those games that needs a bunch of patches before it truly becomes the game we thought it would be.

[i]I received this game through an Nvidia GPU promotion.[/i]
[list]
[*] The game is bad. Enemies that don't work properly, an open world that is mostly empty, and everything is boring when it actually does work properly.
[*] The first three major bosses were actually decently fun. There aren't any bosses outside of these three, though. There are some strong enemies but they keep reusing the three or so special vampire archetypes everywhere. The last boss isn't even a boss, it's just a room filled with a few of these special enemies, and even makes them less challenging than normal [b]for the final boss[/b].
[*] Weapons suck. You keep leveling up by playing the game, and when you hit a new level suddenly all the guns that are lower level than you are become garbage. If you enjoy using a certain type of weapon, tough, because you need to find a new max rarity type of if every time you level up. You usually won't and will be stuck using level appropriate weapons that you don't enjoy.
[*] Why are weapons even candy colored with rarities? All it does it turn any gun that isn't purple or orange into trash. There are skins for weapons, too, apparently, though they're all pretty lame. I bet that if the game wasn't so poorly received they would have put good skins into an in-game shop.
[*] Way too much walking. The streets are so empty that you can tell they planned to let you use vehicles to move around during development, but just scrapped driving completely so you can hoof it through an empty world to each location.
[*] When you beat the game, it just restarts at the beginning with the same character. Maybe they thought that people would be willing to play it more than once? Who would do that? There's nothing different or new on a second play-through, there is no new game plus.
[*] I genuinely hope that everyone who owns this game on Steam also happens to have purchased a new graphics card during the promotion. Nobody deserves to have had $69.99 stolen from them for this trash.
[/list]

Like most peeps, I don't usually write reviews, and I wasn't looking forward to this title, I knew it was looking bad, the only reason i decided to pick it up was cause someone gifted me jedi fallen order the game I was actually interested in and out of morbid curiosity.

So with lowest expectations in mind...and  a few beers in hand on a sick day...I realized it was worse than I expected. I would like to preface this by saying that for me the game performed well except for an occasional micro stutter moving between the zones, but I do have an RTX 4090 paired with a Ryzen 7 5800x3D, 32 gigs of DDR4 3600 RAM and one of the fastest PCIE 4.0 SSDs, but keeping this in mind, a game this small, this unpopulated and ugly has no business neither weighing 100 gigs on your hard drive nor giving you performance issues even if your are still running a gtx card.

In the words of Gordon Ramsey...ITS BLAND! It's got bland visuals, bland sounds, bland gameplay and bland RPG mechanics and story. A lot of this can be forgiven if gunplay was fun...but its not, I am not normally sensitive to these things but when a shotgun feels like a peeshooter you know there are issues. Enemy bodies don't respond appropriately at being shot and the guns have zero impact or kick, for nostalgia sake I tried Borderlands 1 a few days ago and it had more impactful weapons than Redfall. The RPG mechanics themselves are nothing to write home about either and loot feels inconsistent and largerly pointless as all enemies are pushovers in both stats and AI. Two of the 4 characters are also pointless, well 1 if you place co-op I imagine 2 if you play solo as one is a healer which has no purpose in solo and one is a sniper with a cloak ability and a revealing ability both of which are useless because the AI is really weak and you are might as well just run up and blast them in the face.

It does feel like the game had an ounce of vision behind it at some point, as some of the details around town are clearly inspired by the actual location and someone giving a crap about authenticity and the whole occult theme has not yet been repeated in triple A to death but a confused and troubled development has clearly impacted on what little original inspiration and vision there was...until a husk remained, that kept what little life it had by sucking the life of other better games dry...a bit sad really...

To all the people that decided to pass on this game I must say [b]"Thanks for the smooth launch"[/b]. I can admit it had no server issues or connectivity problems on start, at least for me. I haven't experienced any performance issues either so I don't know where/what that is coming from. (I do have a top of the line PC though). 

From what I can read a lot of people must be playing the game on easy mode... Playing this on midnight (the harder of the 3 modes you can play in the beginning) I died a couple of times before leaning towards a more tactical approach. It's gotten a little easier now that I've gotten the hang of it but it's still not 'easy'. You can't expect a challenge playing on the baby mode.

[h1] From what I can gather from my play so far, I'll try to be as unbiased as I can: [/h1]
 
[b]PROS:[/b]
(+) [b]Class identity[/b]. Game gives you four different classes (more to come iirc), each one seemed unique and full of flavour. Currently playing Jacob (raven, camo) and it's been pretty solid for solo play. One of the classes I saw, I wondered why I would play that solo. Game has a passive tree system which seems nice, but some of these traits, again, why would I take them solo play. Unless I can get followers later, which I doubt. But the abilities have been fun to utilize and play with. After all who likes playing a looter shooter or RPG without class fantasy?
(+) [b]Enemy disparity[/b]. Now hear me out. As far the humans go, you have the cultists and the paramilitary. These guys carry any of the guns, and can be easy or a pain to deal with depending on how their oriented. As stated earlier I opted for a more tactical approach after I tried to brazenly open on one of these groups out (I'm in midnight mode again) and it didn't go according to my pea sized brain. The vampires have some generic ones, but then some specialty ones. Magic, watchers, these blob things (I think?) I just recently opted out of fighting for the time being, buffed ones, and I'm pretty sure in one of the missions to come that I need to unlock there's a bunch of others.
(+) [b]Cute vampire girls[/b]. What I wouldn't give to spend an eternity with the vampire woman I love... but that would be a curse in disguise if she was like the last girl I was with... let me take the stake for you my friends and tell you to choose wisely gentleman, and don't dip in crazy.
(+) [b]Visuals[/b]. Honestly, I love the graphics of the game. There are cosmetics to come/earn, there are weapon skins as well so it should just continually get better aesthetically speaking. 
(+) [b]Weapons[/b]. Although I've opted for a sniper, pistol, and shotgun for the time being, there are several choices up to the dealer. I don't know if there is one, but I haven't gotten a melee weapon and that feels amiss as even Blade himself used a sword, albeit it was a titanium blade with acid. Aesthetically speaking as I noted above, one of the shotguns I got after the beginning missions (and IDK if I was just lucky or everyone gets it) was this drenched/barnacle ghost pirate covered shotgun. And I love the way it looks, and feels to use. I've one shot one of the smaller vampires with it, but it's only level 2 and doesn't quite work on the harder enemies all the time. As I level up, it may get worse and worse, so here's hoping I keep the skin
(+) [b]Game is true to it's nature[/b]. People talking about the lack of enemies in the open world? Yea... Did you not read or pay attention to the game? This was a lovely family friendly town slowly taken over and decimated by vampires.... Why would you want to be out in the open if that was the case. Lol... Also it's daylight... And you literally watch a vampire get burned in the VERY FIRST CINEMATIC. Why do you expect there to just be vampires laying out and about sunbathing on the beach with the sun at 12'o'clock. But going into a random house, yup, found three vampires and they mauled me at the beginning. 
(+) [b]Game play has been fun so far[/b]. There have been environment interactions that I've had to use, such as lighting a battery on fire to explode a car to light some vampires and enemies on fire cause it was just the right thing to do. Staking my beloved vampires always has been fun. Abilities doing their things, stealth killing people, gunning down innocent vampires that were just trying to enjoy their day, all fun.

[b]Cons[/b]:
(-) Some of the AI do seem to be bugged sometimes. They've gotten stuck in trees, although they later moved when I got closer. There was a hecka cute vampire girl that was in one house, that was just floating around but I couldn't kill. Maybe that was on purpose, maybe I had killed her already, or she was bugged. There was a UV lamp upstairs so maybe that got her, and I didn't and that's why. But 9 times out of 10, the AI has been fine. 
(-) [b]Lose coins on death[/b]. It doesn't happen super often, but I think even Borderlands makes you pay money for dying too. Immortality ain't free bb. Not that big of a deal to me, but you know, I LOSE the coins, so obviously this is a con as a negative gain deserves a negative sign right?
(-) [b]Weapon slots[/b]. While you do get 3 weapon slots to use what you want. I've been using the sniper, pistol, and shotgun. There are those other weapons that I mentioned like a stake launcher. That seems super cool and fun to use. But I feel comfortable and safe with my 3 current weapons so why would I want to switch. But maybe I should get out of my comfort zone, go talk to that girl up at the bar or the club after all since the moment I saw her we've had 3 kids and got married and grew old and died together. But just like this made up fantasy, it only sounds good/easy on paper.
(-) Aiming. This seems a little different, but I mean it's up to the eye of the beholder. Aiming down the pistol or sniper, the cross hairs/sights don't stay still. I get this may be applicable of real life, but it feels bad missing shots because my hand eye coordination is terrible, in the game. But this is kind of up to you. Some games, the aimer doesn't sway, some does. Take your pick. 
(-) Some areas blocked off in beginning. There's a red mist that I'm assuming that hurts you, IDK cause I haven't tried. Maybe I should try, but again I lose money on death. But I wish I could go into these areas or into more but can't because of what I assume are vampire farts. I suppose a diet of ONLY human blood would turn your gas particles into red mist right? I wouldn't know, but I am an engineer so let's just say I'm right.
(-) [b]Lack of friends[/b]. If you were to play with a friend, I think you can be revived. As well as help each other out and do other stuff etc. Some of the passives help your team. But you know, with a lack of friends that play games with me I guess that's what I deserve. Not that I'm really missing out, but WHY DO I HAVE A ELDRITCH RAVEN IF IT CAN'T REVIVE ME... RIDDLE ME THAT.

All in all I think this game has been good so far and you should give into your desires and play with me. The price point DOES seem a little steep. But if money is no issue, then shoot for the stars! Although stars tend to be like the sun, so if you're a vampire, probably best to not right? Also isn't moonlight reflected sunlight? Hello plot holes... Just kidding. Is it worth $70? As far as a metric, people usually use the $1-2/hr/game right? If you play 35-70 hours of this game it should be worth it. This is quite impossible since the game just released, and I do work a 9-5 so just keep track of my hours above. This review is also coming from a huge fan and patient waiter of the 'Vampire Masquerade Bloodlines 2' game. Which will never release because the game studio is doing exactly what they did to my boy 'Titanfall 3'. They made a Battle Royale instead of developing the next best thing. Rest in peace BT. But this looks like it will be a good place holder and a good game to play in the meantime that will give me and you our fix.

Writing a review to refute the whinging:

Bad performance? I'm playing max settings at 5120x1440 with a 7900XTX and a 5800X3D. One member of my three-man squad is using a near 8 year old midrange rig and playing at 1440p with no issues. Another is using a 3070Ti and a 3600X at 1440p, again, with no issues. Maybe look at your crap rig before complaining. Sucks to suck.

Bad port? This shows zero signs of being a port at all, let alone being a bad one.

Bad graphics? You do realize this is this studio's art style? Have you never seen Dishonored, or Prey? Sorry but you're delusional for expecting photorealism. These aren't bad graphics by any stretch.

Coop is broken? Strange, my three-man squad experienced perfect coop. Invite sent, accepted, and away we went. If you can't coop, maybe pull a couple braincells together and troubleshoot your crap network.

Waah no matchmaking? Good. I wouldn't want you scrubs in my game. Sorry foreveralones, you have to actually *try* to make some friends.

This game is boring? Sounds like a personal problem.

Steam reviews are becoming worse than metacritic. It seems they let any toddler with a keyboard write a review these days...

I think the game so far is quite fun. Sure some things render a little slowly but my laptop isn't the best. I think my 2 biggest complaints are: 1) some hit box issues when near terrain (hard to headshot a guy that's juuusst peaking a corner or wall and 2) The AI seems a little dim witted, but I'm sure that's an easy enough fix.

I've only spent 1.5hrs playing this game so my review is limited. From what I've seen of the game, I'll, sadly, be refunding it.

Coming from the devs who made Dishonored series, Prey and Deathloop, I had some high expectations for Redfall. Unfortunately, all the things that I loved about those games seem to be lacking here. The level design is not as unique, the characters seem hollow, the gun play is just ok, and the graphics look shockingly outdated for a new release, let alone a brand new IP from a AAA developer. Both Deathloop, DH2 and even Prey look much better than Redfall. 

Overall, it feels unpolished and rushed. Really disappointing coming from Arkane...

Gamspot's Mark Delaney sums up my feelings on Redfall: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cqYvMt_CBKo

Ok so let me explain the game so far and put into perspective some of the negativity. The game isnt that bad, its actually entertaining. That being said; it was sort of billed as this "Left 4 Dead" style game which it is sorely not. This game is basically more like Dead Island than Left for Dead. The single player is the main focus and the multiplayer is basically rendered to an after thought in some aspects because they do nothing to encourage it. This is very sad considering the trailers and demo game play make it look like the next big coop multiplayer game like Left 4 Dead. Additionally the AI is ridiculously dumb for a AAA game. I mean stupid dumb... I cant believe they let it pass like this. The AI basically is super predictable, runs at you just to be shot. The vampire AI is slightly better but I almost feel like they dumbed down the humans so much to make the Vampires seem more challenging. The Vampires are basically the same situation but a bit more tanky. They run at you, jump at you, and warp around you. They are very easy to predict. Overall I would recommend buying this game on a steam sale.

1. Go to this place
2. Find an item
3. Go to the basement for a reason
4. End mission

Massive disappointment from Arkane and Bethesda

I really tried to ignore the reviews and base this off my own opinion, the opening to game i was really feeling it and enjoying it but was quickly let down by how much running and jump in jump out of combat i was doing just on the second the mission alone i do not recommend this at $70

So I was in love with the cinematics and the gameplay provided here and in youtube intrigued me.


So I decided to bite the bullet, play a bit and hopefully put some gameplays on my youtube channel.

The moment I launched I was greeted with 3 consecutive crashes.
The irony? the "send report and restart" did not even work.
The application was still alive in the background and I had to kill all the 3 copies by hand.
Strangely, the 4th time It ran normally.
then you get greeted by one of the largest annoyances you could find.
A DAMN INTERNAL LOGIN SYSTEM... 

PERFORMANCE:
There is some sort of weird jitter/stuttering issue with this game..
RivaTunner/MSIafterburner with a 4090 RTX had this very constant "spike".
The spike was not that large but you could see the jitter when you moved sideways.
Very similar of the deformation you see when DLSS3 was turned on.
Running natively (4k, epic quality)  alleviated the issues a bit. But was still there.
Some people mentioned this is because the engine used? (Unity) and many games needed patches to fix this.
Why then in 2023... after so many years fixing and experiencing these issues... the games still have it when using this engine? No idea.

Gameplay wise:

Think of this like a mixture between Borderlands and Left4dead.
The bad? there are loot mechanics.. That means you could crap your pants at first and get a legendary.
But as time goes by. Enemies boost in power and you will need to ditch your precious legendaries for weapons of higher level but with worse rarity ( you have level and rarity variations).
You also get special powers, 3 of them... for each character. 1 basic, 2 medium and an ultimate.
There is also a leveling system that improves these skills based in a branch system. 


So far I noticed the weapon has plenty of weapon classes with subclasses.
Example, shotgun has pump, double, and auto.

Weapon classes are pistols, shotguns, assault rifles, UV weapon,  flaregun, stake launcher, sniper rifle.
Certain weapons are better against humans while others decimate vampires.
So weapon wise, theres plenty to experiment.  Plus some skins of the legendary weapons are great. 

The bad about weapons: Your ammo is mostly limited, specially the strong ones like sniper rifle.
Sniper aim plus the weird inputlag/jitter  affects how the shots register. trajectory also does not follow the scope.
So you might think you're going to shot an enemy in cover, but you end hitting the cover instead (yes, when zoomed in).
So I ended missing a lot of easy shots and ended running out of ammo.

The worst? almost all ammo is for shotgun and pistols in my gameplay so far.

Enemies: Enemies are... well.. very generic.
You get the humans of 2 factions that fight AGAINST you.
Then you have some ones with "powerups". These are the classic pistol, shotgun, assault rifle and sniper variants.
Then you have vampires.

Ironically I ended dying more by traps (laser trip mines) and environmental damage (the same explosion of the trip mines triggered electrical damage nearby..) than dying by enemies.

The map is very detailed and pretty decent in size. Almost looks like a real town.
The bad.. enemies appear randomly (you can see them on the horizon spawning as you approach). Only certain zones have predefined enemies for quests or setting up safe houses).

Gameplay wise: While the game feels a bit clunky, it is varied and effective.
Still no way nearby gems like Prey, Borderlands or Bioshock.
Infact, the videos shown by the publisher related to gameplay.. looked enhanced as crap compared to what you get in reality.
Lore and Story papers are scattered around. It's decent so far I guess.

The most annoying stuff: YOU CAN GET STUCK IN SO MANY PLACES AND YOU HAVE TO RELOAD!

To resume: Not worth it if you get bored easily with loot mechanics and "go here do this" kind of missions.
And def not worth 70$ and the deluxe season pass versions completely not worth the money.

First Impression Grade: C- 
Want a Spooky FarCry style co-op adventure with Borderlands loot progression? Can you deal with jank and bad UI in an effort to have spooky fun?
I look forward to enjoying this with the friends I want to play it with, and it will get better with a patch/update or two.
Expensive, and jank, but its the mood and the experience I want right now.

Criticism:
It is not very pretty, it feels very un-optimized and messy. I had a few crashes, went and updated drivers, turned down a few settings and we still had some major slow down and lag, but it did work.
Feels way bloated and slow for the amount of game that it is doing, needs optimization.
Very much feels like a console first UI and design with PC second kind of play.
Feels like I should wait for the first DLC and a few update patches to really enjoy this.
AI is really bad. But fun bad.
This does NOT feel like a $70 premium experience.

If you want a better co-op game stick with Back 4 Blood, but RedFall is going to be more of the spooky adventure

I would not purchase this game in its current state. This game feels very bad, combat was clunky at best. As a content creator, I did make it 1/2 way through the story in 4.5 hours, and I feel this is not worth $70-100. I wish I would have stopped before the 2 hours and asked for a refund. I do have a high-end PC with a 4090 and it was only using 30-40%, same with my CPU around 30-40%. FPS fluctuated between 40 and 144, with it usually around 40-60 FPS. Its not fun running around the same house looking for a key item for 10 minutes then you fight a boss that lasts 10 seconds. Game feels empty, game feels incomplete. Honestly a title that I could see an indie studio making and charging around $10-20 for it.

Loving it so far

Before I start, I received Redfall for free from a GPU purchase deal.

Redfall is another opportunity and potential video game that could have been better and probably failed due to rough polishing and rushed features.

- Redfall's AI is way too basic and is extremely easy to deal with for players who play on normal difficulties.
- The environment to me makes me feel a little sick and almost like I'm in a fantasy dream. I've never thought a game could convince me that Fire Trucks are imaginary in real life and do not exist.
- The character art and detail are way off and every NPC character looks like an action figure where you can tell they're fake and don't blend in to the environment and stand out way too much. (I played solo, so I don't know what other player characters look like.)
- No public matchmaking is just a massive mistake for these types of games. Games with four-player co-op and online multiplayer should have a public match-making system.
- Weapons aren't satisfying; they just added a stake on some weapons and said, "Yea, this is cool!" and didn't pay attention to the sound design or polishing of the guns. The scale of these weapons in the first person is crazy huge as well.
- Capture Post cut scenes are just characters frozen in a pose like they're talking to each other, and there was no animation. It was like going through a mannequin museum, and it felt way too creepy and uncomfortable
- With a lot more polish and updates, I could see this being a game I'll go back to playing, but for now, this is not worth $70...

Absolute trash. 

This game quite literally puts how bad Cyperpunk was at launch to shame. Think even worse graphical bugs, barely playable framerate's (pretty decent computer), braindead AI, and the hard difficulty isn't even hard thanks to the AI.
Cyberpunk promised a populated, alive city. It delivered when compared to this, given that i had to run around for 30-40 minutes after the tutorial to find my first group of people.

Avoid this for at least the next year, or go to your local park and have a nice campfire with cash as fuel.

(Edit: I'm editing this review to say that i don't mean any disrespect towards the developers at arkane even though it may come off that way. This disaster is likely just a corporate issue like with most triple A titles.)

The game runs perfectly fine for me and my friends. The graphics are cartoony which I don't mind but some might. The world is empty.. Only certain areas are loaded with vamps or cultists. In an "open world" game there should be enemies around every corner. The world is cool and interesting to explore and tons of stuff to collect and find but no one around. The guns are in variety and rarity colors but the gun play is nothing exciting and slow. The AI also kinda just walk right at you or stand still. The talent system is cool and character abilities are neat. Different vampire enemies to fight and bosses is cool. Can't really comment on story due to spending hours exploring and doing side missions than main quest lol. Wish my friends and I could refund but we figured we'd give it a shot so ya'll don't have to. These new AAA games pricing at $70 and being garbage now a days are such a let down and show developers no longer care about the passion of making a good game and care more about cash grabbing. Made from Dishonored company and published by Bethesda?? what an absolute shame and stain on their reputation this game is.

This just ain't it chief.

the game is good but very glitchy some monsters are glitch out but good game

I read all the reviews and was hopeful that most of the issues were just performance related but the game was still solid. This was very much not the case. Surprisingly my performance was decent, but the gameplay itself is just bad. The AI is so horrible I started just completely ignoring shooting people. I would just run in and do the objective and then get out. I did  this without even getting shot by any enemies.

If I had a nickel for every Left4Dead clone with "fall" in the name that I absolutely loved and played until my fingers bled, I'd have 2 nickels. Yeah, I know, that's not very much - but still, weird that it happened twice!

It's stunning how good this game could've been without all the Division nonsense grafted onto it. Buried under all the terrible looter shooter contrivances is an original and cruelly effective narrative about the rich eating the poor, told against the backdrop of a quaint coastal town that is so damn detailed I think I actually stayed there a few years back when visiting PEI. It's worth experiencing, but only if you're willing to trudge through repetitive open world chores and listen to dead-eyed Ubisoft-style NPCs riding your dick with unearned praise.

I saw the reviews and was worried it would be another Jedi Survivor situation. I can safely say the performance issues are definetly not as bad as people make them out to be. Sure, there are some areas where my frames dropped for a second when I entered them, but no more than that. I do not have a top of the line rig. I play with a 2060 on medium with solid 60 frames. A drop here and there while entering a new area but nothing I couldn't manage. The game itself seems like a lot of fun. The map you get to explore feels familiar to a cross between Arcadia bay from the original Life is Strange and Union from The Evil Within 2. The gunplay is decent albeit a little easy. The AI isn't too smart. As far as the playable characters go, I've been playing as Jacob and he's a fun stealth character. I can't comment on the others nor on co-op, since I have yet to try that.

Alright, after about 14 hours, I can happily say that I enjoy the game. It certainly has it's issues which include framerate drops/dumb ai/ and being a tad easy. (when I'm not being gangbanged by 30 cultists and vampires) 
But honestly, Im having FUN. I killed my entire evening playing solo campaign as Layla. 
While the game definitely needs fixing, I think there's SO SO much potential here for something great, and I already think it's pretty great. I've been a long time fan of Arkane Games and even when I heard the bad reviews coming in I knew I would enjoy the game regardless. It has that Arkane feel I look for when I'm playing an Arkane game. 

That being said, when I'm playing solo those issues listed are my only ones. Co-op is a different story however, and I found it to be very buggy.  Some crashes here and there (about 3-4 during 3-4 hour session with a full squad) but we still had FUN we're all laughing and running around murdering cultists and vampires. It really sucks that this game is getting such a bad rep right now, but I can see why that is and certainly those issues need to be fixed, but I personally believe that as it is right now, it's not that bad. honestly. It's fun, and that's all I look for when I play a game. If you're testy about the pricetag you should wait for a sale imo, but otherwise give it a go, it's a fun immersive sim.

didn't encounter any of the technical issues running around, it's just a mediocre game.  i expected as mush but it sucks that arkane has been shoved into this dumb co-op gaas thing.  elements of arkane are there but its underwhelming at best.  i sincerely hope bethesda stops trying to do this and goes back to what they do best.  however, it's still kind of a fun little shooter, but def not worth 70$.  i would pay that for god of war willingly, this almost seems like it should be f2p.

im really disappointed in this game the trailers made it look really good. lots of people are having problems running the game but my issue is with the game play itself. its so easy that you can ignore most of the systems. vampires should be scary but most you can 2 shot with a sniper or pop with a shotgun its a joke. the trailers made it look like every vampire would be a fight but its just a joke. this game is still half backed at launch as so many "AAA" games are these days. what a shame.

I can see where the negative reviews are coming from, though looking at the forums the last few days, it seems a lot of people went into the game ready to hate it (somewhat evidenced by the number of reviews with less than an hour). The price tag is high, and the game launched with some glaring issues. That said, even the worst issue I found (graphical issue with sniper scope sometimes) was not at all game-breaking, and will almost certainly be addressed in the week 1 patch.

I personally did not suffer any major performance issues, my game ran between 53-60 fps for the majority of my playtime, though I did drop to around 40 in the theatre. (RTX 2060, ryzen 5 3600, 32gb, medium settings, 2560x1440).

In terms of the actual gameplay, the different enemies so far have been pretty unique, with some having some very cool mechanics I hadn't seen before in other games. The gunplay was entertaining, and the character I played had some fun abilities. I can't comment on the other characters as I haven't tried them, but Layla's elevator made for some awesome plays in co-op. Exploration is also rewarded with items and collectibles, which is nice.

It's hard to go into more depth with just a couple of hours played, but I'm looking forward to seeing more from this title.

My advice would be to take the negative reviews with a grain of salt. While I truly hate this trend of games being released with obvious bugs, at least in my case, I didn't encounter anything major. Co-op worked perfectly for me, with one friend on steam and another on gamepass, and as mentioned, even with my pretty average setup the game ran smoothly with only relatively minor drops in one area.

$70 is IMO pretty expensive for a game, so maybe wait for the week 1 patch and see what folks are saying then (or just try it out on gamepass). In my case, I've had fun with it so far and am excited for more laughs in co-op.

So a note of as much constructive criticism to the developers as I can give

I was really excited for this game. I was unfortunately heavily disappointed. .

The game is extremely easy to the point of boredom, even on the highest difficulty.

Every house has 5-10 guns in it, with the player able to obtain purple loot in less than an hour (on the highest difficulty setting). 

I found myself trying to create my own challenge by only playing the entire game... multiple hours in, with a pistol and was still almost instantly killing every enemy I came into contact with. 

It just needs a lot of balancing. But it needs more than that...

There is all of this cool loot all over the map... but it serves no function and instantly gets translated into cash... I would almost be more satisfied if (like borderlands... / honestly the closest game experience to this game.. except much better) you just replaced all of that loot with actual cash and made all of those loot models decorative. 

Also if you play with a friend the loot the 2 of you receive is different but there is no way (that we could figure out after hours) to trade or drop guns or loot... only to turn those guns...you guessed it.. into more space bucks or blood dollars or whatever they are. 

I am not trying to just tear this game down... I truly hope the devs are able to rebuild what they have here into a playable experience but this is NOT worth 70$

This is like a well put together early access game at best

Sorry folks but honestly the price is just irritating with this level of quality. 

I am surprised Bethesda let this ship in the state that it is in with their name on it

Please take the 350+ "mostly negative" reviews so far... 6 hours into launch and read what we have to say... because like stated above... you really have potential with this, it just really missed the mark of what was promised.

This is the first Arkane game that I don't enjoy.

Despite the difference in genre from most Arkane titles, I was excited. The trailers made this game look fun. Despite the difference in genre, I'd like to point to how good Prey 2017 was (despite the low sales and poor ending) and what [i]could have been[/i] for Arkane Austin's Redfall...

[b]Redfall's open world is empty, and the enemies that populate it are hilariously dumb.[/b] Let me touch on both:

I think a good way to describe the open world is with an example. On the north-east side of town, there's a house you can actually enter. It's a normal house, furnished although a large amount of empty space in it. In the backyard, there's a large shed that you can also enter. For about 50 meters around the shed, there is nothing but flat, freshly cut grass. No bushes, flowers, nothing. And inside this large shed? Nothing. An empty, fully textured shed with a pool leaning up against the wall.
[b]The world feels like it's too big for itself, and yet in 3 hours I had been around half of the whole town.[/b] I noticed that a truck with cultists had spawned and the disappeared later on, meaning that the empty space is supposed to be filled with things that can change. Which would be neat, if it happened more than once...

Now, I had seen the pre-release footage. I knew enemies ran towards you instead of shooting in an open space. I was hoping that the harder difficulty would make them less dumb, but all the difficulty seems to do is boost the damage done. Now I was also thinking "oh it's an Arkane game, they're meant to be dumb so that I can find fun ways to kill them!" There are so few ways to go about doing that: guns, and your abilities that do pitiful amounts of damage. No throwable props, no stealth take-downs/back-stabs, and environmental damage props maybe every 200 meters.
I also came to notice that groups of enemies would spawn behind me quite often. Anywhere I wasn't looking, in the heat of battle, enemies would spawn in a room I had just cleared. I actually saw them spawn at one point. Maybe I had whipped around too fast or something? 

Despite being a different Arkane studio, it's worth making the comparison. DEATHLOOP, despite it's arguably worse optimisation, is a better game. It even shares some of the same RPG gimmicks as Redfall. I wanted to love Redfall, and I want Arkane to prove me wrong and make me buy this again in the future once they do something with it. Given Bethesda's track record of dropping things that don't sell well (they did it to Prey 2017 and DEATHLOOP), I don't see that happening.

Sitting at $101.69 CAD, I cannot in good faith recommend Redfall at all, and during writing this I have been given a refund.

I really want to like this game (and I do) but as it is right now, I cannot recommend it. 

Love the vampire slaying, love the characters + their abilities. It's very much an Arkane take on Borderlands + Far Cry with the open world hero looty shooty concept. However, for an island that is supposedly overrun by vampires + cultists, it's empty. Enemies are dumb and don't detect you even after you shoot at them a couple times (tried to headshot a cultist and missed THREE times before they became aware). Vampires are better enemies but still too easy to defeat. Loot is very inconsistent in the sense that you find "epic" and "legendary" items VERY early and VERY often. In one instance I opened a bag that gave me three snipers, each a different tier. I'm not gonna complain about good loot (hehe) but if I'm always gonna find legendary items, there just doesn't seem to be a need for the tier system, if that makes sense.

You would think that after Cyberpunk 2077's controversial release that all game devs would know what NOT to do (release an unfinished game) but some lessons don't stick even in 2023. This game is buggy, glitchy, runs poorly........... it's  U N F I N I S H E D. I'm not the type to let performance make or break a game for me too much, as long as everything else is really enjoyable, but that's not what's happening here. I would rather devs delay the game until it's great then release it half baked.

Also, what's the point of co-op if mission progress isn't shared? To ME, that's zero incentive to even try it out. Might just be a "me" thing though, idk.

I do think that after some updates, patches, bug fixes, AI balances and what not, the game could be pretty good. Great, almost. I want to like this game. I want to play this game all the way through...but not in it's current state. I'll be requesting a refund and keeping an eye out for updates to see if anything has improved. I would like to revisit this game after it's gotten what it deserves: help.

Maybe one day they can go in and give it the Cyberpunk treatment, but right now, I'm just hoping I get my 70 dollars back.

A fun game despite the FPS and Minor Graphical issues. Though I don't think it's worth the $70. $70 would have been the optimal price for the Deluxe Edition, but not the base game.

First off it isn't really how they made the marketing seem like it was. This is a Single Player game that happens to have Coop. This is not a Coop Vampire shooter like we were made to believe.

As an open-world co-op shooter, Redfall is a refreshing entry into the genre that more or less hits all the right notes. Arkane‚Äôs remarkable knack for art direction is ever present throughout the vampire ranks, with out-of-proportion hands, shiny trench coats and gnarled expressions bringing the fear factor when they‚Äôre up close. Siphons drain your life force, Shrouds cover the arena in darkness, and Anglers can hook you towards them for a deadly uninterruptible blow. This all comes together to create a superb setting, where you get to explore the pithy backstories of each Vampire God before you face them, seeking out guilt-ridden remnants of their past to expose vulnerabilities.

What really hurts Redfall the most is the dismal shape it‚Äôs in. Stuttering and sharp dips in the framerate are just the beginning here. Graphical anomalies are pretty much constant, with textures failing to load and shadows flickering. After some updates however, Redfall will become another Arkane gem. I just wish they would have made the price more reasonable because as is the $70 price tag is going to deter a lot of people from playing the game until one of Steams many discounts.

Pros
-------
- Vampires are done gruesomely well
- Engaging ability-based combat with room to specialise
- An inspired setting with a thick, immersive, open-world atmosphere
- A fun story with plenty to say
- Plenty to do with your friends in co-op

Cons
-------
- The focus on action can get in the way of narrative nuance
- Arkane‚Äôs strengths struggle to shine through

Remember that time you saw the movie Cats and thought to yourself, 'Wow, that was the biggest mistake of my life?" Well, playing this game is like reliving that experience all over again. If you haven't seen the Cats movie or played this game, save yourself the trouble and don't do either...

Even if you completely IGNORE all the DAY 1 bugs and just ask yourself "Is it fun to play?" - The answer is NO (For a $70 title, this is completely unacceptable)

Overall: 2.5/10 (Save your $70...and go buy Hogwarts Legacy instead)

Performance: 3/10
...Disclaimer: I have a RTX 4070 TI and intel i9 ...The game ran like hot garbage.
      -Poor frame rate
      -Jittering
      -Frame Rate Drops
      -Crashed multiple times
      -Just overall not optimized at all.

Story: 2/10
      -I can see what they were going for...but its like they crammed the crappiest parts of AAA titles into one REALLY bad story. It's like if you took the most confusing parts of Inception and the Matrix and they had a baby...

Gameplay: 2/10
     -Lackluster weapons system...You can only mod the paint and "stake"appearance
     -Lots of random items to pick up in the world and to loot out of the trunks of cars...(which glow btw)...oh wait, they have no purpose as they are only worth $$$...Pack of Toilet Paper = $450. Its like they tried to take any crafting system (division 2) but completely remove crafting.
     -There are safehouses with no purpose...
     -You can buy lockpicks & Rewiring kits...but have no fear...you can just climb through a window...
     -Questing seems random with NO side story whats-so-ever...
     -Fast Travel points on an extremely small map
     -You can pick up loads of items...that don't mean anything...they are just worth $$$
     -Skill Tree!....that is underwhelming...

Look, at the end of the day...game companies need to stop rolling hot piles of garbage and calling them games. TEST your games and stop expecting players to BE the beta testers on DAY one. UNACCEPTABLE.

Great graphics, awesome theme, and fun gameplay so far. Excited to see how leveling into each of the characters feel. I can see the game being a lot of fun with friends.

FIRST IMPRESSIONS 

This is one of those games that needs a meh option. Before the review let me talk about performance:
Spec - RTX3080ti, 32 Ram, i912900K

With these specs I had no real issues with the game. I understand that some people are having worse issues than that, but it is definitely NOT "one of the worst PC launches ever" that is becoming a mantra now. Last of Us and Jedi Survivor are CLEARLY much more broken launches, so let's not call everything the worst ever.

The only real performance issue for me was that It seams that when you move into a new area, sometimes you get a slight pause, but I don't think that is graphics performance issue; I think it is an always on-line loading assets issue like the Diablo 4 beta had and it is a very uncommon occurrence.

I played through one neighborhood so far taking it slow and wandering as much as trying to do a mission. So far here are the ups and downs.

UPS
+ Atmosphere is creepy, but not scary
+ The game feels like a town and the aesthetic is overall good.
+ Weapons are solid and feel punchy. Despite what I have seen some others say, there are definitely several styles of weapon to play with from your basic shotgun, sniper, and handgun (I have yet to see an assault rifle) to the more specific purpose stake shooters, uv guns and flare guns.
+ Weapon levels and quality both are very impactful. Weapon damage seems more level dependent and special modifier quantities are defined by rarity.
+ Exploration is rewarded with lots of different things from rare guns to cosmetics.
+ There is mob diversity so some fights could be interesting, but see below.
+ No inventory concerns. You are frequently picking up items that the civilians can use at hubs and safe houses, but they instantly get converted to cash. So, the only thing you store is guns and even they can be instantly turned into cash.

DOWNS
- The world is too empty. There are too few roaming mobs so far and I have gone through a few buildings now that had only 3-6 mobs in them and one that had NONE. Perhaps this is how they intended to curb the difficulty for single player. But more would definitely be better.
- The AI on most mobs is terrible. I was jumped by a pack of 4 vampires at close range. I should have been dead as I was just starting with mostly crappy weapons, but I killed them because half of them just stood there and they were getting in each others way as they just rushed me.
- Small but significant bugs. That may sound contradictory, but what I mean is that there are glaring bugs that don't break the game in any way. There was one house where a vampire seemed to have gotten stuck in the ceiling and just stood there unavailable but not doing anything. In another place, I opened a chest and it displayed nothing, but then I shut it and walked away. When I came back, it was full of stuff. Things like that.
- Odd immersive element choices, there are things that are just... odd and disconnected feeling about the game. You are picking up everything from rope to toilet paper for your survivors, but not aspirin or many other obvious and small essentials laying around. You also don't pick up food for them. Food is for small heals. You would think that, if you are full on health and you pick up a food item it would just cash itself for the community but it doesn't. So, I guess you are supposed to just leave it there? There was another place where there was a big deal made about a furnace in the basement and when I got to the place that allowed me to unlock the furnace... nothing happened and nothing was in there.
- The graphics, while not terrible are very average and enemy motions are stilted and awkward. Even with fast vampires they are not liquid and menacing. They are marionettes with invisible strings. The cultists move more naturally, but they are pretty brain dead so they seem more like zombies in very small quantities.

I would say that this game is pretty half baked, but that would not be fair as it is playable and there was only a bug or two that I saw. The main problem seems to be more design oriented than being launched to early.

I average 120-240 fps so far @ 5120x1440p everything set to EPIC and FOV 100
7900xtx 
5800x3d
32gb drr4 3200mhz ram

I'm enjoying it so far. AI is pretty easy. Not sure if I should raise difficulty?

2 hrs in, day 1

Easily met the min spec requirements
Playing on High settings with a cpl of setting tweaked

Weird tree & bush leaf flickers
Outline for intractable objects extremely blurry
Some FPS drop (went in a cave, no issues. went in the same cave later, fps dropped to 10)
Some traversal stuttering when running and jumping

Gameplay seems fun, but also a bit too easy, so far anyways

meh

I have an I7 6300 and a 1080TI running at 1440p 60 fps and I've had 0 performance issues on high settings, I don't get why so many people are? There was an issue with the menu lagging a little right at the beginning but that seemed to correct itself before I even got to the firehouse.

I can understand the AI issue though, while it's not been as bad as some reviews I've seen (the vampires haven't been getting stuck on doors etc), the cultists seem to be hesitant to shoot at me even on harder difficulties, and I feel like the vampires should be spongier. Right now my blue tier assault rifle can down one in 5 hits to the head which isn't hard to do. It's far from the worst game I've ever played for the price, it has potential and I could see some tweaks being needed to make it a good AAA experience.

Finished the first zone with a buddy.
We chose the raven dude and the teleporter dude so we could mark most enemies before we engaged and had a way to get up cliffs and stuff easy.

We killed the first Underboss and called it a night.
So day 1 review was it was a lot of fun with a friend and we plan to keep going all week.
Cheers.
=============================================================
Update after the weekend
Still having fun.
We had 2 crashes over the weekend.  
Had one issue when transition from the east map to the west one where I could not load in.  
We rebooted and all and still couldn't load in.  I launched in solo and it loaded and we were back at it.
There were a couple bosses that kinda bugged out mid-fight and just freeze mid-air.
I would recommend the game for maybe $30 tops if you're looking for a casual looter shooter.
Its buggy and has technical issues but it is playable.
